MirabelaProject Page: 16 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Mirabela Brazil successfully tendered to CBPM and Rio Salitre to explore and, if successful 
with exploration, then mine the Contract Tenements upon the terms of the Contract.  
Pursuant to the Contract, CBPM and Rio Salitre grant access to Mirabela Brazil to the 
Contract Tenements and Mirabela Brazil is obliged to undertake an exploration programme 
in accordance with its technical proposal (the "Exploration Program").  The Exploration 
Program consists of 24 months of exploration, improving infrastructure, interpretation of 
previous data, drilling, geophysics, petrography, soil sampling, reports and economic 
feasibility studies. 

Mirabela Brazil must spend a minimum of 1,500,000 Reals (R$) on the Exploration 
Program and complete the Exploration Program by 17 October 2005, being two years from 
the execution of the Contract (the "Contract Period"). 

Mirabela Brazil must commence the Exploration Program within three months of execution 
of the Contract (by 17 January 2004), which it has done. 

Mirabela Brazil has sole responsibility for the Exploration Program and will, amongst other 
things, provide equipment, materials and labour, be obliged to restore damaged areas, pay 
any compensation to landowners or third parties, and pay any relevant taxes and fees. 

Mirabela Brazil must submit a progress report on exploration bi-monthly to CBPM and 
further submit a detailed report every six months.  Upon completion of the Exploration 
Program by 17 October 2005 (see below), Mirabela Brazil must submit to CBPM a final 
report of the Exploration Program including economic feasibility studies of mineral deposits 
that may be found (the "Final Report").  If CBPM approves the Final Report, CBPM will 
forward the Final Report to the Mine Bureau of Brazil ("DNPM").  Upon approval of the 
Final Report by the DNPM, Mirabela Brazil must obtain DNPM authorisation through the 
presentation to the DNPM of an economic profitability plan, an environmental licence and 
other documents needed to obtain a Mining Licence.  On 17 October 2005 a variation to 
the contract was signed allowing Mirabela an additional 18 months to complete the 
Exploration Program and submit the report.  The final exploration report was submitted to 
the DNPM on 18 September 2006. 

Mirabela Brazil is responsible for ensuring the continued good standing of the Contract 
Tenements. 

Mirabela Brazil and CBPM will form a technical support committee, with two members 
appointed by each party, which will have the role of overseeing the technical work of the 
Exploration Program and the assessment of minerals. 

If Mirabela Brazil's actions or omissions result in the loss of mineral rights concerning the 
Contract Tenements, Mirabela Brazil will pay CBPM as compensation R$500,000 as varied 
by the general market price index of Brazilian inflation ("IGPM"). 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 17 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Mirabela Brazil can terminate the Contract by notice of termination to CBPM within the 
Contract period and payment of a cancellation fee to CBPM of one half of the difference 
between R$1,500,000 and the value of duly documented expenses incurred by Mirabela 
Brazil in undertaking the Exploration Program. 

CBPM can terminate the Contract if Mirabela Brazil fails to complete the Exploration 
Program within the Contract Period, in which event Mirabela Brazil will pay a fine to CBPM 
of R$1,500,000. 

CBPM may further terminate the Contract if Mirabela Brazil, at the end of the Contract 
Period, fails to submit documented proof to CBPM of the costs incurred by Mirabela Brazil 
in the Exploration Program to a minimum of R$1,500,000.  In such an event, Mirabela 
Brazil will pay a fine to CBPM of the difference between R$1,500,000 and the value of duly 
documented expenses incurred by Mirabela Brazil on the Exploration Program. 

CBPM and/or Rio Salitre, as registered holders of the Contract Tenements, are obliged to 
enter into a mining lease in favour of Mirabela Brazil ("Mining Lease") upon the following 
events: 

� Mirabela Brazil completing the Exploration Program during the Contract Period and 
having spent a minimum of R$1,500,000. 

� Mirabela Brazil completing economic viability work for the mining of nickel mineral 
deposits situated upon the Contract Tenements so that economic viability plans and 
Mining Licence applications are registered with the DNPM. 

� Mirabela Brazil implementing the mineral industrial project for the mining, exploitation 
and commercialisation of the mineral products derived from the nickel mineral 
deposits upon the Contract Tenements. 

� Mirabela Brazil having paid the transfer premium of R$510,000 to CBPM for each 
Exploration Licence converted to a Mining Licence. 

Upon the satisfaction of the above conditions, CBPM and/or Rio Salitre will enter into a 
Mining Lease of the nickel ore deposits upon the Contract Tenements in favour of Mirabela 
Brazil.  The Mining Lease will be for a term of 20 years from the date of publication of 
registration of the Mining Lease with the DNPM.  Mirabela Brazil, as the lessee, will pay all 
taxes, development and operational costs and keep the tenements in good standing.  
CBPM and/or Rio Salitre, as a lessor, will grant to Mirabela Brazil the right of access as 
soon as the Mining Lease is registered with the DNPM.  Mirabela Brazil, as the lessee, will 
pay CBPM and/or Rio Salitre royalties on a monthly basis for the leasing of the mining 
rights of nickel sulphide ores and nickel laterite ores.  The royalties will be paid in Brazilian 
Reals and will be as follows: 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 18 
Technical Report – May 2008 

� Royalty for Sulphide Ore - The lessee will pay the equivalent of 2.51% of the gross 
revenue from the sales or conversion of concentrates of nickel produced from 
sulphide ore, calculated on the basis of 60% of the market value of nickel contained 
in the concentrate, added to the market value of other metals contained in the 
concentrate which are economically recoverable and vendible, expressed in nickel-
equivalent, including cobalt, gold and metals in the platinum group. 

� Royalty for the Laterite Ore - The royalty for the laterite ore will be based upon each 
tonne of extracted mineral, converted or sold, according to the scale below: 

� the equivalent to US$2.01/t of laterite ore, when the value of nickel at the 
London Metal Exchange is higher than US$9,000 per metric tonne; 

� the equivalent to US$1.51/t of laterite ore, when the value of nickel at the 
London Metal Exchange is between US$8,000 and US$9,000 per metric tonne; 
and 

� the equivalent to US$1.01/t of laterite ore, when the value of nickel at the 
London Metal Exchange is lower than US$8,000 per metric tonne. 

� Royalty for Other Metals Contained in the Laterite Ore - The royalty for such other 
metals economically recoverable including cobalt, gold, and metals of the platinum 
group, etc, will be the equivalent in Brazilian Reals to US$0.31/t of extracted mineral 
transferred or sold. 

The expression "market value" in respect of the above royalties refers to the rates of nickel 
and associated metals at the London Metal Exchange.  The payment of the various 
royalties must be made before the 15th day of each month and a late penalty of 10% on the 
debit balance calculated daily on the basis of fluctuations of the general market price index 
will apply. 

Mirabela Brazil will further pay royalties to CBPM and/or Rio Salitre, according to the 
royalties in the Mining Lease on any profit or revenue derived from the sale of mineral and 
nickel concentrates, and related products obtained from the Contract Tenements, under the 
Exploration Program prior to the execution of the Mining Lease. 

Under the Mining Lease, Mirabela Brazil as lessee will pay a transfer premium of 
R$510,000 in favour of the lessor within 10 working days of the date of publication of the 
conversion of an Exploration Licence to a Mining Licence.  The payment of R$510,000 is 
indexed in accordance with the IGPM.  If the relevant payment is not made, Mirabela 
Brazil's rights as lessee over the respective tenement are relinquished. 

The lessor may terminate the Mining Lease if: 

� Mirabela Brazil does not commence mining activities within 90 days from registration 
of the Mining Lease; or 

� Mirabela Brazil does not complete the full installation of the nickel concentrate 
production facility to utilise the minerals extracted from the mineral deposits within a 
period of two years from the date of execution of the Mining Lease; or 

� Mirabela Brazil fails to comply with any of its requirements under the Mining Lease. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 19 
Technical Report – May 2008 

In any of the above events, Mirabela Brazil will pay a penalty of R$500,000 upon 
termination of the Mining Lease.  Mirabela Brazil, as the lessee, is obliged to take the 
necessary steps to register the Mining Lease.  Brazilian law will apply to the Contract and 
any subsequent Mining Lease in the jurisdiction of Salvador. 

MNL has arranged access with local landowners to conduct project evaluation activities 
and exploration as required over the Exploration Licences within the tenement schedule. 

4.4.1 Environmental Liabilities and Permits 

There are no environmental liabilities associated with the tenements.  Permits for clearing 
of vegetation are required where gridlines are opened in forested areas.  Drilling operations 
require appropriate approvals for clearing of vegetation, and licences for pumping and 
utilization of surface water.  Mirabela have retained the services of environmental 
consulting group Arcoverde Consultoria e Projetos for all aspects of the environmental 
management of the tenements. 

As a requirement for the environmental licensing of the development project a 
comprehensive Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) has been completed and was 
submitted to the State environmental authority on the 21 September 2006.  

The EIA has been approved by State Environmental Board of Bahia and the Location 
License ("Licença de Localização") has been granted.  Notification of the granting of the 
Location License ("Licença de Localização") has been published in the official gazette of 
the State government on 23 December 2006.  Construction License ("Licença de 
Implantação") has been published in the official gazette of the State government on 
28 September 2007. 

 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 20 
Technical Report – May 2008 

5 ACCESSIBILITY, CLIMATE, PHYSIOGRAPHY, LOCAL RESOURCES AND 
INFRASTRUCTURE 

5.1 Access 

The Mirabela Project lies about 2km from the sealed BR330 main highway as shown in 
Figure 4.3_1.  Palestina lies about 25km to the south of Mirabela, close to highway BR030.  
Access within the project areas is by unsealed formed municipal roads and farm tracks. 

5.2 Climate

The Itagiba region is classified as having a humid tropical climate.  Annual rainfall varies 
between 800mm and 1,800mm and averages approximately 1,300mm.  There is no well-
defined dry season.  Monthly average temperatures are above 18°C.   

 

5.2.1 Physiography 

The area is characterised by sub-tropical rainforest, although little remains due to 
deforestation of the area for farming.  Local topography is characterised by flat to gently 
undulating soil-covered terrain at about 150mASL, traversed by a drainage network feeding 
the Rio de Contas.  The terrain is punctuated with rounded hills rising to 350m to 400mASL 
comprising resistant lithologies within the metamorphic terrain, such as banded iron 
formation, and the mafic-ultramafic complexes of Mirabela and Palestina. 

5.2.2 Local Resources and Infrastructure 

The project areas respectively lie adjacent to sealed highways BR330 and BR030.  High-
voltage power supply lines cross the tenement areas.  Land in the area is dominantly used 
for pastoral and agricultural purposes, and farms cover the tenements concerned.  All land 
impacted by mining activities, including associated infrastructure, has been purchased by 
MNL 

Water is provided for industrial and pastoral activity by the Rio de Contas, other major 
watercourses and numerous artesian bores.  A water treatment facility is located in Ipiau to 
supply potable water to the town. 

The towns of Ipiau and Itagiba are well endowed with commercial activity and industrial 
support services such as transport and earthmoving, construction, commercial and 
banking.  The towns provide an excellent source of skilled and unskilled labour. 

Sources of power, tailings storage, and other associated infrastructure items are discussed 
in detail in Sections 16, 18 and 19 of this report. 

 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 21 
Technical Report – May 2008 

6 HISTORY 
6.1 Ownership History 

See Section 6.2 below. 

6.2 Exploration History 

Mineração Nhambú Limitada 1979-1981

The existence of mafic-ultramafic intrusive complexes was first noted following regional 
aeromagnetic surveys by the CPRM in the Itaberaba-Belmonte area in 1976. 

Mineração Nhambú Limitada (a joint venture between BP Minerals and RTZ) conducted a 
regional exploration program for base and precious metals, and in particular gold and 
chrome, in the south of Bahia State between 1979 and 1981.  This area was selected by 
analogy with regions showing similar geological environments and known base metal 
mineralization such as Broken Hill in Australia, Aggeneys in South Africa and Geco in 
Canada (de Souza, 1981).  The area to the south of Ipiaú was assigned a high priority due 
to the presence of north-northeast trending granitic intrusions identified by existing mapping 
(Pedreira et al, 1975). 

Initial exploration comprised a stream sediment and soil sampling program at a density of 
1 sample per 4km2, along with regional mapping at 1:100,000 scale, which led to the 
discovery of two important geochemical anomalies comprising nickel-copper-cobalt near 
Fazenda Mirabela (Mirabela Farm), 8km south-southeast of the town of Ipiaú, and zinc-
copper, located 5km SSE of Ipiaú near Fazenda Ipiranga (Ipiranga Farm).  The first 
anomaly resulted in the discovery of the Fazenda Mirabela mafic-ultramafic intrusion and 
the second resulted in the discovery of a thin (�1m thick), but very extensive (2km strike 
extent) gossan in the Grutinha Salobo area.  Follow-up was conducted at both targets, 
focussing on the former, where ground geophysical (IP and magnetics) and geochemical 
(soil) surveys, geological mapping and two diamond holes totalling 328.88m (MF-01 and 
MF-02) were completed.  As a result of this exploration, Mineração Nhambú concluded 
that: 

� The trend of intrusive bodies shown in the existing mapping by Pedreira et al (1975), 
including the Fazenda Mirabela and Fazenda Palestina bodies, were not of a granitic 
but rather mafic-ultramafic composition. 

� A nickel soil anomaly, with subordinate copper and cobalt, delineates what is now 
known at the Fazenda Mirabela mafic-ultramafic intrusion, measuring some 1,500m 
in length by 250m in width, containing values greater than 3,000ppm Ni (maximum of 
5.83% Ni), interpreted to be of lateritic origin.  The presence of pyrite and pyrrhotite 
was detected in an outcrop of pyroxenite in the northeast of the anomaly, yielding 
values of between 0.53% and 0.78% Ni and >0.14% Cu. 

� The thin, 2km long, Zn-Cu gossan at Grutinha Salobo proved to be barren of 
elevated base metal values and was interpreted to be part of a volcano-sedimentary 
sequence. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 22 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Mineração Nhambú Limitada relinquished the ground in 1981, concluding that the Fazenda 
Mirabela nickel anomaly was of lateritic origin and unrelated to significant primary 
mineralization. 

Caraíba Metais S/A (1985-1989)

Caraíba Metais SA claimed tenements in the Fazenda Mirabela region to explore for 
copper, nickel and PGEs in 1985.  The company carried out geological reconnaissance and 
an orientation soil geochemical survey, prior to executing detailed field work over an area of 
1km2.  This work was restricted to the ultramafic zone of the intrusion, as the company was 
denied surface access to the whole intrusion by the landowners at the time (Carvalho et al, 
1981). 

Detailed prospecting comprised: 

� Geological mapping at 1:5,000 scale, which revealed the Fazenda Mirabela intrusion 
to comprise a north-northwest striking succession, comprising a western ultramafic 
portion of intensely serpentinized peridotites and dunites, and an eastern portion of 
mafic lithologies varying from orthopyroxenites through clinopyroxenites, 
melanogabbronorites and leucogabbronorites to leucogabbros. 

� Soil geochemistry revealed strong copper anomalies (up to 2,500ppm) extending 
over a distance of 1.3km in a north-south orientation, which were not considered to 
reflect superficial effects. 

� Geophysical surveying at 1:5,000 scale on 100m-spaced lines, including gravity, 
magnetics and IP (dipole-dipole array with 40m dipole separation), was completed 
over the ultramafics in the central part of the target.  The magnetic survey delineated 
the contact between the ultramafic and mafic succession.  The gravity survey did not 
define any significant anomalies and the IP survey, whilst hindered by the weathered 
cap, identified a trend of anomalies in the vicinity of the ultramafic-mafic succession 
contact. 

� Five diamond core holes (579.70m) were drilled to test both IP anomalies (FM-01, 
FM-02 and FM-05) and copper soil anomalies (FM-03 and FM-04).  Four of the five 
holes intersected intervals of disseminated nickel and copper sulphides within the 
Fazenda Mirabela mafic-ultramafic intrusion (FM-01, FM-02, FM-03 and FM-04).  The 
sulphides comprised pyrite, pyrrhotite chalcopyrite and pentlandite, and constituted 
approximately 1% by volume, locally reaching 5%.  Atomic absorption analysis (AAS) 
for Au, Pd, Pt, Ir, Ru, Rh, Ag, Cu, Ni, Co, V and Ti was completed on the most 
sulphidic interval intersected in hole FM-02 (total depth 128.45m).  In this hole the 
peridotite and pyroxenite interval from 50m to106m returned an average grade of 
0.65% Ni and 0.2% Cu, with 44% of the analysed samples yielding a combined Ni-Cu 
grade of >1%.  Maximum grades of 820ppb Au, 120ppb Pd, and 720ppb Pt were 
recorded in the interval from 86m to 87m.  The sulphides intersected in holes FM-01, 
03 and 04 were less evident, with better grades intersected in the interval from 82m 
to 84m in hole FM-04, returning 0.72% Ni, 0.14% Cu, 420ppb Au, 620ppb Pd, and 
360ppb Pt. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 23 
Technical Report – May 2008 

� On the basis of conformity with the mineralised tholeiitic intrusive model and 
reasonable consistency between holes, Caraiba Metais SA estimated a resource for 
the 40m thick layer of disseminated sulphides.  The company noted that the resource 
was overlain by a 30m to 40m thick zone of supergene oxides in situ, but undertook 
no investigation of this profile. 

This work confirmed the differentiated character of the intrusion and its magmatic sulphide 
mineralization.  At the time, however, the primary focus of the Caraíba Metals SA 
exploration was for copper-dominant deposits, which, combined with the low metal grades 
encountered and the existing economic conditions, led them to terminate exploration 
activities in the area, ceding their exploration rights to the Companhia Baiana de Pesquisa 
Mineral (CBPM) in 1989. 

CBPM (1989-2002)

The Companhia Baiana de Pesquisa Mineral (CBPM) claimed the Mirabela and Palestina 
tenements in July 1989 to follow up on the work of Caraíba Metais SA. 

Two 1,000ha tenements (numbers 871.368/89 and 871.369/89) were claimed covering the 
Fazenda Mirabela intrusion, whilst three 1,000ha tenements (numbers 872.312/89 to 
872.314/89) were claimed covering the Fazenda Palestina intrusion. 

CBPM exploration was conducted initially under the auspices of the "Projeto Verificações 
Minerais no Estado da Bahia, Prospecto Fazenda Mirabela" (Cunha et al, 1998) and 
comprised: 

� Re-evaluation of the previous exploration work by Mineração Nhambu and Caraíba 
Metais SA. 

� Geological mapping at 1:5,000 scale, with analysis of Cu, Ni, Co, As, Ti, V, Cr, Pt 
and Pd in 39 rock samples and petrographic description for 135 rock samples.  This 
work led to the definition of the Fazenda Mirabela intrusion as a differentiated mafic-
ultramafic body comprised of a western, dominantly ultramafic, sequence 
(serpentinite/dunite, peridotite, pyroxenite and melano-gabbronorite), succeeded by 
an eastern mafic sequence (gabbronorite and leucogabbro), with the sulphide zone 
defined earlier by Caraíba Metais SA being located within the upper portion of the 
ultramafic sequence. 

� Detailed profiles of ground geophysics (magnetics and VLF-electromagnetics) were 
completed along five lines, and density and magnetic susceptibility measurements 
were compiled for the five diamond drillholes completed by Caraíba Metais SA.  This 
data permitted CBPM to subdivide the area into five magnetic domains, comprising 
from east to west: Domain A - country rock (paragneiss); Domain B - Fazenda 
Mirabela Intrusion gabbronorite and melanogabbronorite (eastern mafic sequence); 
Domain C - Fazenda Mirabela Intrusion pyroxenite (western ultramafic sequence); 
Domain D - Fazenda Mirabela Intrusion dunite, serpentinite and peridotite (western 
ultramafic sequence); Domain E - country rock (iron formation within paragneiss).  
The electromagnetic data did not reveal any significant conductors on the three 
surveyed lines. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 24 
Technical Report – May 2008 

� The sulphide mineralization was studied by Professor José Haroldo da Silva Sá of 
the UFBA. 

� All the above work concluded that the Fazenda Mirabela Intrusion was of tholeiitic 
magmatic affiliation and possessed potential to host economic mineralization of  
Ni-Cu, PGE and Au, or of Pt-Pd with Au, Ni and Cu associated, or even economic 
chromite concentrations.  The intrusion was regarded as a priority exploration target, 
with the principal zone represented by the transition between the peridotite and the 
pyroxenite within the western ultramafic sequence. 

An airborne magnetic and QuesTEM survey was flown in 1998, followed up by ground 
magnetic, electromagnetic and IP geophysics at the São Pedro and Grutinha Salobo 
targets, where a number of coincident magnetic-EM anomalies indicated the possible 
existence of massive sulphide targets. 

The second phase of exploration by CBPM commenced in 2000 and was conducted under 
the auspices of the "Projeto Avaliação de Ni-Cu-Platinóides na Faixa Ipiaú" (Moraes, 2001) 
and comprised: 

� Diamond drilling of the primary mineralization.  Five diamond drillholes totaling 
1,340.35m were completed by CBPM (FMIR-01 to FMIR-05), confirming the data 
previously obtained by Caraíba Metais SA (Fróes and Moraes, 2000), and a similar 
sulphide resource was outlined. 

� Auger and diamond drilling of the secondary (laterite) mineralization included 101 
auger holes (maximum depth of 14m), which indicated a potential lateritic resource.  
This was further defined by 36 diamond drillholes for 985.8m (Ferreira, Moraes and 
Fróes, 2000).  The nickeliferous laterite is developed above the ultramafic core and is 
vertically zoned from oxide/hydroxide to silicate. 

Academic Studies

CBPM supported an MSc study of the Mirabela intrusion under the supervision of Professor 
A.J. Naldrett at the University of Toronto (Fróes, 1993) and at the same time the Brazilian 
Geological Survey (CPRM) independently supported an MSc study of the Mirabela 
intrusion under the supervision of Professor M.G. da Silva at the University of Bahia 
(Abram, 1994). 

CBPM Tender

In 2003, fulfilling its role of stimulating mineral exploration, the CBPM offered private 
enterprise the opportunity to develop the nickel resources of the 'Mirabela Laterite and 
Sulphide Ni-Cu-PGE Target' via public tender number 005/2003 (Cunha et al, 2000). 

Mirabela Mineração do Brasil Limitada, the Brazilian subsidiary of MNL, was selected on 
the basis of the discovery bonus and royalty offered to CBPM.  Diamond drilling of the 
lateritic resource began in March 2004, and diamond drilling to investigate the area of 
sulphide mineralization known as Santa Rita began in September 2004. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 25 
Technical Report – May 2008 

6.3 Resource History 

Santa Rita Sulphide Deposit

On the basis of conformity with a mineralised tholeiitic intrusive model, Caraiba Metais SA 
estimated a resource for an hypothetical 40m thick layer of disseminated sulphides that 
was assumed to extend with a reasonable consistency between their five drillholes 
covering approximately 700m of strike of the current Santa Rita deposit, as containing 18Mt 
at 0.5% Ni, 0.2% Cu and <0.5g/t PGE yielding 90,000t of contained nickel and 36,000t of 
contained copper (Carvalho et al, 1981).  The historical resource generated by Caraiba 
Metais SA is not consistent with the NI 43-101 and is not considered reliable by the 
authors. 

The CBPM drilled five drillholes to test the primary sulphide potential of the Mirabela 
intrusion, three of which were located within the current Santa Rita deposit, with the 
intention of verifying the results obtained by Caraíba Metais SA.  According to Morães 
(2001), these holes confirmed both the thicknesses and Ni and Cu grades intersected by 
Caraíba Metais SA., reinforcing the stratigraphic nature and extent of the mineralization.  
Morães further noted a strong correlation between the PGE content and the amount of 
sulphides.  The CBPM did not calculate a new ore resource estimate. 

Serra Azul Deposit

A nickeliferous laterite resource was estimated by the CBPM in 2002 covering part of what 
is now known as the Serra Azul deposit at 54.7Mt at 0.78% Ni, representing some 428,713t 
of contained nickel.  This included an estimated 'measurable mining reserve' of laterite, 
smectite clay and saprolite mineralisation types of 21.7Mt at 1.16% Ni, representing some 
252,655t of contained nickel using a 0.7% Ni cutoff grade (CBPM, 2002). 

The stated CBPM historic resource is not consistent with the NI 43-101 and is not 
considered reliable by the authors. 

6.3.1 Production History 

No production has been recorded from any of the MNL properties. 

 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 26 
Technical Report – May 2008 

7 GEOLOGICAL SETTING 
7.1 Regional Geology 

According to Barbosa and Sabaté (2004), geological, geochronological and isotopic studies 
allow the identification of four important crustal segments in the basement of the São 
Francisco Craton in Bahia (Figure 7.1_1). 

 
Figure 7.1_1 

São Francisco Craton in Bahia 

 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 27 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The oldest portion is the Gavião block in the west-southwest comprised of granitic, 
granodioritic and migmatitic continental crust, including remnants of 3.4 Ga TTGs and 
associated Archean greenstone belts.  In the south-southwest, the Archaean Jequié block 
comprises granulitic migmatites with inclusions of supracrustal rocks, intruded by many 
charnockite plutons.  To the northeast, the Archean Serrinha block is composed of 
orthogneisses and migmatites, which form the basement for Paleoproterozoic greenstone 
belts.  The youngest segment exposed is the Archean-Paleoproterozoic Itabuna–Salvador–
Curaça belt, which extends from southeast Bahia along the Atlantic coast to Salvador, then 
northwards into northeast Bahia, separating the Gavião and Jequié blocks from the 
Serrinha block.  This segment is mainly composed of a low-K calc-alkaline plutonic suite, 
but also contains belts of intercalated metasediments and ocean floor/back-arc basin 
gabbro and basalt.  During the Paleoproterozoic Transamazonian Orogeny at about  
2.15-2.05 Ga, these four crustal segments collided, resulting in the formation of an 
important mountain belt.  Regional metamorphism, resulting from the crustal thickening 
associated with the collision, occurred at around 2.10-2.05 Ga (Barbosa et al, 2005). 

According to Barbosa et al (2003), the collision of the Jequié block and the Itabuna–
Salvador–Curaça belt was responsible for their tectonic superposition and granulitization of 
the southern part of the Itabuna-Salvador-Curaçá Belt.  Inspite of this, the "Ipiaú Band", a 
narrow belt of quartzo-feldspathic rocks and lesser granites positioned between the two 
blocks, preserves only amphibolite facies metamorphic conditions.  During the peak of the 
metamorphism leuco-charnockites (garnet-cordierite bearing lithologies considered to be of 
anatetic metasedimentary origin), as well as intermediate-Ti charnockites formed by partial 
melting of the enclosing rocks, were generated, the latter usually exhibiting typical oval 
structures. 

In the southern part of the Itabuna-Salvador-Curaça belt, the last transpression of the 
Paleoproterozoic deformation at ca 2.08-2.06 Ga is interpreted by Barbosa and Sabaté 
(2004) to have governed the emplacement of the Mirabela and Palestina mafic-ultramafic 
intrusions. 

7.2 Local Geology 

The Mirabela and Palestina mafic-ultramafic intrusions are located within the Itabuna–
Salvador–Curaça belt, close to its western margin with the Jequié block, and within 6km of 
the "Ipiaú Band" (Figure 7.2_1).  Both intrusions appear to occupy nuclei of anticlinal 
structures, which may have developed in response to the westward thrusting of the 
Itabuna-Salvador Curaça Belt over the Jequié block. 

The country rocks to the intrusions correspond to a supracrustal succession and 
orthogneisses, which have equilibrated at granulite facies.  The supracrustals are 
represented by quartzo-feldspathic and kinzigitic gneisses, meta-quartzites, 
metamorphosed silicate -and oxide-facies banded iron formations, horizons of fine grained 
meta-mafic volcanics, meta-gabbroic sills and lesser serpentinites,  The orthogneiss 
commonly represents deformed charnockite. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 28 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Barbosa (1986) defined three phases of deformation in the country rocks; the first produced 
reclined folds, the second isoclinal folds coaxial with the first, and the third generated open 
folds with vertical axial planes orthogonal to the first two phases, responsible for dome and 
basin-type fold interference patterns.  The first two fold phases resulted in east-west 
shortening, whilst the third produced north-south compression. 

 
Figure 7.2_1 

Simplified Geology of the SSE Bahia Granulite Region 

 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 29 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The Mirabela and Palestina intrusions are undeformed and partly re-equilibrated at 
granulite facies, displaying magmatic temperatures above 1,000°C and sub-solidus re-
equilibration at 850°C (Barbosa and Sapucaia, 1996), although igneous textures and 
mineral textures are recognised, suggesting late or post-tectonic emplacement.  The 
Mirabela body was dated by Silva et al (1996) using the Sm-Nd method at 2.2 Ga, but 
since the magma which produced the body underwent crustal contamination, this age must 
be considered as a maximum.  Given that the Mirabela body clearly postdates the ca 
2.1 Ga peak granulite facies conditions established in the country rocks, these authors 
conclude that an emplacement age of ca 2.0 Ga is more likely. 

The Fazenda Mirabela Intrusion represents one of at least two mafic-ultramafic layered 
bodies intruding along a major structural lineament that extends for over 100km, adjacent 
to the western margin of the Itabuna-Salvador-Curaça belt (the Aratuípe-Nova Canaã trend 
of Silva et al, 1992).  It is located 25km north-northeast of the Fazenda Palestina Intrusion 
which is interpreted to be possibly comagmatic. 

The intrusion is a layered body of originally tholeiitic composition, which has differentiated 
into ultramafic lithologies at the base, overlain by a gabbronoritic phase.  It has an ovoid 
exposed area about 4km long by 3km wide, with an area of approximately 7km2.  The 
current outcrop pattern is interpreted to result from the combined effects of its primary 
morphology and superimposed broad folding.  The intrusion shows no evidence of the 
penetrative deformation that has affected the enclosing rocks, although is has partly re-
equilibrated at granulite facies, and igneous textures are perfectly preserved.  For 
simplicity, the complex is described in terms of two zones, a western ultramafic zone and 
an eastern mafic zone, since the contact between the two zones is usually sharp. 

7.3 Property Geology 

7.3.1 Country Rocks 

The country rocks to the Fazenda Mirabela intrusion include a supracrustal succession and 
orthogneisses, which have equilibrated at granulite facies.  The orthogneisses represent 
deformed charnockite and enderbite.  The supracrustals are represented by quartzo-
feldspathic gneisses, horizons of fine-grained meta-mafic volcanics, meta-gabbronoritic 
sills, silicate-oxide facies banded iron formations, khondalites and rare serpentinites, which 
according to Barbosa and Sabaté (2004) represent intercalated metasediments and ocean 
floor/back-arc basin gabbros and basalts. 

Meta-Gabbronorites

These rocks have abundant calcic plagioclase (51-70%) and orthopyroxene (20-24%), as 
well as clinopyroxene (2-17%) and sulphide, disseminated and in lenses (0.5-3%), 
accompanied by opaque oxide (0.5%) and biotite (0.5-1%).  They represent 
metamorphosed relatively leucocratic norites (orthopyroxene-plagioclase cumulates), 
hypersthene gabbros and gabbronorites with disseminated sulphide. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 30 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Large aggregates of relatively coarse-grained feldspar without pyroxene or sulphide may 
occur locally, or finer-grained plagioclase in areas with pyroxene and sulphide.  The texture 
is granuloblastic with slightly irregular, partly sutured grain boundaries.  Plagioclase has 
refractive indices significantly higher than those of quartz, suggesting bytownite as the most 
likely composition.  Pyroxene is mostly evenly disseminated to 1mm in grainsize but can 
also occur in patches to 15mm long that may represent recrystallised phenocrysts.  There 
are also larger pyroxene grains, mostly orthopyroxene, to 3mm long with exsolution 
lamellae parallel to [100], suggesting high temperature igneous or metamorphic 
orthopyroxene, with most of the clinopyroxene in fine-grained aggregates with hornblende 
(0-7%).  Rare poikiloblastic orthopyroxene also occurs.  Patches and lenses of sulphide to 
7mm long may occur parallel to a weak biotite foliation and may constitute up to 10% 
locally.  The sulphides include pyrrhotite, chalcopyrite and rare pentlandite.  Rare biotite is 
present as well as very minor opaque material including ilmenite and magnetite.  Up to 8% 
magnetite occurs in samples of hypersthene gabbro adjacent to the western contact of the 
Mirabela intrusion. 

Restricted veiniform and massive Ni-Cu sulphide mineralization occurs within the meta-
gabbronorite unit in the footwall of the Fazenda Mirabela intrusion at both the northern and 
southern ends of the Santa Rita horizon.  Research is underway to define whether these 
sulphides represent mineralization remobilized from the intrusion, or a feeder conduit. 

Meta-Banded Iron Formation

The quartz-rich lithologies have various proportions of quartz, pyroxenes, opaque oxides, 
sulphides and mostly rare plagioclase, and appear to represent varieties of siliceous to 
ferruginous metasediments (chert) or banded iron formation.  They contain granuloblastic 
quartz (13-77%) as interlocking amoeboid or inequigranular grains to 4mm long (locally to 
8mm indicating exaggerated grain growth), as well as less abundant pyroxenes (10-47%) 
and opaque oxide (8-20%).  Most of the disseminated orthopyroxene is fine-grained, 
however in more pyroxene-rich areas rare larger pyroxene grains to 4mm in diameter occur 
as well as a plagioclase-rich micro-mosaic with minor quartz and opaque oxide.  Magnetite 
occurs both as disseminations and in amoeboid aggregates 5-10mm long, roughly parallel 
to the pyroxene banding, suggesting weak layering or banding, but this may be tectonic 
rather than inherited from the banded iron formation.  Minor exsolved spinel is seen in the 
magnetite, but no ilmenite.  Sulphide occurs as trace quantities, however may also locally 
form partly continuous patches up to 15% and is mostly fine-grained pyrrhotite or pyrite.  
Grains and small lenses of trace to 1% granular apatite are disseminated. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 31 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Khondalites

Khondalites are sillimanite, K-feldspar, garnet-rich carbonaceous metasediments and 
contain pyrrhotite as the main or only sulphide.  They are variously rich in quartz (20%-
28&), feldspars (17%-35%), sillimanite (12%-17%), pyrrhotite (12%-21%) and graphite (6%-
8%), with garnet (2%-10%) as irregular grains and minor smectite rimming sillimanite and 
sulphides.  The quartz occurs partly as lenses to 8mm long and partly as disseminated 
grains with pyrrhotite, graphite and biotite.  The feldspars are complex, with perthitic alkali 
feldspar that is partly mesoperthite and antiperthitic plagioclase that in some areas has 
exsolved K-spar with internal lamellae of exsolved plagioclase.  Minor myrmekite is also 
disseminated.  The sillimanite is coarse-grained and prismatic with bands and lenses of 
sillimanite from 0.4mm to 3mm wide with locally quite elongate crystals.  Pyrrhotite occurs 
as lenses to 10mm x 4mm, some of which contain irregular patches of microporous low-
temperature pyrite and rare chalcopyrite, and there is abundant coarse-grained graphite as 
well as garnet to 3mm long and 1mm wide.  Minor rutile or ilmenite, to 0.8mm in grainsize, 
is partly enclosed in garnet. 

7.3.2 Mirabela Intrusion 

The Fazenda Mirabela Intrusion is a Paleoproterozoic differentiated mafic-ultramafic body 
emplaced near the western margin of the Itabuna-Salvador-Curaça belt during the later 
stages of the 2.15-2.10 Ga Transamazonian Orogeny when this belt collided with, and was 
thrust-over, the Jequié Block. 

The intrusion was emplaced closely following peak granulite facies metamorphism into a 
sequence of charnockite, enderbite, gneisses, meta-norite, and banded iron formation that 
had been previously deformed. 

The intrusion is the result of cumulative fractionation of a liquid of tholeiitic basalt 
composition, generating a layered intrusion with a basal ultramafic zone, varying from 
dunite to harzburgite, to olivine orthopyroxenite, and finally to bronzitite, and an upper mafic 
zone of gabbronorite to augite norite.  This regular fractionation trend may indicate that the 
magmatic system was closed without replenishment by new magma pulses, however it is 
also possible that the dunite represents an early pulse that was succeeded by a second 
pulse.  Between the footwall country rock and the ultramafic zone there is a zone showing 
inverted fractionation which is interpreted by Latypov et al (2007b) as a primary magmatic 
basal margin reversal arising from a temperature gradient-driven flux of low melting point 
components from the hot magma towards the relatively cold cumulate floor. 

7.3.2.1 Structure 

The Fazenda Mirabela Intrusion represents one of at least two mafic-ultramafic layered 
bodies that have been intruded along a major structural lineament that extends for over 
100km adjacent to the western margin of the Itabuna-Salvador-Curaça belt (the Aratuípe-
Nova Canaã trend of Silva et al, 1992).  The intrusion is located 25km north-northeast of 
the Fazenda Palestina Intrusion, which is interpreted to be possibly comagmatic. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 32 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The Mirabela intrusion is a layered body of originally tholeiitic composition, which has 
differentiated into ultramafic lithologies at the base, overlain by a gabbronoritic phase.  It 
has an ovoid exposed area about 4km long by 3km wide, with a total area of about 7km2 

(Figure 7.3.2_1).  The current outcrop pattern is interpreted to result from the combined 
effects of its primary shape and superimposed broad folding.  The intrusion shows no 
evidence of the penetrative deformation that has affected the enclosing rocks, although it 
has partly re-equilibrated at granulite facies, and igneous textures are perfectly preserved.  
For simplicity, the complex is described in terms of two zones, a western ultramafic zone 
and an eastern mafic zone. 

 
Figure 7.3.2_1 

Mirabela Property Geology 

 
7.3.2.2 Composition 

The western ultramafic zone comprises a typical ultramafic cumulate sequence overlying a 
basal reversal.  A core of fine-grained dunite (serpentinite ~600m thick) is successively 
overlain by peridotite [harzburgite (50m thick) to olivine orthopyroxenite (25m thick)] and 
pyroxenite [bronzitite (50m thick)] units, whilst underneath the dunite the basal margin 
reversal comprises bronzitite (~130m thick) and augite norite (~90m thick).  This zone 
occupies about one-third of the total area of the intrusion on its western side, and is 
reflected by a topographic high.  The dunite core and a large part of the peridotite are 
completely serpentinized, with preservation of relic texture.  The peridotites become 
gradually richer in pyroxene and poorer in olivine outwards from the nucleus.  The overlying 
pyroxenite-rich units show minor alteration of their constituent minerals compared to the 
core.  The extent of the ultramafic zone is well defined by outcrop mapping and magnetics. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 33 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The mafic zone lies to the east of the ultramafic zone, is ellipsoidal in exposed shape, and 
occupies two-thirds of the surface area of the intrusion.  It defines the general shape of the 
Fazenda Mirabela Intrusion due to its almost perfect oval form and is estimated to be at 
least 1,000m thick.  Topographically, it represents an area of subdued, almost planar, relief 
and comprises coarse-grained gabbronorites, leuco-gabbronorites and augite norites of 
remarkably homogeneous character, only locally disrupted by late tectonic overprints.  
Compositionally, olivine is absent and plagioclase becomes the major mineral phase, 
together with ortho- and clino-pyroxene.  It does not have a magnetic signature. 

Dunites

The dunites are massive/granular olivine meso-orthocumulates with inequigranular olivine 
varying from 0.8mm to 7.0mm in crystal size, averaging 3.0mm, as the principal cumulus 
mineral (94%).  Localized areas of finer recrystallised olivine (<0.4mm in grainsize), also 
occur.  The olivine shows weak to intense serpentinization, especially in sheared examples, 
with serpentinites often completely pseudomorphing olivine cumulates.  Minor 
orthopyroxene (bronzitite 3%) is mostly interstitial as large optically continuous oikocrysts, 
some of which are >10mm in diameter.  Trace hornblende or biotite is fine-grained and 
granular, and may be metamorphic. 

Granular chromite (1%) occurs as rounded grains to 2mm in diameter, generally rimming 
the olivine, but lacks Fe3+-rich chromite or chrome-magnetite rims. 

Serpentine (± talc and/or carbonate) alteration typically occurs along micro-fractures in 
olivine and orthopyroxene.  Sparse, thin lenses of fine secondary magnetite occur in 
serpentine, but are much less abundant than is typical in most serpentinites. 

The dunites are usually poor in sulphides (<0.6%), which may occur as fine-grained, 
disseminated, interstitial phases and partly correlate with post-cumulus minerals. 

Peridotites

These rocks are composed of cumulus olivine and chromite with varying quantities of 
intercumulus bronzite, titano-augite and occasional plagioclase, and have compositions 
varying between harzburgite, lherzolite and wehrlite.  Meso and orthocumulate textures are 
present, although orthocumulate textures predominate.  These phases host 35% of the 
total mineral resource, in the intrusion, with highest nickel and copper grades, and 
anomalous PGEs, associated with primary post-cumulus sulphides. 

Harzburgites are massive and granular, with olivine (68%) and orthopyroxene (23%) 
crystals mostly <5mm in size, and olivine to orthopyroxene ratios of about 2.  Two types of 
harzburgite are present; olivine mesocumulates with orthopyroxene entirely, or largely, as 
oikocrysts, and partly layered harzburgites with bands and lamellae rich in olivine, and 
alternate bands rich in granular or prismatic cumulus orthopyroxene.  Some olivine bands 
have orthopyroxene as oikocrysts, but clinopyroxene (3%), hornblende (1%) and 
plagioclase (trace) occur as oikocrysts in other layers, with olivine or orthopyroxene as 
cumulus grains. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 34 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The harzburgites include minor, mostly granular chromite (1%), and accessory 
disseminated fine granular sulphide (1.5%).  Moderately abundant serpentine has mostly 
affected the olivine, whilst talc-filled microfractures and microshears are common locally.  
Carbonate is less abundant than in the dunites, however minimal secondary magnetite 
development is consistent with the dunites. 

Lherzolites vary from olivine cumulates to olivine (67%) – orthopyroxene (21%) cumulates, 
with orthopyroxene as a postcumulus mineral in the olivine cumulates, but as a cumulus 
mineral in the others.  Clinopyroxene (8%) and hornblende (2%) also occur as oikocrysts 
and are more abundant than in the dunites and most bronzitites.  Other lherzolites are 
partly layered, with both olivine and orthopyroxene-rich segregations.  Clinopyroxene and 
trace plagioclase (± trace phlogopite) occur as oikocrysts with orthopyroxene and 
hornblende rimming plagioclase. 

Pyroxenites

There are two types of pyroxenite; olivine-pyroxene cumulates (olivine orthopyroxenites 
and lesser olivine websterites) and pyroxene cumulates (bronzitites and lesser 
websterites).  The former are spatially associated with the peridotite unit (harzburgite and 
lherzolite), occurring both as a continuous layer above the peridotites and locally as a 
discontinuous layer between the serpentinized dunite and harzburgite.  The latter form a 
distinct, separate sub-unit at the top of the ultramafic zone.  Post-cumulate copper and 
nickel sulphides occur in quantities up to 2%.  Plagioclase-bearing pyroxenites (varying to 
melanogabbronorites) also occur locally at the top of the pyroxene cumulates.  These lie 
adjacent to the gabbronorites, but contrary to reports by earlier workers (Fróes, 1993; 
Abram, 1994; and Cunha et al, 1998), they do not comprise a continuous mappable unit. 

The composition of the olivine orthopyroxenite is 66% orthopyroxene (bronzite/enstatite), 
24% olivine/serpentine, 3% clinopyroxene (diposide/augite), 2% hornblende, 2% sulphide 
and 1% chrome spinel.  Orthopyroxene is euhedral, commonly showing exsolution lamellae 
of clinopyroxene, and varies from 0.4mm to 4.5mm in grain size.  Olivine occurs as 
subhedral crystals measuring 0.3mm to 0.56mm long, and cumulate crystals of olivine are 
often found within large plates of post-cumulus clinopyroxene.  Clinopyroxene is a post-
cumulus phase with grainsize varying from 2.0mm to 3mm.  It occupies grains interstices 
and also occurs as large plates poikilitically enclosing olivine, orthopyroxene and chrome 
spinel.  The olivine orthopyroxenite hosts 33% of the total mineral resource. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 35 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The composition of the bronzitite is 88% orthopyroxene (bronzite), 2% to 13% 
clinopyroxene, 0.5% to 2% plagioclase, 2% sulphide, 1% olivine, and 1% hornblende.  Ad, 
meso and orthocumulate textures are common, with orthopyroxene as the cumulate phase.  
Bronzitites are predominantly adcumulate, whilst websterites and melanogabbronorites are 
frequently orthocumulate.  Orthopyroxene may vary between enstatite, bronzite and 
hypersthene, displaying both granular and tabular forms ranging from 1.5mm to 3mm, and 
up to 10mm in heterogeneous rocks.  Clinopyroxene (diopside/augite) is the principal post-
cumulate mineral, with a grainsize varying from 2.0mm to 3.0mm.  It occurs in the 
interstices and also as large optically continuous oikocrysts enclosing orthopyroxene.  
Plagioclase is also a post-cumulus phase, occurring in larger concentrations in plagioclase-
bearing pyroxenites and melanogabbronorites.  The bronzitite hosts 20% of the total 
mineral resource. 

Previous workers (Fróes, 1993; Abram, 1994; and Cunha et al, 1998) documented the 
presence of a melanogabbronorite unit at the boundary of the ultramafic and mafic zones.  
This unit was suggested by Cunha et al (1998) to provide evidence that the ultramafic and 
mafic zones represent separate intrusive pulses, but intensive drilling by MNL has not 
validated this concept, confirming that the two zones represent differentiates of the one 
magma. 

Gabbronorites

The gabbronorites occupy the outer zone of the differentiated Fazenda Mirabela Intrusive.  
Mineralogically they vary between augite norites, hypersthene gabbros and their leucocratic 
variants (Purvis 2006d).  They possess a coarse, locally pegmatitic, intergranular gabbroic 
or mosaic texture, sometimes modified by brittle fracturing, and are composed of 40% to 
73% plagioclase with a grainsize of 1.5mm to 4.0mm, 19% to 23% orthopyroxene (bronzite 
to hypersthene, grainsize 2.0mm-3.0mm), and 3% to 24% clinopyroxene (diopside/augite, 
average grainsize of 0.5mm).  Accessory minerals include hornblende (0%-10%), traces of 
biotite and titanomagnetite, rare pyrite and apatite.  The borders and cleavages of the 
pyroxenes are locally altered to amphibole.  Local concentrations of plagioclase (up to 
90%) and minor quartz, confer an anorthositic composition to the rock, but these 
concentrations have no defined stratigraphic horizon. 

Plagioclase (labradorite) constitutes a cumulate phase, occurring both as well-developed 
laths and in small recrystallized grains.  According to Fróes (1993), the laths are distributed 
in a random to slightly oriented pattern, the latter reflecting the primary magmatic flow 
direction.  Orthopyroxene occurs both as large irregular to prismatic form, and also as small 
polygonal crystals displaying exosolution lamellae of clinopyroxene.  Clinopyroxene occurs 
as small polygonal crystals comprising agglomerates, together with polygonal plagioclase 
and orthopyroxene that fill the interstices of the larger plagioclase and orthopyroxene 
crystals. 

The low nickel and copper sulpide development, as well as PGE, demonstrate that these 
rocks are practically sterile. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 36 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Border Zone

Previous workers (Abram, 1994; and Cunha et al, 1998) also documented the presence of 
a border zone around the Fazenda Mirabela Intrusive, comprised of melanogabbronorite, 
interpreted to represent the chilled margin of the gabbronorite unit.  The samples defining 
this zone came exclusively from the western margin of the intrusion.  CBPM drillhole FMIR-
05 tested the western intrusive contact, demonstrating that the intrusion is in contact with 
meta-gabbronorites belonging to the country rock succession, and devoid of a chilled 
margin.  Given that the intrusion is interpreted to have intruded immediately post-peak 
metamorphism, with emplacement conditions estimated by Abram (1994) at 1,000°C to 
800°C and 5-10kbar, it seems unlikely that the difference in temperature of the host rocks 
and the intrusion would be sufficient to form a chilled margin. 

Recent exploration of the Peri Peri prospect, located at the north-eastern extremity of the 
Fazenda Mirabela Intrusive, has confirmed the existence of a border zone constituted of 
sulphide-bearing melanogabbronorite and plagioclase bronzitite, however this has a coarse 
to locally pegmatoidal texture, contrary to that expected of a classical chilled margin, but in 
line with other mafic-ultramafic intrusions according to Latypov et al (2007a). 

Dolerite Dykes

At least two sets of dolerite dykes crosscut the Fazenda Mirabela intrusion in an east-west 
orientation. 

A series undeformed and unmetamorphosed dolerite dykes outcrop at approximately 
8,431,100mN, where they separate the mineralization into the northern and central sectors.  
They are approximately 10m to 15m thick, dip steeply to the south, and are composed of 
58% to 60% plagioclase, 35% clinopyroxene, 5% titanomagnetite, accessory apatite and 
traces of clays, biotite and green hornblende.  Plagioclase laths and granular or subophitic 
clinopyroxene occur to 1.5mm in grainsize, as well as granular titanomagnetite and small 
parallel bundles of apatite needles to 0.3mm long.  Adjacent to these dykes the 
mineralization shows an increase in grade. 

Further south, at approximately 8,430,300mN, a second series of suspected dolerite  
dykes occur.  These dykes are strongly metamorphosed, being composed of a granoblastic 
to granuloblastic mafic lithology, with 55% plagioclase 33% clinopyroxene, 8% 
orthopyroxene, 4% opaque oxide, along with very minor hornblende and traces of biotite, 
apatite and quartz, mostly less than 0.8mm grainsize.  The suspected dolerite is totally 
recrystallised and has crosscutting clay-carbonate-filled fractures, some of which contain 
sulphide (pyrite?). 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 37 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Pegmatite Dykes

Pegmatite dykes are common, especially within the peridotite unit where they appear to 
have intruded sub-parallel to the unit itself.  According to Fróes (1993), they are composed 
of large euhedral crystals of plagioclase up to 3cm long in a matrix of fine grained polygonal 
plagioclase (oligoclase, total for both types is 66%), oriented phlogopite (30%) and chlorite.  
Relatively large crystals (up to 0.5mm) of euhedral zircon (1%) and apatite (trace) and 
masses of monazite (0.5%) also occur in the mica matrix.  Veinlets and impregnations of 
chalcopyrite and pyrite are dispersed throughout the mica. 

7.3.2.3 Age 

Samples from eight different lithologies within the Fazenda Mirabela Intrusion were 
collected by Silva et al (1996) for geochronological dating utilizing the Sm/Nd method.  
Cumulate ultramafic samples were readily distinguished from the gabbro samples, but both 
were interpreted as distinct pulses from the same magma chamber on the basis of their 
similar slopes on the 147Sm/144Nd vs 143Nd/144Nd diagram.  Samples of both the ultramafic 
and mafic material indicated a maximum age of 2.2 Ga, however evidence for crustal 
contamination was observed in various isotopic results, suggesting this age must be 
considered as a maximum.  Given that the Mirabela body clearly postdates the ca 2.1 Ga 
peak granulite facies conditions established in the country rocks, the authors conclude that 
an emplacement age of ca 2.0 Ga is more likely. 

7.3.3 Laterite Development 

A significant laterite profile has developed over the dunite-harzburgite core of the ultramafic 
unit and is absent or poorly developed over other lithologies.  The laterite profile is typically 
25m thick but reaches 60m in places and comprises saprolite at the base of oxidation up to 
limonite near the surface. 

 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 38 
Technical Report – May 2008 

8 DEPOSIT TYPES 
The Fazenda Mirabela Intrusion is a Paleoproterozoic age, late-tectonic to post tectonic 
body of tholeiitic filiation, with the Santa Rita ore body representing a zone of stratabound 
disseminated sulphides located near its ultramafic–mafic zone contact.  It has intruded into 
a Paleoproterozoic mobile belt containing successions of intercalated metasediments, and 
ocean floor or back-arc basin gabbros and basalts. 

8.1 Santa Rita Deposit 

According to conventional classification schemes of nickel sulphide deposits, the Santa 
Rita deposit is considered to be a differentiated mafic intrusion of tholeiitic affinity.  Most of 
such studied intrusions are related to orogenic activity; they are deformed, often contain 
cross-cutting igneous rock types and display metamorphic features.  The host intrusions 
consist of a series of cumulates ranging from olivine cumulates to gabbroic and quartz-
dioritic rocks with mafic rocks prevailing.  Layering is a prominent feature and rhythmic 
layering can be recognized in outcrops and drillholes.  Small intrusions do not contain cyclic 
units, but in larger intrusions several tens of cyclic units may be recognised. 

The Santa Rita deposit can be variably classified together with the Moxie and Rona 
Phanerozoic age intrusions and the Svecofennian Paleoproterozoic age intrusions as a 
Type IV deposit (Naldrett 1989, reclassified as Type NC-5 Orogenic in Naldrett 2004), a 
Type 7a deposit (Du Bray 1996, quoting Page 1986), or a Type 2A deposit (Hoatson et al, 
2006).  It also shares some features in common with Type 2B layered intrusion deposits 
(Hoatson et al, 2006). 

8.1.1 Deposit models 

Hoatson et al (2006) Type 2A deposits are characteristically small sized (2Mt to 8Mt) and 
are hosted by <3km thick intrusions within Archaean-Proterozoic rift zones or Proterozoic 
mobile belts, with basal accumulations of massive to semi-massive sulphides close to 
interpreted feeder conduit positions. 

The 2892 ±34 Ma Radio Hill intrusion, for example, is a small mafic-ultramafic body that 
contains the most significant known Ni-Cu-Co sulphide resource in the Western Australian 
Pilbara Craton, with a global nickel metal resource of 42,000 tonnes of nickel metal 
(2.8Mt @ 1.53%).  It is a moderately dipping sheet-like body covering a surface area of 
3.6km2, and comprises a 330m thick basal ultramafic cumulate zone that is overlain by a 
440m-thick sequence of olivine gabbro, in turn truncated by a 430m thick sequence of 
quartz gabbro (see Figure 8.1.1_1). 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 39 
Technical Report – May 2008 

 

Figure 8.1.1_1 
Northeast Cross-Section through the Mineralized Basal Contact and Interpreted Feeder Conduit  

Radio Hill Intrusion 

 
(from Hoatson et al, 2006, fig. 15) 

 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 40 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The poorly-exposed ultramafic zone is dominated by lherzolite, dunite, olivine websterite, 
clinopyroxenite and websterite.  The overlying gabbroic zone comprises a homogeneous 
mafic sequence of olivine gabbro and olivine gabbronorite, with the highest exposed 
stratigraphic level of the intrusion constituted by quartz-bearing gabbro and gabbronorite.  
Sulphides are largely hosted by thin gabbros and plagioclase-pyroxenite units that persist 
along the basal contact of the intrusion between the overlying ultramafic cumulates and the 
honfelsed metavolcanic country rocks.  Most mineralization occurs in structural depressions 
along the basal contact and in a feeder conduit.  Massive, disseminated and stringer vein 
pyrrhotite-chalcopyrite-pentlandite-magnetite ores form discrete lenses within the structural 
depressions and massive chalcopyrite ores enriched in Au, Ag, Cu, Pd, and Pt are 
prominent in the feeder conduit.  Ultramafic and mafic cumulates throughout the intrusion 
have sulphur contents up to 2,000ppm indicating that the Radio Hill body formed from 
magmas that were sulphur saturated. 

Hoatson et al (2006) Type 2B deposits are characterised by accumulations of stratabound 
disseminated sulphides located near ultramafic-gabbroic zone contacts of mafic intrusions, 
also located within Archaean-Proterozoic rift zones or Proterozoic mobile belts.  They are 
commonly PGE, rather than Ni-Cu deposits. 

According to these authors the 2,925 Ma Munni Munni intrusion in the West Pilbara Craton 
of Western Australia contains the largest resource of PGEs and a small nickel resource 
associated with a layered intrusion in Australia (24Mt @ 2.9g/t Pt + Pd + Au, 0.3% Cu, 
0,2% Ni: Helix Resources Ltd, 2004).  The intrusion is a 5.5km thick elongated body 
interpreted to be a slightly plunging asymmetric boat-like structure.  The lower 1.85km thick 
ultramafic zone comprises macrorhythmic cycles of olivine and olivine-clinopyroxene 
mesocumulates and adcumulates, and the overlying 3.6km thick gabbroic zone consists 
largely of intergarnular gabbronorite, magnetite gabbro, and garnophyric gabbro (see figure 
below).  The upper part of the ultramafic zone contains a distinctive 30m to 80m-thick 
orthocumulate layer refered to as the porphyritic websterite layer, which is host to 
persistent PGE mineralization associated with disseminated chalcopyrite, pentlandite and 
pyrrhotite (up to 2% volume) over its exposed 22km strike extent.  Hoatson and Keays 
(1989) proposed that the PGE mineralization resulted from the combined processes of 
crystal fractionation and mixing of sulphur-undersaturated PGE-bearing magnesian magma 
with more evolved sulphur-saturated tholeiitic mafic magma. 

The Santa Rita deposit contains elements of both models above.  It contains (minor) 
disseminated and semi-massive sulphide mineralisation within marginal plagioclase-
pyroxenite units between the overlying mafic-ultramafic cumulates and the hornfelsed 
country rocks at the Peri Peri prospect, however to date basal accumulations of massive to 
semi-massive sulphides close to interpreted feeder conduit positions that typify the Type 2A 
deposit have not been identified.  In common with Type 2B deposits the majority of the 
mineralization is hosted by an accumulation of stratabound disseminated sulphides located 
near the ultramafic-gabbroic zone contact, although this mineralization to date is Ni-Cu rich 
with only traces of PGE.  Consequently both models are being considered during ore 
targeting. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 41 
Technical Report – May 2008 

 

Figure 8.1.1_2 
West Cross-Section though the PGE-Enriched Porphyritic Websterite Layer and Associated Rocks  

at the Ultramafic-Gabbro Zone Contact of the Munni Munni Intrusion 

 
(from Hoatson et al, 2006, fig. 19) 

 
8.2 Serra Azul Deposit 

The Serra Azul deposit belongs to the oxide laterite type of nickel deposits.  Examples of 
these types of deposits include Koniambo in New Caledonia, Ravensthorpe and Murrin 
Murrin in Australia, and Moa Bay in Cuba. 

 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 42 
Technical Report – May 2008 

9 MINERALISATION 
9.1 Nickel Sulphide Mineralisation 

Disseminated nickel and copper sulphides form a stratiform body parallel to the 
lithostratigraphic contacts extending upwards from the harzburgite unit through the olivine 
orthopyroxenite unit and into the base of the bronzitite unit.  Sulphur saturation appears to 
have post-dated olivine precipitation, as the olivine is not nickel depleted.  This may explain 
why no sulphides have been discovered at the base of the intrusion to date, although it is 
also possible that the dunite unit and basal margin reversal represent a non-mineralized 
pulse that preceded the mineralized pulse. 

The mineralized zone extends from one side of the Fazenda Mirabela Intrusion to the other, 
averaging 35m in width over a 1.5km strike length, and has been tested down dip to depths 
exceeding 500m. 

The sulphide mineralization shows strong lithostratigraphic control, concentrated within the 
peridotite and upwards into the pyroxenite.  The mineralization has a primary disseminated 
nature, originating from accumulation of sulphide liquid within the cumulate silicate phase 
as post-cumulus sulphides, and comprises predominantly pentlandite (52%, with 7% 
violarite) intimately associated with chalcopyrite (14%), pyrite (14%) and pyrrhotite (9%).  
Traces of PGE are also intimately associated with the sulphides, either as a distinct mineral 
phase (not yet identified) or included within the structure of the principal sulphides. 

The mode of occurrence of the sulphides is as granular aggregates comprising pentlandite 
and/or violarite, chalcopyrite, pyrrhotite and various forms of pyrite.  Sulphides are 
commonly fine-grained, with individual samples often containing sulphide aggregates no 
more than 0.5mm to 1mm in size, however larger lenses to 30mm occur locally with 
sulphide aggregates.  Finer and more widely disseminated grains of sulphide seem to 
include more abundant chalcopyrite than relatively coarser scattered aggregates.  
Sulphides occurring as veinlets and fine filaments in micro-fractures, with or without 
serpentine, are mostly copper-rich (chalcopyrite), with or without pentlandite or violarite, 
and rarely include low-temperature secondary pyrite. 

Composite grains of nickel-rich sulphides are commonly equant or elongate, being up to 
1mm to 2mm in diameter or length, and interstitial to olivine and/or chromite. 

Minor sulphides include mackinawite, millerite, poorly defined low-temperature Fe 
sulphides, cubanite, bornite and chalcocite, along with trace native copper.  Millerite and 
more complex nickel-copper sulphides occur in some samples.  Low temperature pyrite is 
less abundant and is rarely colloform or lamellar in texture. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 43 
Technical Report – May 2008 

A detailed description of sulphide morphology according to lithology is as follows: 

� Serpentinite/Dunite - Sulphides (~0.1 vol.%) occur as relics (50-300μm), which are 
intensively replaced by magnetite and serpentine, and also as extremely fine-grained 
inclusions (<1-15μm), hosted by serpentine.  The major nickel mineral is pentlandite 
[(Fe,Ni)9S8] however traces of chalcopyrite and chalcocite (Cu2S) also occur as fine-
grained inclusions in olivine, and rare specimens with very low sulphur contents 
contain native copper.  Purvis (2006a) studied 49 dunite samples and obtained an 
average of 0.38% Ni (above a cutoff grade of 0.3%), but only 0.12% Ni was present 
as sulphide, meaning that the average dunite does not constitute potential mill feed. 

� Peridotite (Harzburgite) - Sulphides (mostly pentlandite and minor chalcopyrite) occur 
as blebs (30-400μm) intergrown with olivine relics and disseminated grains (5-60μm) 
in serpentine.  Chalcopyrite is also found to occur as veinlets (200 x 10μm) in 
serpentine.  The major nickel mineral is pentlandite [(Fe,Ni)9S8].  Other sulphides 
observed as trace constituents in harzburgite include pyrite and pyrrhotite.  
Pentlandite occurs as both relative simple intergrowths with chalcopyrite and as 
discrete mono-mineralic blebs.  Pentlandite is commonly traversed by serpentine and 
magnetite veinlets.  In addition, serpentine invariably forms continuous rims (up to 
10μm wide) along pentlandite grain boundaries.  Mackinawite [(Fe,Ni)1+XS] is 
invariably found within pentlandite grains, occurring as fine-grained veinlets replacing 
the host sulphide. 

� Peridotite (Olivine Orthopyroxenite) - Sulphides occur as bopth poly-mineral 
aggregates (0.1-1.5mm) at triple junctions of silicates and fine-grained disseminated 
particles (<1-100μm) enclosed by pyroxene.  The sulphide aggregates also show 
spatial association with Cr-spinel.  The major nickel mineral is pentlandite 
[(Fe,Ni)9S8], whereas violarite (FeNi2S4) is a rare phase occurring along pentlandite 
cleavage planes and fractures.  Pentlandite occurs as part of lobated sulphide blebs 
interstitial to pyroxene, being composed of pentlandite, chalcopyrite, pyrrhotite and 
pyrite.  While the sulphide intergrowths are typically simple, with regular grain 
boundaries, pyrite and pentlandite locally form complex textures.  Pentlandite is also 
found as typical "flames" (5-50μm) within pyrrhotite.  Moreover, fine-grained 
pentlandite blebs (<15μm) attached to pyrrhotite are also observed in pyroxene.  
Other sulphide minerals observed as trace constituents include bornite (Cu5FeS4), 
galena (PbS), mackinawite [(Fe, Ni)1+XS] and marcasite (FeS2). 

� Pyroxenite - Pentlandite occurs as part of lobated sulphide blebs interstitial to 
pyroxene, being composed of pentlandite, chalcopyrite and pyrite.  Pentlandite is 
also found as discrete grains (<100μm) included in pyroxene, while fine-grained 
pentlandite blebs (<15μm) intergrown with pyrrhotite also occur within pyroxene.  
Pyrite commonly forms a very complex intergrowth pattern with pentlandite.  Millerite 
is typically hosted by pentlandite and occurs as irregular, fine-grained aggregates (up 
to 120μm). 

The estimation of ore tenor is less reliable for samples with less than 2,000ppm sulphide 
nickel (especially oxidised samples and dunites), demonstrating a high variability compared 
to samples with >2,000ppm Ni.  The ore tenor values for samples with <2,000ppm sulphide 
nickel and those with more than 2,000ppm sulphide nickel are tabulated below after Purvis 
(2006c). 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 44 
Technical Report – May 2008 

 

Table 9.1_1

The bulk sulphide composition (tenor = grade recalculated to 100% sulphide) has been 
calculated to be ±18.9% Ni, 6.1% Cu, 36.2% Fe, 38.8% S in 2.57% by weight sulphide. 

Despite deliberate research by Fróes (1993), and during extensive MNL petrology, no 
discrete PGE mineral phase has been identified.  This is largely due to the average Pt+Pd 
content of the ore being only 105ppb, suggesting that the PGE may be contained within the 
structure of the principal sulphides. 

9.2 Primary Alteration 

The principal alteration exhibited by differentiates comprising the Fazenda Mirabela 
Intrusion is serpentinization.  During this process both the olivine and orthopyroxene are 
strongly altered along fractures and grain boundaries to a fibrous chrysotile, associated 
with blebs and dendritic exsolutions of secondary magnetite.  In olivine cumulates, coronas 
with an inner rim of orthopyroxene and an outer rim of clinopyroxene occur around olivine 
grains in contact with interstitial plagioclase (kelyphitic texture). 

In the dunite unit, usually none of the former grain structure is seen amid the serpentine 
mass, however towards the top of the unit quite unaltered olivine crystals are found.  
Orthopyroxene is also altered along cleavages to bastite, tremolite, talc and chlorite.  
Carbonate (± secondary mineral) veinlets also fill some fractures. 

Within the peridotite unit, olivine is also strongly altered along fractures, but the 
serpentinization rarely progresses through the whole mineral, as is the case within the 
dunite unit.  The orthopyroxenes suffer bastitization along cleavages and fracture-fill 
chrysotile, accompanied by powder-like magnetite and rutile, whilst clinopyroxene shows 
incipient amphibolitization, indicative of hydrothermal alteration or metamorphic re-
equilibration. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 45 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Within the pyroxenite unit, orthopyroxenes are slightly altered to tremolite along the grain 
boundaries when in contact with clinopyroxene, and to bastite along cleavages with 
liberation of powder-like magnetite giving the mineral a dusty appearance in thin section.  In 
common with the gabbronorite unit, plagioclase is strongly saussuritized. 

9.3 Laterite Mineralisation 

Nickel mineralisation at the Serra Azul deposit is well developed throughout the laterite 
profile (limonite, clay and saprolite), and overlies the dunite-harzburgite core of the 
ultramafic unit and is poorly developed or absent over other lithologies.  These olivine-rich 
lithologies (>40% olivine) are particularly susceptible to lateritic enrichment development 
since they contain the highest values of silicate nickel (>2.2% Ni) within the crystal lattice of 
the olivine. 

The clay/saprolite mineralization is hosted within the smectite with abundant garnierite 
identified. 

The thickness of the laterite profile is generally around 25 m but reaches 60 m.  The thicker 
sections of laterite correspond to the topographically highest parts of the hill, and thickness 
falls away to the north. 

 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 46 
Technical Report – May 2008 

10 EXPLORATION 
Prior to commencement of the MNL exploration programs (2004 onwards), exploration has 
been completed by operators Mineração Nhambú Limitada (1979-1981), Caraíba Metais 
S/A (1985-1989) and CBPM (1989-2002) (Section 6.2). 

The MNL strategy was initially designed to test the Ni laterite mineralisation identified at the 
Serra Azul deposit until focus shifted to the Santa Rita deposit and the nickel sulphide 
mineralisation.  Recent MNL programs focussed primarily on drilling the sulphide 
mineralisation to understand the geological controls, to collect metallurgical and 
geotechnical data, and to define a high confidence Mineral Resource.  This strategy has 
been successful, with the drilling confirming the continuity of the mineralisation and 
expanding the known extents of the deposit.  MNL considers it likely that on-going 
exploration will continue to identify extensions to existing mineralisation or new 
mineralisation elsewhere within the project. 

Exploration surveys and investigations completed to date within the Mirabela Project have 
been planned, executed and supervised by expatriate and national MNL personnel, 
supplemented by consultants and drilling and geophysical survey contractors.  The current 
MNL exploration team is considered well qualified and motivated to fulfil the responsibilities 
of on-going exploration programs. 

The geological understanding of the Mirabela Project has evolved greatly since the 
commencement of the MNL exploration strategy and will continue to do so with additional 
exploration.  The knowledge acquired to date confirms the considerable potential of the 
Mirabela Project. 

Coffey Mining considers that the exploration and development strategy is entirely 
appropriate. 

10.1 Peri Peri prospect 

Soil sampling along the contact of the gabbronorite and basement some 2km E of the 
Santa Rita sulphide horizon at the Peri-Peri target where the contact bends sharply 
southward revealed a highly anomalous soil geochemical response (1% Ni, 0.3% Cu, 
0.3% Cr, and 12% Fe) which was followed up by drillholes MBRC-070 (20m @ 0.62% Ni, 
0.14% Cu from surface) and MBRC-071 (4m @ 0.78% Ni, 0.13% Cu from 17m-21m 
downhole, and 7m @ 0.40% Ni, 0.12% Cu from 26m downhole). 

Following these initial results 37 diamond drillholes totalling 5,388.8mm have since been 
completed (MBS-300, 302, 307, 312, 317, 322, 325, 329, 335, 336, 338, 340, 341, 342, 
343, 346, 347, 380, 382, 384, 387, 389, 391, 394, 397, 399, 400, 401, 405, 407, 485, 490, 
492, 494, 495, 497, and 498) and a list of the significant intersections (i.e. 0.4% Ni cutoff 
grade; 4m minimum mining width) is given in Table 10.1_1 below.  Drillhole MBS-378 which 
tested the intrusive contact  ~500m west of Peri Peri was barren, while assays are pending 
for drillholes MBS-492, 494, and 495. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 47 
Technical Report – May 2008 

 

Table 10.1_1

At Peri Peri the bounding lithology of the Fazenda Mirabela Intrusion changes from the 
usual metric zone of melanogabbronorite, to a thick ultramafic sequence varying from 
orthopyroxenite (bronzitite) through feldspathic bronzitite to pegmatoidal feldspathic 
websterite ranging in width from <5m to a maximum of 70m, and this in turn is in contact 
with basement mafic granulite, felsic gneiss and felsic granofels.  Disseminated sulphide 
mineralization with a maximum width of 60m is hosted within a steeply dipping (~70°SSW) 
shoot which is primarily hosted by the ultramafic but locally transgresses the intrusive 
contact into the basement mafic granulite. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 48 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Drilling has intersected the shoot over 350m of strike length (local sections 9,700mN to 
10,050mN) and as deep as 150m below surface (refer Figure 10.1_1 and Figure 10.1_2 
below).  Local occurrences of matrix –stringer style mineralization with up to 30% sulphides 
are also commonly intersected within the basement footwall lithologies within 20m of the 
intrusive contact. 

 
Figure

Peri Peri Prospect 

 
According to Purvis (2007b) the ultramafic sequence comprises plagioclase and 
clinopyroxene-bearing orthopyroxene-rich cumulates and partly recrystallised pegmatoids 
belonging to the Fazenda Mirabela Intrusion.  The cumulates vary from bronzitite : bronzite 
(92%), hornblende (3%), clinopyroxene (2.5%) and plagioclase (2.5%), to feldspathic 
bronzitite : bronzite (69%), plagioclase (17%), clinopyroxene (6%), biotite (2%), hornblende 
(1%) and 5% sulphides, and finally to feldspathic websterite : bronzite (41%-56%), 
plagioclase (10.5%-17.5%), clinopyroxene (21%-23%), biotite (1%), hornblende (3.5%-5%) 
and 8-12% sulphides.  The percentages of clinopyroxene, plagioclase and sulphide 
increase towards the contact of the intrusion whilst deeper samples have very coarse-
grained orthopyroxene, to 25mm developing a pegmatoidal facies.  Locally there is 
extensive recrystallisation of clinopyroxene and plagioclase at the intrusive contact. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 49 
Technical Report – May 2008 

 

Figure 10.1_2 
Peri Peri Cross Section 

 
The sulphides within the ultramafic tend to be rich in nickel and poor in copper compared to 
sulphides from the Santa Rita ore body, but are texturally similar, varying from fine grained 
disseminations (<0.1mm) to irregular interstitial patches or lenses to 5mm in diameter.  The 
larger sulphide aggregates vary from pentlandite-rich to pyrrhotite-rich with pyrite 
> chalcopyrite in some aggregates and chalcopyrite > pyrite (or without pyrite) in other 
aggregates.  Pyrite is more common in small disseminated sulphide aggregates, usually 
with chalcopyrite and little or no pyrrhotite. 

The basement lithologies include granulite-facies metasediments, mafic granulite (ex meta-
gabbronorite) and felsic granofels (ex meta-tonalite) which suffered mylonitization prior to 
intrusion of the Fazenda Mirabela Intrusion.  Within 20m of the intrusive contact they host 
disseminated pyrrhotite, pyrite and chalcopyrite, pentlandite-rich lenses and veins, and 
veins of sulphide-hosted breccia (pyrrhotite > pyrite, pentlandite > chalcopyrite) with largely 
undeformed fragments composed of quartz, microcline and muscovite.  This assemblage of 
sulphides is similar to that seen in drillholes at the northern limit of the Santa Rita resource 
(Section 17). 

The economic significance of this shallow mineralization is being assessed. 

 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 50 
Technical Report – May 2008 

11 DRILLING 
11.1 Introduction

Diamond, Reverse Circulation (RC) and auger drilling has been completed at the Mirabela 
Project, as summarised in Table 11.1_1.  A subset of the total database, comprising all 
drillholes available at the time, was used for the resource estimation studies completed in 
March 2005 (Serra Azul – Table 17.3.1_1) and November 2007 (Santa Rita–
Table 17.2.1_1).  Neither the auger drilling nor the Santa Rita RC drilling was included in 
the resource estimates. 

 
Table 11.1_1
