Data collection can be subdivided into two distinct periods of exploration; prior to 2004 and 
2004 onwards.  The first period relates to data collected as part of Brazilian company 
CBPM exploration management.  The second period relates to data collected under work 
programs managed by MNL.  As such, further comments are directly attributed to each 
company. 

Data collection methods applied by MNL have been reviewed by Coffey Mining and, as 
such, have been directly assessed.  As exploration completed by CBPM was undertaken 
prior to Coffey Mining's involvement in the Mirabela Project, no detailed review has been 
undertaken although the vast majority of the data applied to resource evaluations has been 
collected by MNL.  The following sections are a summary of the MNL data drilling and 
collection approach. 

11.2 Diamond Core Drilling 

The diamond drilling was predominantly carried out by Boart Longyear Geoserv.  The rigs 
used were sled-mounted LM-38's and LM-44's, and were moved and placed into position 
using a tractor (Figure 11.2_1).  The number of rigs on site at any one time varied between 
one and six. 

One sled-mounted diamond drill-rig from GEOSOL (Geologia e Sondagens Ltda.) was also 
used on site from the 4th April, 2006 until the 8th September 2006. 

All holes were drilled with HQ pre-collars and completed with NQ core.  Drilling was 
completed in runs of 3m. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 51 
Technical Report – May 2008 

 

Figure 11.2_1 
Diamond Drill Rig and Tractor 

 
Care is taken aligning the drill-rig prior to drilling.  The drill-rig is aligned using a cord strung 
between 3 pickets.  These pickets and cord are placed using a compass and GPS.  The rig 
alignment (ie. the azimuth and dip) was re-confirmed using a compass prior to 
commencement of drilling. 

All holes have been downhole surveyed by either single-shot surveys or post-drilling via a 
north-seeking gyroscope, or, by both of these methods.  The single shot surveying was 
completed by Boart Longyear Geoserv and the gyroscope surveying was completed by 
Downhole Surveys DHS Pty Ltd from October to December 2005 (holes MBS-001 to  
MBS-101). 

Originally the single-shot surveys were taken at an initial downhole depth of 10m, then at a 
50m depth, and subsequently at 50m downhole intervals.  This was subsequently modified 
to one survey at 10m, and then a survey every 30m down the hole until the end.  From 
November 2005, a new strategy was implemented whereby if a hole deviated by more than 
4° in dip and / or azimuth from the initial survey, MNL reserved the right to request that the 
hole was re-drilled at no extra cost.  The gyroscope surveying has generally been 
completed inside the PVC casing post drilling, although a limited number of holes were 
surveyed inside the drill rods.  The gyroscope survey interval was 3m with surveys 
collected from the beginning of the hole until just above the end of the hole or to the end of 
the PVC casing.  Based on a review of the available survey information, the data is 
considered to be well established in 3D space. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 52 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Core structural orientations were routinely recorded to assist in determining the controls on 
mineralisation and in establishing a reliable geological model for resource estimation, as 
well as to provide additional geotechnical information to determine likely blast 
fragmentation and pit stability characteristics. 

The core was transferred from the trays and pieced together on a V-rail (angle iron) rack 
and the orientation line, determined from the crayon orientation mark recorded during 
drilling, was drawn along the entire length of the assembled core. 

 
Figure 11.2_2 

Measuring of Diamond Drill Core Recovery 

 
 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 53 
Technical Report – May 2008 

11.3 RC Drilling 

A program of RC drilling was completed at Santa Rita as sterilization of the surrounding 
area.  As such it has not been used in the Mineral Resource estimate presented in this 
report. 

Geosedna Perfurações Especiais S.A. were contracted to complete the drilling with a W750 
truck mounted rig with air capability of 900cfm/350psi used.  All drilling was completed with 
a 51/2 inch face hammer. 

For the inclined RC drilling, significant water ingress was noted resulting in poor quality 
samples, potential downhole contamination and variable recovery.  During the program the 
rig reached a maximum hole depth of 150m.. 

11.4 Auger Drilling 

On completion of the diamond drilling and resource estimation of the Serra Azul deposit, a 
short auger drilling program was undertaken.  15m deep holes were drilled on a 10m by 
10m grid over the two main areas of the deposit, where it was thought mining would 
commence.  After the first metre, which was sampled individually, the holes were sampled 
in 2m composites.  The three augers used were hand-held motorised augers, each one 
operated by 4 people.  The results from the auger program were not used in any resource 
estimation, although they generally concord with those from the diamond-drilling program. 

11.5 Drilling Orientation 

Drilling was undertaken normal to the plane of the principal mineralised orientation (where 
practical), however some geotechnical holes have been drilled down dip targeting specific 
structures critical for geotechnical analysis and understanding.   

The vast majority of downhole drilling intercepts represent true mineralisation width 
although in all cases the interpretation of the geology and mineralisation constraints has 
been completed in 3 dimensions and therefore directly considers the attitude of the 
mineralisation relative to the orientation of the drillholes.  The mineralisation is fully 
interpreted as discussed in Section 17.2.2. 

The dominant drill direction at Santa Rita is -60° towards 270° (UTM Grid Zone 24 south 
using Corrego Alegre datum). 

11.6 Drilling Results 

A summary of the more significant drilling results returned from the Santa Rita since the 
resource estimate cutoff date of 28 September 2007 is provided in Appendix 1.  These 
results are derived from diamond drillholes and are not considered material to the resource 
and have therefore been listed in the Appendix. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 54 
Technical Report – May 2008 

11.7 Drilling Quality – Drillhole Database Verification 

The systems and procedures used by MNL limits the possibility of errors occurring in the 
data.  To validate the database, MNL randomly-selected holes were audited against the 
original logs and assay reports.  A summary of the holes validated is given below: 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 55 
Technical Report – May 2008 

� MBS-28 and MBS-149 collars were checked against the DGPS pick ups.  No 
material errors were identified. 

� MBS-19, MBS-45, MBS-62 and MBS-184 assays were checked against original SIF 
reports for the laboratory.  No errors were identified. 

� MBS-25, MBS-77, MBS-78, MBS-79, MBS-80, MBS-81, MBS-82, MBS-83, MBS-84, 
MBS-86, MBS-87, MBS-88, MBS-89, MBS-90, MBS-91, MBS-92 & MBS-93 surveys 
were checked between Single Shot surveys (EZ-Shot ) against Gyro Survey (North-
Seeking).  The results of this comparison are located in Appendix 2. 

� MBS-55 and MBS-135 geology code were checked against original logs.  No errors 
were identified. 

� MBS-88 and MBS-161 density measurements were checked against original reports.  
No errors were identified. 

In addition, Coffey Mining independently selected a number of drillholes (35 holes 
representing 4,317 assay intervals) and compared the digital database against the hard 
copy data and laboratory assay certificates.  Based on this independent assessment, the 
quality of the data in the database was excellent with no material errors being identified at 
any stage of the validation process. 

11.8 Surveying 

11.8.1 Grid Control 

The grids used in the surveys mentioned above were initially established using a GPS.  
The grid-lines were opened with machetes to cut-back the grass and low bushes, and a 
marked stake placed at each of the survey points, as located with a GPS.  When the 
surveys were actually made by TopMin, each stake was moved slightly to be in the exact 
surveyed point. 

11.8.2 Drillhole Collars 

On completion each diamond drillhole was cased with PVC tubing, which was left 
protruding a metre or so from the collar.  The PVC was then cemented in place.  Each 
collar was marked with a cement block, upon which was placed an aluminium plaque with 
the hole details engraved on it.  The collar coordinates were initially obtained using a GPS.  
More recently the collars have been surveyed with a DGPS, and finally surveyed by 
TopMin and/or MNL surveyors. 

11.8.3 Downhole Surveying 

For each diamond hole, the drill-rig was aligned to a cord strung between 3 pickets.  These 
pickets and cord had previously been put in place on the drill pads using a compass and 
GPS.  Once the rig was ready to drill, the alignment of the rig (i.e. the azimuth and dip) was 
re-confirmed using a compass. 

The downhole direction and dip changes were monitored by either single-shot surveys or 
by post-drilling north-seeking gyroscope surveys, or, in various instances, by both these 
methods. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 56 
Technical Report – May 2008 

11.8.3.1 Single Shot Survey 

� Single-shot surveys were completed by Boart Longyear Geoserv using a Reflex EZ-
Shot tool. 

� The surveys were taken at a depth of 10m (downhole), again at 50m deep and then 
every 50m down the hole until the end.  This has since been modified to one survey 
at 10m, and then a survey every 30m down the hole until the end. 

� From November 2005, it was implemented that if a hole deviated by more than four 
degrees in dip and / or four degrees in azimuth from the initial survey, MNL reserved 
the right to request that the hole was re-drilled, at no extra cost.   

11.8.3.2 Gyro Survey 

� From October to December 2005, Downhole Surveys DHS Pty Ltd. used a  
north-seeking gyroscope to carry out downhole surveys of all drillholes to date 
(i.e. MBS-001 to MBS-101). 

� The holes were generally surveyed inside the PVC casing after they had been 
drilled, although some of the later holes of the list above were surveyed inside the 
drill rods immediately after completion of the hole. 

� The holes were surveyed every 3m (downhole) from the very beginning of the hole 
until just above the end of the hole (or in cases where the PVC casing didn't reach 
the end of the hole, until the end of the PVC casing). 

� The downhole surveys were processed by a technician from Downhole Surveys, and 
passed onto the MNL in digital format. 

11.8.4 Surface Topography 

The surface topography of the immediate region of the Santa Rita deposit was surveyed in 
two stages.  In August 2004, an area containing the Santa Rita ridge and the adjacent 
Mirabela hill (i.e. 8,429,950mN to 8,431,900mN and 421,500mE to 422,900mN; UTM 24S, 
Corrego Alegre datum) was surveyed by TopMin (Topografia e Mineração Ltda.) on a 
100m (north-south) by 50m (east-west) grid.  In June 2005, TopMin returned to site and 
closed the grid spacing to 20m (north-south) by 10m (east-west) in the northern part of 
Santa Rita ridge (i.e. 8,430,600mN to 8,431,700mN and 422,200mE to 422,500mN; UTM 
24S, Corrego Alegre). 

Since 2005, no detailed topographic surveying has been conducted over the Santa Rita 
resource with the exception of drillhole collar pickups.  Some topographic surveying has 
been completed on areas surrounding Santa Rita hill. 

 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 57 
Technical Report – May 2008 

12 SAMPLING METHOD AND APPROACH 
12.1 Soil Sampling 

Multiple phases of surface geochemistry have been executed by the operators of the 
property.  The geochemistry includes soil samples, rock chip samples and auger samples.  
A summary of the programs completed is provided below. 

Mineração Caraíba S/A (1985-1989)

A programme comprising 480 shallow bulk soil samples were taken from the B horizon.  
These data were collected based on a regular 100m by 40m grid.  The analytical method is 
unknown but the samples were analysed for Ni, Cr, Co, Cu, Pb and Zn, with selected 
samples also analysed for Ag, Pt and Pd. 

CBPM (1989-2002)

CBPM collected 1087 bulk soil samples (including 49 duplicates) on a regular 200m by 
50m grid.  Of the total program, 977 samples were collected from the B horizon at a depth 
of approximately 50cm, and 110 samples originated from the deeper C horizon.  The 
C horizon samples and were collected by hand auger infilling the existing grid locally to 
100m by 25m spacing. 

All samples were analysed by Lakefield Geosol Limitada for the following sample suite: 

� Au (detection limit=1ppb) by atomic absorption, and Pt (detection limit=10ppb) and 
Pd (detection limit=1ppb) by optical emission spectrometry following an Aqua Regia 
digest. 

� Ag, Al, As, Ba, Bi, Ca, Cd, Co, Cr, Cu, Fe, K, La, Li, Mg, Mn, Mo, Na, Ni, P, Pb, Sb, 
Sr, Ti, V, Sn, W, Y, Zn, and Zr by ICP following an Aqua Regia digest. 

Mirabela Nickel Limited (2004-2006)

MNL extended the geochemistry coverage by completing 12 additional lines of sampling 
(100m by 20m sampling).  This infill sampling has been completed at the northern and 
southern ends of the main ultramafic part of the Mirabela Intrusion (i.e. to the immediate 
north and south of the area covering the Santa Rita sulphide and Serra Azul saprolite 
deposits). 

The MNL sampling consisted of 155 bulk soil samples collected in most cases using augers 
from an average depth of 2.15m (maximum depth of 14m). 

All samples were analysed by ALS CHEMEX using the ICP41, PGM-ICP23 and OG62 
analytical techniques.  Sample preparation (PREP-41) included the weighing and drying of 
samples prior to dry-sieving the sample to -180 micron (80mesh). 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 58 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Al, As, B, Ba, Be, Bi, Ca%, Cd, Co, Cr, Cu, Fe%, Ga, Hg, K%, La, Li, Mg%, Mn, Mo, Na%, 
Ni, Ni%, P, Pb, S%, Sb, Sc, Sr, Ti%, Tl, U, V, W and Zn were analysed by ICP-AES 
following an Aqua Regia digest.  Au (detection limit=5ppb), Pt (detection limit=1ppb), Pd 
(detection limit=1ppb) have been assayed by fire assay using an ICP-AES finish, Ag 
(detection limit=0.2ppm) 

12.2 Diamond Core Sampling 

The zones of each hole sampled were selected at the discretion of the geologist completing 
the geological logging. 

The drill core was logged in detail and intervals for sampling selected and an appropriate 
sampling form completed.  The core was then cut evenly down the middle using a diamond 
saw, slightly to the left of the orientation lines (or metre-marks where no orientation line 
exists).  The two halves of each piece of core were placed back in the core tray in the 
original position. 

The drill core was sampled in 1m intervals by trained and supervised technicians.  Each 
metre was sampled by taking the left-hand half of each piece of core for that metre 
(i.e. leaving the half with the orientation line and / or metre marks in the tray) and placing 
them into the appropriate sample bag. 

Calico sample bags with draw-strings have been used for core sampling.  Sample tickets 
were also used in the sampling process with one half (identical halves) of each ticket, which 
have a printed sequence of sample numbers (six figures), placed in the calico sampling 
bag.  The technician completing the sampling annotated the hole number and the sample 
interval on the remaining sampling ticket.  As part of the quality control protocols, the 
technician verified that the metre interval marked on the core matched the metre interval 
written on the sample ticket, and also matched the metre interval on the sample form.  The 
technician also verified that the corresponding sample number on the sample form, for that 
interval, matched the sample number of the sample ticket, and also matched the sample 
number written on the sample bag. 

Once the entire metre had been sampled and placed in the calico bag, along with the 
sample ticket, the bag was closed with the draw-string and tied firmly.  Crushed quartz 
supplied by the laboratory was put into sample bags and used as "blank" samples.  The 
blank samples were inserted into the sample sequence at the start of each hole, as well as 
every sample number ending in 50 or 00 (i.e. every 50 samples). 

Four certified standards have also regularly been inserted into the sample sequence as 
part of the quality control protocols.  These samples were inserted on a rotating basis 
(i.e. Standard 1, then Standard 2, then Standard 3, then Standard 1 again, etc.) for every 
sample number ending in 20 and 70 (i.e. every 50 samples).  Standard 1 is no longer used 
and was replaced by Standard 4 in late September 2007. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 59 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Samples for each hole have been placed into large plastic bags, with approximately 
12 samples per bag.  The bags were then numbered and labelled with the enclosed sample 
numbers and then taped closed. 

In batches of approximately 1,000 samples, the large plastic bags of samples were loaded 
onto a truck and sent to the laboratory for preparation and subsequent analyses, along with 
a dispatch sheet. 

In addition to the routine assaying completed, thin sections have been collected in zones of 
anomalous Ni mineralisation for petrological studies.  These thin sections have been 
collected at approximately 10m downhole interval.  Thin section sampling has been 
completed for all drillholes up to and including MBS-107.  The samples, generally 
representing 5 to 10cm billets of quarter core, were then put in a protective bag, and sent to 
Amdel Laboratories Ltd. in Adelaide, South Australia.  After quarantine, the samples were 
transferred to Pontifex & Associates Pty Ltd. for detailed and specific petrographic work of 
polished thin-sections. 

12.3 RC Sampling and Logging 

RC drill chips were collected as 1m intervals downhole via a cyclone into PVC bags prior to 
splitting. 

The collected samples were riffle split using multiple passes through a single stage riffle 
splitter.  A final sample of approximately 2kg was collected for submission to the laboratory 
for analysis.  In drillholes of interest, the final samples were of 1m intervals, however for the 
majority of the sterilisation programme the samples were 4m composites.  The sampling 
represents industry standard practices.  In wet holes, the samples were left to dry as best 
possible, and then homogenized and quartered by hand. 

RC chip trays were systematically logged by collecting the sieved RC chips and storing 
them in a tray, with each labelled compartment of the tray containing the chips from one 
metre.  RC sampling has not been reviewed by Coffey Mining. 

12.4 Diamond Logging 

Every diamond drillhole completed was logged in a geological, structural and geotechnical 
sense.  The lithological, stratigraphical and structural information gathered from these logs 
was then used, along with assay data and other information, to create a geological 
interpretation and model.  

12.4.1 Geological Logging 

Geological logging is carried out to gather information of the sample interval and is used 
along with assay data to assist with the geological interpretation.  



 

MirabelaProject Page: 60 
Technical Report – May 2008 

� Brief logs of each hole were completed as the hole was drilled, in order to monitor the 
hole's progress in terms of mineralisation targets and stratigraphic units. 

� Later each hole was logged in detail.  The major features that were logged were: 

� Rock type . 

� Colour. 

� Dominant primary mineralogy and estimated percentages. 

� Alteration mineralogy, style and estimated percentages. 

� Overall rock texture and / or structure (e.g. fractured, veins, etc). 

� Estimated percentage of magnetite. 

� Sulphide mineralogy and estimated percentages. 

� The major features listed above were recorded as an 8-figure geological "code".  This 
was intended to facilitate the logging process and also help with modelling and 
interpretation. 

� Each hole was divided into geological intervals, based on the features above.  The 
contacts of these logged intervals were marked on the core in black to be visible in 
the core photographs. 

� The main stratigraphic units of the deposit were determined from historic work, field 
mapping, and the early drillholes.  Once determined, these were also noted in the 
geological logs.  

� A comments section was included to allow for any information that wasn't sufficiently 
explained by the 8-figure code. 

12.4.2 Structural Data 

Major structural features observed in the drill-core were recorded for both orientated and 
un-orientated core.  These features included veins, faults, folds, cleavage, foliation, 
brecciation and major jointing.  

For each structure logged the downhole depth, thickness (if relevant), and the angle the 
feature made with the core axis (i.e. the alpha angle – see explanation below) were 
recorded.  Infill material and sense of movement data were also collected for faults.  Any 
additional data were recorded as comments. 

In addition to the above, where the core was orientated, the beta angle was measured for 
that particular structure.  

Note: The alpha angle is the acute angle between the core axis and the plane being 
measured (Figure 12.4.2_1).  The alpha angle can be measured using a protractor.  The 
beta angle refers to the angle between a reference line (e.g. the orientation line) and the 
lowermost apical trace of the ellipse.  The ellipse refers to the elliptical cross-section that a 
planar structure makes with the cylindrical core.  This is measured in a clockwise direction 
looking in the 'downhole' direction using a ring protractor. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 61 
Technical Report – May 2008 

 
 

Figure 12.4.2_1 
Structural Logging of Diamond Core 

 

 
(adapted from BHPBilliton, WINS-PLN-RGD-008) 

 
12.4.3 Geotechnical Data (Internal) 

The following geotechnical data were recorded for each drilling run (i.e. core-block to core-
block; typically 3m) for each drillhole: 

� Core recovery – the percentage of the length of core recovered of the total length of 
the run. 

� Rock Quality Designation (RQD) – this is an index of the rock quality, and is a 
percentage of the cumulative length of core pieces greater than 10cm long (standard 
for NQ) of the total length of the run.  Note that a "piece" of core is a length of core 
between two natural breaks, rather than using breaks in the core that resulted from 
drilling or subsequent handling. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 62 
Technical Report – May 2008 

� The longest length of core per run – again a length is determined to be between two 
natural breaks in the core. 

� Breaks per metre – the number of natural breaks were counted for each drill run, and 
then divided by the length of the run to give an average breaks per metre for the 
whole run. 

The above data were logged for all diamond drillholes until February 2006 (i.e. MBS-114).  
At this time a geotechnical consultant firm, Dempers & Seymour Pty Ltd., were engaged to 
create a geotechnical interpretation and model for the deposit, and thus took responsibility 
of any geotechnical logging.  More recently, this responsibility has been handed over to 
Brazilian consultancy VOGBR.  MNL continued to record the core recovery per run for each 
drillhole. 

12.4.4 Magnetic Susceptibility 

Until November 2005, the magnetic susceptibility of each logged interval of each drillhole 
was measured simply with a free-swinging pen magnetic, and recorded as a relative 
reading (ie. non-magnetic, weakly-, moderately- or strongly magnetic). 

In November 2005 MNL purchased a Kappameter.  Since then the magnetic susceptibilty 
was logged for every metre of core, and recorded in standard units (ie. SI x 10-3). 

The magnetic susceptibility readings were taken from whole core. 

12.4.5 Rock Density Measurement 

In order to determine rock density (i.e. apparent rock density), pieces of core at least 10cm 
long were selected at roughly 10m intervals throughout every drillhole.  The following 
summarises the bulk density determination approach: 

� Whole 10cm core billets selected for measuring, although for some of the early holes 
the pieces were half-core.  Each piece of core was weighed in air; that is, each piece 
was weighed dry on top of a balance. 

� Immediately after weighing in air, each piece of core was then weighed in water.  
This involved hanging a cradle from the balance and submerging it into a bucket of 
water.  The balance was then zeroed, the core placed on the submerged cradle and 
the weight recorded. 

� The balance used was an electronic balance accurate to 1gm (maximum weight of 
3kg).  The balance was tested and calibrated before each drillhole, and regularly 
throughout each drillhole, with a 500g standard weight. 

� The readings were all taken in a closed room under normal conditions. 

� From the two readings, the (apparent) rock density was calculated according to the 
following: 

Apparent density = weightair / (weightair – weightwater)



 

MirabelaProject Page: 63 
Technical Report – May 2008 

To account for lower rock densities in the oxide and supergene profiles, a program of wax 
coated testwork is in progress. 

12.5 Sample Quality 

The sampling procedures adopted for diamond drilling are consistent with current industry 
best practise.  In addition, all technicians appear well trained and are effectively supervised 
by MNL expatriate staff. 

Coffey Mining has not assessed the RC drill quality however the approach is also 
consistent with current industry best practise, except for wet drilling.  Coffey Mining 
considers that wet RC drilling is inappropriate and drillholes should be stopped when 
significant water ingress occurs.  The RC drilling has not been used to generate the Mineral 
Resource reported in this report. 

The mostly 1m sampling is consistent with broad disseminated mineralisation styles 
identified at the Mirabela Project.  The presence of scissor drillholes (drilled an approximate 
180º different azimuth), plus the collection of a substantial structural and geochemical 
database, has confirmed the validity of the drilling orientation and the geological 
interpretation (as described in Sections 8, 9 and 17).   

All relevant sampling has been included in the grade estimation studies described in this 
document and therefore will not be discussed separately.  Appendix 1 lists significant 
intercepts for drilling completed post the resource estimation study database close off date.  
These intercepts are not considered material to the resource.  All material drilling has been 
included in the resource and the assay data has been interpreted in 3 dimensions, as 
discussed in detail in Section 17.2.2.  

Bulk density determinations for the sulphide samples have been conducted in accordance 
with industry standard procedures.  The collection of a suite of transitional and oxide 
samples for tested using a method that includes oven drying of the core billet, sealing of the 
core with Paraffin Wax prior to standard immersion method density determinations is 
considered appropriate.  A limited number of tests on the sulphide material should also be 
routinely completed. 

 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 64 
Technical Report – May 2008 

13 SAMPLE PREPARATION, ANALYSIS AND SECURITY 
13.1 Sample Security 

The rapid submission of samples from drilling for analysis, and the close scrutiny of 
procedures by expatriate technical staff, provides little opportunity for sample tampering.  
Equally, given the umpire assaying via an external international laboratory and the regular 
'blind' submission of international standards to both the primary and umpire assay facilities, 
any misleading analytical data would be readily recognised and investigated. 

Current MNL drilling procedures require samples to be taped closed once taken from the 
core sampling facility.  Samples are then transported directly to the laboratory. 

Reference material is retained and stored on site, including half-core and photographs 
generated by diamond drilling, and duplicate pulps and residues of all submitted samples.  
All pulps are stored at ALS Chemex's storage facility in Belo Horizonte. 

13.2 Analytical Laboratories 

ALS Chemex Ltd, has been used as the principal analytical laboratory company.  The 
sample preparation has been completed in Brazil and the analytical laboratories in Perth, 
Australia, and Vancouver, Canada, assayed the pulps.   

The ALS Chemex laboratories in Perth and Vancouver are ISO 9001:2000 accredited.  In 
addition, the ALS Chemex Vancouver laboratory is accredited to ISO 17025 by Standards 
Council of Canada for a number of specific test procedures including fire assay Au by AA, 
ICP and gravimetric finish, multi-element ICP and AA Assays for Ag, Cu, Pb, and Zn. 

Umpire assay checks were also completed by ACME Analytical Laboratory Ltd in 
Vancouver, Canada, and Ultra Trace Analytical Laboratories, in Perth, Australia. 

For the Serra Azul deposit, samples from the CBPM holes were submitted to Lakefield 
Geosol Ltda in Belo Horizonte, Brazil.  Multi element assaying was completed for Au (aqua 
regia/AAS), Pt and Pd (ICP-OES), Ni, Cu, Co, MgO, Cr2O3, Fe2O3, MnO, Al2O3, SiO2, CaO 
(all by XRF).  Loss on ignition (LOI) was also determined. 

13.3 Sample Preparation and Analytical Procedure 

The majority of the sample preparation and analysis has been completed by ALS Chemex 
Ltd.  The sample preparation was completed at ALS Chemex sample preparation facility in 
Luziania, Brazil until February 2006, at which time it moved to Belo Horizonte, also in 
Brazil.  Coffey Mining reviewed the Luziania facility and considered it to be well organised 
and run with the technical staff well trained.  The sample preparation flowsheet applied to 
the ALS Chemex assaying is provided below as Figure 13.3_1. 

The samples pulps were then sent to an ALS Chemex analytical laboratory for analyses.  
Most of the samples were analysed by ALS Chemex in Vancouver, Canada, but the early 
drilling and some of the later drilling, due to turnaround time issues, where analysed by 
ALS Chemex in Perth, Australia.  A lesser amount of the assaying has been completed by 
Lakefield Geosol Ltda in Belo Horizonte, Brazil.   



 

MirabelaProject Page: 65 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The chain of custody, and adequacy of these procedures, is discussed further in Section 
13.4. 

The majority of the Ni assaying has been completed using inductively coupled plasma 
atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) while inductively coupled plasma mass 
spectroscopy (ICP-MS) methods with appropriate collectors, for example 30g fire assay for 
gold and nickel sulphide collection for PGE's have also been applied. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 66 
Technical Report – May 2008 

 

Figure 13.3_1 
Flow Diagram of ALS – Chemex Sample Preparation Laboratory 

 
 

 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 67 
Technical Report – May 2008 

A brief summary of the analytical methods used by ALS - Chemex is provided below: 

� PGM-MS23 -  Pt, Pd, Au package using 30 g lead fire assay with ICP-MS finish. 

� ME-ICP41 - 34 elements by aqua-regia acid digestion and ICP-AES. 

� ME-ICP61 - 27 elements by HF-HNO3-HClO4 acid digestion, HCl leach and ICP-AES. 

� ME-ICP93 - Nickel laterite analysis by lithium meta/tetra borate fusion.  ICPAES 
determination. 

� Cu-OG62 - Anomalous grade Cu by HF-HNO3-HClO4 Digest, HCl leach for use as 
Over-range with ICP-AES though AAS can be substituted. 

� ME-OG62 - Anomalous Grade Elements by Four Acid Digestion and ICP-AES 
though AAS can be substituted. 

� Ni-OG62 - Anomalous grade Ni by HF-HNO3-HClO4 Digest, HCl leach for use as 
Over-range with ICP-AES though AAS can be substituted. 

� PGM-ICP27 - Anomalous grade Pt, Pd and Au by fire assay and ICP-AES, 30g 
nominal sample weight, duplicate analysis. 

� PGM-MS27 - Anomalous grade Pt, Pd and Au by fire assay and ICP-MS, 30g 
nominal sample weight. 

No detailed description of the other elements assayed is provided in this report, although a 
full multi-element assay suite has been completed in all cases.  This includes the assaying 
of S, Fe and Mg. 

13.4 Adequacy of Procedures 

The adoption of the analytical methods, including ICP-AES for Ni, is entirely appropriate.  
Sufficient quality control data exists to allow thorough review of the analytical performance 
of assay laboratories. 

The sampling methods, chain of custody procedures, sample preparation procedures and 
analytical techniques are all considered appropriate and are compatible with accepted 
industry standards.   

As described in Section 12, the sampling and dispatched of samples is completed and 
managed by MNL staff.  Sample preparation and assaying is completed independent of 
MNL by ALS Chemex.    

13.5 Analysis for Non-Sulphide Ni 

Analysis for non-sulphide Ni was attempted in May 2005 to determine the sulphide Ni 
portion of the total Ni assay result. 

A total of 12 pulp samples were submitted from drillhole MBS-031 from Santa Rita to ALS 
Chemex Ltd and Genalysis Laboratory Services Pty Ltd, both laboratories located in Perth, 
Western Australia.  The samples were analysed by the following techniques: 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 68 
Technical Report – May 2008 

� ALS Chemex: TOTAL Ni–OG62 - L- Abcorbic Acid Method 
1. Weigh 1 gram sample into 400ml beaker 
2. Spread sample evenly over floor of beaker 
3. Add 20mls of 5% WV, L-ascorbic acid 
4. Gentle mix, cover with watch glass 
5. Leave for 24 hours 
6. Filter residue (centrifuge) 
7. Analyse liquor for Ni by AAS 

� Genalysis: PA2/OES 
Hydrogen Peroxide, Ascorbic Acid digestion with ICP OES finish 
specific for sulphitic Ni. 

Results are summarised in the Table 13.5_1 and the graphs of Figure 13.5_1 below.

The chart above shows all samples taken from the peridotite rock type (a combination of 
Harzburgite and Olivine Orthopyroxenite).  It suggests that for 0% sulphur, the typical 
background silicate Ni value will fall between 0.05% to 0.3% Ni, averaging approximately 
0.17% Ni.  This suggests that the ALS Chemex method is under-estimating the silicate Ni 
levels and that the Genalysis method may be more effective in estimating the silicate Ni, 
but it appears to be unreliable. 

A larger dataset may provide a more reliable result for determining the silicate vs. sulphide 
Ni levels. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 70 
Technical Report – May 2008 

14 DATA VERIFICATION 
14.1 Method

The quality control data of drilling used in the resource estimation has been assessed 
statistically using a number of comparative analyses for each dataset.  The objectives of 
these analyses were to determine relative precision and accuracy levels between various 
sets of assay pairs and the quantum of relative error.  The results of the statistical analyses 
are presented as summary plots, which include the following: 

� Thompson and Howarth Plot, showing the mean relative percentage error of grouped 
assay pairs across the entire grade range, used to visualise precision levels by 
comparing against given control lines. 

� Rank % HARD Plot, which ranks all assay pairs in terms of precision levels 
measured as half of the absolute relative difference from the mean of the assay pairs 
(% HARD), used to visualise relative precision levels and to determine the 
percentage of the assay pairs population occurring at a certain precision level. 

� Mean vs % HARD Plot, used as another way of illustrating relative precision levels by 
showing the range of % HARD over the grade range. 

� Mean vs %HRD Plot is similar to the above, but the sign is retained, thus allowing 
negative or positive differences to be computed.  This plot gives an overall 
impression of precision and also shows whether or not there is significant bias 
between the assay pairs by illustrating the mean percent half relative difference 
between the assay pairs (mean % HRD). 

� Correlation Plot is a simple plot of the value of assay 1 against assay 2.  This plot 
allows an overall visualisation of precision and bias over selected grade ranges.  
Correlation coefficients are also used. 

� Quantile-Quantile (Q-Q) Plot is a means where the marginal distributions of two 
datasets can be compared.  Similar distributions should be noted if the data is 
unbiased. 

� Standard Control Plot shows the assay results of a particular reference standard over 
time.  The results can be compared to the expected value, and the ±10% precision 
lines are also plotted, providing a good indication of both precision and accuracy over 
time. 

14.2 Analytical Quality Control Procedures and Data – Santa Rita Sulphide Deposit

The current quality control procedures include 4 quality control samples: blanks, certified 
reference material (standards), coarse reject sample duplicates (at the lab) and pulp  
re-assay (umpire lab checks). 

Standard blanks are inserted at the beginning of every hole and there after at every 50th 
sample.  Certified reference material (CRM) is inserted for every sample number ending in 
either 20 or 70.  Sample duplicates were inserted at the preparation laboratory for every 
20th sample.  Umpire assay checks (pulp re-assay) were also completed using ACME and 
Ultra Trace laboratories. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 71 
Technical Report – May 2008 

14.2.1 Blanks 

Laboratory blanks usually comprised either flux or pure silica.  MNL also used internal field 
blanks of pure quartz, which were inserted at the start of every hole, as well as for every 
sample number ending in 50 or 00 (i.e. every 50 samples).  Blanks were used as a test for 
contamination during the sample preparation process. 

14.2.2 Standard Samples 

The standards used were CRM purchased from Geostats Pty Ltd who specialise in 
analytical quality control and the production of certified standards.  The CRM was inserted 
into an empty calico bag at sample numbers ending with 20 and 70.  Three different 
standards (targeting high, medium & low grade Ni) were rotated in the sample sequence 
and the standard's number recorded for QAQC reporting. 

The 4 standards used from Geostats Pty Ltd are GBM396-8C, GBM396-8, GBM301-3 and 
GBM999-1. 

The standards were only certified for Ni, Cu and Co.  The standards assays were 
monitored for any assays falling outside certified ranges.  These failed sample batches 
were flagged and investigated. 

14.2.3 Sample Duplicates 

Sample duplicates (coarse reject duplicates) are prepared from the submitted sample after 
primary crushing.  The crushed sample was split using a riffle or rotary splitter with a 
second sample or coarse reject sample collected.   A splitting process then further reduced 
each sub-sample until a sample size of approximately 500g was attained.  Each sample 
was then pulverised as per standard procedures to produce a pulp.  The two duplicate 
pulps were inserted into the sample batch at the rate of 1 in 20. 

The duplicate samples have been used to determine analytical error pertaining to the 
sample preparation and analytical procedures. 

14.2.4 Pulp Re-assay (Umpire Assays) 

Independent re-assaying (umpire assaying) of pulps has been completed.  These umpire 
assays are collected from the primary sample, at the discretion of the geologist, and 
provide a measure of relative analytical accuracy. 

14.2.5 Size Fraction Analysis 

Routine size fraction analysis is undertaken by the laboratory as a check on the size 
distribution and homogeneity of the sample at different stages during the sample 
preparation process.  The analysis is completed at a rate of 1 per batch and provides a 
measure of the effectiveness of the pulverisation. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 72 
Technical Report – May 2008 

14.3 Assay Quality Control Data Assessment – ALS Chemex 

14.3.1 ALS - Chemex Internal Standards 

An assessment of the ALS Chemex internal standards was completed by means of control 
plots.  The focus of this investigation was Ni, although associated elements  
(ie. Cu, Co, Pt, Pd & Au) were also reviewed.  In general the internal standard assay result 
indicated acceptable accuracy was being achieved, with the majority of standards falling 
within 90% of the Standard Tolerance Values.  Detail analysis for these standards is found 
in Appendix 3. 

Assaying (Ni) of the low grade standard GBM999-5 by ALS - Chemex was poor with 35% 
of the data outside the expected range, and an 82% bias noted, although Cu and Co 
assays for this standard are acceptable.  Poor Ni results are also returned for standards 
LKSD-3 & PB-106 although the MNL submitted standards indicate the Ni assaying is 
accurate. 

14.3.2 MNL Submitted CRM – ALS 

The following 3 CRM standards were routinely submitted for assaying: 

� Standard 1 (GBM396-8C) - certified value: 

� Ni 4010ppm (expected range - 3,244 to 4,776ppm) 

� Cu 246ppm (expected range - 196 to 296ppm)  

� Co 140ppm (expected range - 102 to 296ppm) 

� Standard 2 (GBM301-3) – certified value: 

� Ni 7,843ppm (expected range – 7,057 to 8,629ppm) 

� Cu 770ppm (expected range - 672 to 868ppm) 

� Co 155ppm (expected range - 155 to 219ppm) 

� Standard 3 (GBM999-1) – certified value: 

� Ni 11,728ppm (expected range – 10,326 to 13,130ppm) 

� Cu 435ppm (expected range - 367 to 503ppm) 

� Co 239ppm (expected range - 239 to 355ppm) 

� Standard 4 (GBM396-8) - certified value: 

� Ni 4064ppm (expected range - 3,312 to 4,816ppm) 

� Cu 246ppm (expected range - 196 to 296ppm)  

� Co 140ppm (expected range - 102 to 296ppm) 

The standards are certified for Ni, Cu and Co only, with the acceptable assay ranges 
(as defined by Geostat) 3 times the standard deviation of the certified grade.  Control plots 
for these standards are found in Appendix 3. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 73 
Technical Report – May 2008 

In general, the CRM assaying falls within acceptable ranges, with the majority of samples 
falling within the tolerance limit (2 times the recommended standard deviation value).  
However, a small percentage of standards are outside the accepted standard range. 

No material bias was identified for Ni (<2%) although Cu and sometimes Co assays over 
reports relative to the certified value by approximately 5-7%.  It is of note that umpire 
assaying completed for Cu return excellent results with no relative accuracy difference 
between ALS Chemex versus ACME nor ALS Chemex and Ultra Trace assaying 
(Section 14.2.4), thus potentially indicating an issue with the CRM Cu grades. 

While Pt is not certified, assaying of the Standard 3 was poor.  Again, the umpire assaying 
completed by ACME and Ultra trace support the accuracy of the ALS Chemex assaying 
with little relative bias identified in these data sets. 

The independently submitted standards indicate the assaying is accurate for Ni and Co, 
and is suitable for the purposes of grade estimation and mine planning studies.  While the 
standard assaying for other elements is problematic, the umpire assaying (Section 14.2.5) 
supports the overall accuracy of the ALS Chemex assaying. 

14.3.3 Blanks 

Blank material submitted returned satisfactory results, although a limited number of Ni and 
Cu blanks returned elevated grades potentially indicating some low level contamination 
(generally <0.01% Ni, <0.005% Cu and <5ppm Co) at the sample preparation process.  
The majority of these blank assays were submitted between samples interpreted to be of 
moderate to high grade.  The generally infrequent values above detection is not material for 
resource estimation study as the elevated blank assays are generally below the detection 
of the resource estimate. 

Ongoing monitoring of QA/QC protocols and data are recommended to ensure 
minimization of further errors. 

14.3.4 Umpire Assaying 

ACME vs ALS - Chemex

In total, 348 umpire assays are available for investigation.  Statistical analysis and plots for 
these data can be found in Appendix 3. 

In summary the following key conclusions are provided: 

� Good correlation (r=0.96) is noted for the Ni assaying.  The scatter plot shows that for 
data above 1% Ni a positive bias in favour of ALS Chemex exists whilst the reverse 
is true below 1% Ni.  Overall the relative accuracy, measured in terms of mean half 
relative difference (HRD), is acceptable with a mean HRD of 2.83% returned.  
Approximately 96% of the data is reported within +/-10% HARD.  It is of note that the 
CRM assayed ACME supports the relative bias above and below 1% Ni. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 74 
Technical Report – May 2008 

� Excellent correlation (r=0.98) for Cu assaying is noted.  Little relative bias is present 
with a mean HRD of 0.57% reported and 97% of data within +/-10% HARD. 

� The ACME Co umpire assays show a significant negative bias, as highlighted with a 
7.81% HARD.  While a strong negative bias exists a reasonable correlation (r=0.94) 
is noted.  The assays of the NML submitted CRM indicates the ACME Co assays are 
biased (17.9%). 

� The ACME Pd umpire assays display a high level of correlation (r=0.98) with the 
original assays.  Approximately 78% of the umpire assays display a better than 10% 
relative precision with the mean HRD calculated at -2.24%, thus indicating little 
relative bias. 

� Similar to the Pd umpire assays, the Pt umpire assays display good correlation 
(r=0.95) and low levels of relative bias (mean HRD = -1.94). 

� Poor levels of relative precision and accuracy are noted for the Au umpire assays.  
However, 3 outlier values exist in the ACME assay data set which impact significantly 
on this comparison.  The overall linear correlation is 0.67 whiles the rank correlation 
(Spearman CC) is much improved at 0.87.  In general, a strong positive bias in 
favour of ACME is noted although the relative accuracy as measured by the mean 
HARD is acceptable at -3.48%.  The MNL submitted CRM assaying completed by 
ACME reports higher values for Standards 1 and 2 (calculated mean of 1,144ppb 
compared to 943ppb and 1,049ppb compared to 914ppb) than reported by 
ALS Chemex. 

14.3.5 Assay Quality Control Data Assessment - Umpire Checks Ultra Trace vs ALS 
Chemex

A limited amount of umpire assaying was completed at Ultra Trace with 135 pairs of data 
available for review.  Detail analysis for these umpire assays is found in Appendix 3. 

Excellent correlation is noted for the Ni results (r= 0.99) and good relative accuracy (mean 
HRD -1.41%).  A slight positive bias in favour of ALS Chemex is noted for assays 
>0.8% NI, however this apparent bias is small with 99.3% of the data within a precision 
measure of 10% HARD. 

Excellent relative accuracy is noted for the Cu umpire assays (mean HRD = -0.01%) with 
the linear correlation calculated at 0.99.  Similarly the Co umpire assays show high levels of 
correlation (r= 0.95) and relatively good intra-laboratory precision (mean HRD = -2.18%). 

The Pt and Pd umpire assays show high levels of intra-laboratory precision and accuracy.  
The linear correlation for both is >0.94 and the mean HRD is calculated at 0.13% and 
0.90% for Pd and Pt respectively. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 75 
Technical Report – May 2008 

As with the ACME umpire assaying, lower levels of intra-laboratory accuracy and precision 
is noted for the Au umpire assays.  Similar marginal distributions are noted until 
approximately 180g/t Au, where the influence of a small number (n<10) of data distort the 
statistic.  A correlation of 0.56 is returned while the relative accuracy is acceptable (mean 
HRD = -2.60%), although on 55.6% of the data is within the relative the precision measure 
of 10% HARD.  No certified gold standards have been submitted and therefore it is not 
possible to resolve the relative accuracy differences identified in the umpire assaying. 

14.3.6 Assay Quality Control Data Assessment - Coarse Reject Duplicates ALS Chemex 
Laboratory 

The coarse reject duplicates have been investigated.  Statistically charts and analyses for 
these duplicates are found in Appendix 3. 

In summary, the coarse rejects indicate the sample preparation has been adequate and is 
not impacting the precision of the majority of assaying.  The Au duplicate assaying is more 
problematic, as was the umpire assaying, with the pulverisation potentially insufficient to 
ensure precise assaying when 0.01ppm detection limits are required and the distribution of 
mineralisation maybe more inhomogeneous. 

14.3.7 Data Quality Summary 

With the exception of Au, the assaying is considered both accurate and precise, and is 
suitable for mine planning studies.  The current quality control protocols are considered to 
be high industry standard and should be maintained for future drilling programs.  However, 
it is recommended that the monitoring of quality control data, especially the standards and 
blank assaying, be done as a routine part of the data management process which for 
logistical reasons in the past has been completed in batches.  Assay batches returning 
CRM assays outside accepted ranges should be rejected and the laboratory asked to re-
assay these samples at no cost.  In addition, the submission of certified Au standards 
should be considered if Au becomes a significant revenue stream for the project and/or if 
improved quality control results are not returned for in future assaying. 

14.4 Analytical Quality Control Procedures – Serra Azul 

14.4.1 Introduction

Two main types of quality control samples were inserted for the Serra Azul deposit drilling: 
internal lab duplicates (at the lab) and internal lab standards.  Two labs were used during 
the drilling phase, ALS Chemex and SGS in Vancouver, Canada.  Detailed QAQC analysis 
for the following is found in Appendix 4. 

14.4.2 ALS Chemex Internal Laboratory Standards 

The majority of the ALS Chemex internal standards reviewed are targeting nickel accuracy, 
along with associated elements (i.e. Cu, Co, Pt, Pd and Au).  In general the results of the 
QA/QC analysis were satisfactory, with the majority of standards falling within the tolerance 
range with little bias evident (<2%). 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 76 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Relatively few standards reported results outside the tolerance range and appear due to 
mixing of standards. 

14.4.3 ALS Chemex Internal Laboratory Duplicate 

There were 212 internal lab duplicate samples taken and assayed for Ni, Cu and Co.  The 
duplicates correlate well with the original assaying (r> 0.999) and 97% of all the data fell 
within a 10% precision limit. 

14.4.4 Assay Quality Control Data Assessment – SGS Canada Internal Laboratory 
Standards

There were 84 blank samples inserted by the laboratory to monitor sample preparation.  
The majority of the blank assays returned values within 10 times the detection limit.  A 
single Ni and 2 Cu results were in excess of the 10 times detection limit.  The SGS blank 
assays indicate that no systematic contamination exists in sample preparation. 

14.4.5 SGS Canada Internal Laboratory Duplicate 

There were 459 internal laboratory duplicate samples taken and assayed for Ni, Cu and 
Co.  All duplicates correlate well with the original assaying (r=0.997) and greater than 94% 
of all the data fell within a 10% precision limit. 

14.4.6 SGS Canada External Duplicates 

There were 48 duplicate samples analysed for Ni using ICP method.  These data 
correlation perfectly (r=1.0) with the original assaying. 

14.5 Bulk Density Determinations 

Bulk density determinations have been carried out by MNL.  Density data (10,329 
determinations) has been collected by MNL using billets selected from available diamond 
core. 

The method applied to density collection for Santa Rita included sun drying, weighing the 
core in air and weighing in water.  The bulk density was then determined as a ratio of 
weight in air over weight in water.  The weighing is completed using high quality electronic 
scales with regular calibration of the scales completed (Figure 14.5_2). 

The method represents an industry standard approach to dry bulk density collection when 
no porosity is present in the rocks, as is the case for the sulphide / fresh mineralisation.  
However, when the rock is partly or completely oxidised the methodology is inappropriate 
as moisture is absorbed during the water immersion step.  During Coffey Mining's site visit, 
randomly selected samples from the transition were re-weighed post water immersion.  An 
increase in the weight, directly attributable to water ingress, was noted in all cases although 
the net change was generally small (<5%) with a maximum difference of approximately 
10% noted.  In these cases the determined relative density represented a wet density or 
specific gravity and is not appropriate for tonnage determination.  However, the magnitude 
of the bulk density issue in the transition is difficult to quantify, although Coffey Mining 
considers the likely over call of the bulk density to be relatively small (<5%). 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 77 
Technical Report – May 2008 

 

Figure 14.5_1 
Serra Azul Deposit – Bulk Sample Shaft 

 
 

Figure 14.5_2 
Calibration of Scales Used for Bulk Density Determinations 

 
 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 78 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Bulk density determinations for the sulphide samples have been conducted in accordance 
with industry standard procedures.  A suite of transitional and oxide samples is currently 
being tested using a method that includes oven drying of the core billet, sealing of the core 
with Paraffin Wax prior to standard immersion method density determinations. 

The summary statistics for bulk density grouped by rock type is summarised in 
Table 14.5_1.

ALS Chemex completed the bulk density testwork for the Serra Azul deposit.  The 
approach taken to this work is consistent with the porous laterite and saprolite regolith 
samples and is considered to be industry standard.  The testwork approach is summarised 
as follows. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 79 
Technical Report – May 2008 

This procedure is used if the sample is porous and must be coated with wax before 
immersion. 

� Oven dry the sample overnight at 105 – 110oC and then allow to cool to room 
temperature. 

� Connect the weighing harness to the balance under hook.  Level the balance and 
zero the display. 

� Place the sample in the harness and weigh the sample in air.  Record this weight 
(W1). 

� Immerse the sample in a container of molten paraffin wax to apply an impervious wax 
coating. 

� Allow the wax to solidify and the sample to return to room temperature.  Weigh the 
wax coated sample and record this weight (W2). 

� Place the coated sample in the harness and suspend the sample and harness in a 
container of water, ensuring that the sample is completely immersed and the harness 
is not in contact with any part of the container.  Record the weight of the immersed 
sample (W3). 

� Calculate the density or specific gravity of the sample as follows: 

Specific gravity = 
W1  

(W2 – W3) – �(W2 – W1)/ ��

Where � = density of the wax 
 
The summary bulk density for the Serra Azul deposit, grouped by zone, is provided as 
Table 14.5_2. 

 
Table 14.5_2

15 ADJACENT PROPERTIES 
There are no mineral deposits associated with adjacent projects that are directly relevant or 
comparable to the Mirabela Project. 

 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 83 
Technical Report – May 2008 

16 MINERAL PROCESSING AND METALLURGICAL TESTING 
16.1 Introduction

The Mirabela Project comprises the Santa Rita deposit that contains nickel sulphide as well 
as lesser amounts of nickel oxides and the Serra Azul deposit which is nickel laterite.   

Santa Rita

A comprehensive testwork program has been undertaken on the nickel sulphides to 
determine the mineralogical, comminution and metallurgical properties of the various 
mineralised zones within the deposit.   

The aim of the testwork programme was to establish a processing route that maximised 
recovery of nickel and copper whilst minimising the incorporation of penalty elements such 
as magnesia.  Testwork to date has established that from a nickel feed grade of 0.61%, a 
nickel concentrate with a grade of 13.0% can be produced at a recovery of approximately 
70%.  In addition, the concentrate contained approximately 4.7% copper and potentially 
payable quantities of gold and platinum group metals. 

The testwork undertaken has been thorough and of high quality, with particular emphasis 
on ensuring that samples tested were representative of the deposit.   All of the metallurgical 
samples tested originated from diamond drill core either 47.6mm (NQ) or, where required, 
85mm (PQ). 

Mirabela proposes to treat approximately 4.6Mtpa of the Santa Rita deposit.  Though the 
Bankable Feasibility Study (BFS) was conducted on 4.0Mtpa, a detailed concept study was 
conducted and the plant was subsequently resized to handle the additional throughput.  
The proposed processing route utilises a conventional SAB (SAG and ball mill) circuit and 
flotation circuit.  A recycle pebble crusher and second ball mill are included in the 4.6Mtpa 
design to ensure confidence in achieving the target grind size at the higher throughput.  
The engineering design philosophy is well supported by testwork. 

Serra Azul

A review has been undertaken of the options available for processing the various laterite 
mineralisation domains as they exist at Serra Azul.  All nickel laterite processing 
technologies have been evaluated, including emerging technologies. 

The studies conclude that the laterite resource of 21mt at 1.17% Ni may be insufficient in 
size to accommodate the operating costs for a leaching project using the more 
conventional processing technologies. 

Heap leaching technology for nickel laterites is an emerging technology that may provide a 
route for processing particular mineralisation types at Serra Azul in the future.  There are 
currently no known projects seeking to prove up the process on a commercial basis, largely 
due to the high operating costs associated with the high acid consumptions. 

Acid consumption has a significant impact on the operating costs for all leaching options 
and has been modelled for each of the Serra Azul mineralised zones. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 84 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The saprolite and high grade saprolite ores may be amenable to treatment in a ferronickel 
smelter.  The combined resource for these potential feed sources of 3.94Mt at 1.91% Ni 
(indicated) would be less likely to justify the construction of a ferronickel smelter on site.   

Direct shipping of the laterite to a ferronickel smelter also represents a potential economic 
project with low risk. 

16.2 Metallurgical Sampling 

The Santa Rita metallurgical testwork was conducted on composites or straight NQ 
diamond drill core taken from 523 drillholes around the Santa Rita deposit.   Five PQ 
diamond drillholes were also drilled where large diameter core was required to generate 
sufficient material for the comminution, engineering design and routine metallurgical 
development testwork. 

Samples for metallurgical testwork were collected immediately after the receipt of assay 
results.  All of the significant intersections (at nickel head grades greater than the cutoff) 
were sampled and divided into pre-determined metallurgical domains, with lithology being 
the predominant control. 

The samples were then placed into protective bags and sent to Independent Metallurgical 
Laboratories Pty Ltd (IML) and AMMTEC Ltd. in Perth, Western Australia, where they were 
kept in cold storage to avoid oxidation until they were required for metallurgical testwork. 

Figure 16.3_1 shows the locations from which the metallurgical samples were derived. 

16.3 Testwork Program 

Preliminary metallurgical testwork began in July 2005 with a number of samples being 
submitted to SGS Lakefield by MNL for flotation testwork.  Subsequent testwork has been 
completed at a number of testing facilities across Australia.  These facilities included, but 
were not limited to: 

� Pontifex and Associates – ore dressing and mineralogy test work and analysis. 

� JKTech – mineralogical testwork and analysis. 

� AMMTEC Ltd – flotation and comminution testwork. 

� Independent Metallurgical Laboratories Pty Ltd – flotation testwork. 

� SGS Lakefield Oretest – Flotation and heap leach testwork and analysis. 

As part of the design and review process, technical professionals external to MNL were 
consulted for advice in their specific areas of expertise.  These professionals included: 

� Orway Mineral Consultants – comminution circuit design. 

� Steve Morell – comminution circuit design review. 

� GRD Minproc – process plant design and review. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 85 
Technical Report – May 2008 

 

Figure 16.3_1 
Santa Rita Overview Displaying Metallurgical Testwork Samples Post BFS 

 
The comminution testwork included a suite of standard tests that were conducted on 
samples collected from the different mineralisation zones within the Santa Rita deposit, as 
described in Section 9.1 of this report.  These tests included SAG milling comminution 
(SMC), full JK drop weight, Bond ball mill work index (BWi), Bond rod mill work index 
(RWi), Bond crusher work index (CWi), unconfined compressive strength (UCS) and 
advanced media competency test (AMCT). 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 86 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The flotation testwork was aimed at optimising parameters such as grind size, reagents 
dosage, pulp density and pH as a means of promoting a higher quality of concentrate.  The 
tests were conducted under a variety of conditions ranging from small 1kg units to 15kg 
bulk units.  Variability with lithology, nickel head grade and weathering were all examined 
as part of variability testwork.  Material below the cutoff grade is also being extensively 
examined using a numerous techniques including conventional flotation and gravity. 

Additional testwork was also completed to establish tailings thickening and materials 
handling properties. 

16.4 Mineralogy 

Pontifex and Associates conducted mineralogical analyses of the flotation feed material 
and a number of the metallurgical testwork products.  This analysis found the dominant 
sulphide minerals in the Santa Rita deposit to be pentlandite, pyrrhotite, pyrite, chalcopyrite 
and violarite.  The major gangue materials were identified as olivine, orthopyroxene, 
serpentine and chrome spinels. 

The recoverable nickel (sulphide) was found to be predominantly found in pentlandite, 
violarite and pyrite. 

Copper was primarily associated with the chalcopyrite though a coarse tailings fraction 
sample exhibited a few large nuggets of native copper. 

Analysis indicated that iron was most abundant in pyrite (~47%), less abundant in 
pentlandite and chalcopyrite (32-34%), and less abundant in chrome spinel (19-24% Fe).  
Where pyrrhotite was present it had approximately 69% iron. 

The platinum group metals were identified as most likely to be in pentlandite, though due to 
the low concentrations in the samples analysed, it was difficult to confirm.  Maximum PGE 
occurred in samples with about 200ppm Co and 0.8% sulphide Ni. 

The investigations indicated a number of key points about the gangue, the most significant 
points being: 

� Between 0.24% - 0.3% nickel is associated with olivine, 0.05 - 0.1% with 
orthopyroxene and approximately 0.09% in chrome spinels. 

� Approximately 110ppm Co is in silicates (between 30 - 50% of the total cobalt). 

� The majority of the iron was found to occur in orthopyroxene, olivine and serpentine. 

� Of the gangue materials, olivine was found to have more abundant iron (11-12%) 
than serpentine (~5-9%) or orthopyroxene (~8%), with even less abundant Fe in 
clinopyroxene (2-3%). 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 87 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The mineralogy also confirmed the optimised grind size (P80 125μm) evidenced in the 
flotation testwork.  The Santa Rita deposit has been categorised in a number of ways 
during the testwork, however, there are four dominant mineralised types.  They are 
orthopyroxenite, olivine orthopyroxenite, harzburgite and dunite.  The orthopyroxenite 
makes up approximately 60% of the deposit and approximately 14% of the contained nickel 
is associated with silicates limiting the recovery to approximately 80% under ideal flotation 
conditions.  The olivine orthopyroxenite makes up 14% of the deposit and has a higher 
nickel sulphide component which allows recoveries of between 70% to 75% to be achieved 
under ideal conditions.  The harzburgite has the highest non recoverable component with 
up to 25% of the nickel in silicate and a maximum recovery of between 60 and 70% under 
ideal conditions.  Harzburgite currently comprises 26% of the overall resource.  The 
remainder is dunite. 

16.5 Metallurgical Testing  

16.5.1 Comminution Testwork 

A thorough comminution testwork program was conducted over three phases, with careful 
consideration in respect to sample representativity from within the Santa Rita deposit. 

Orway Mineral Consultants completed phases 1 and 2 of the comminution testwork with 
GRD Minproc completing phase 3.  The phase 3 testwork identified the various 
mineralisation types and their respective contributions within the deposit.  All of the 
conventional comminution tests were then carried out on these various samples.  
Table 16.5.1_1 summarises the key physical characteristics of the deposit. 

 
Table 16.5.1_1 

Physical Parameters 
 

4.6 Mtpa Design 
Unconfined Compressive Strength (Mpa) 86.6 
Crushing Work Index 23.2 
Bond Work Index - Rod Mill (kWhr/t) 18.4 
Bond Work Index - Ball Mill (kWhr/t) 20.4 
JK Drop Weight A x b 41.3 
SAG Mill Comminution - SMC DWI 7.48 
Abrasion Index 0.346 
 
These results indicate that the samples tested are of medium competency in terms of 
crushing and are in the medium to high range in terms of milling.  The samples tested 
display an amenability to SAG milling and the abrasive properties or wear rates are less 
than that of quartz (0.40), but are still in the medium to high range. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 88 
Technical Report – May 2008 

16.5.2 Batch Flotation Testing 

Extensive flotation testwork, conducted over five phases, was carried out on representative 
samples from the Santa Rita deposit.  All of the testwork was conducted in a thorough 
manner and as was the case with the comminution testwork, considerable attention was 
paid to ensuring that the samples were representative of the deposit. 

Phases 1 to 3 were conducted by IML (now AMDEL Perth, Australia) and focussed on 
optimising concentrate grade and recovery for the different mineral types within the deposit. 

Phase 4 testwork utilised composite samples and the testwork was carried out at two 
independent laboratories, AMDEL and AMMTEC (Perth, Australia). 

The Phase 5 testwork was carried out by AMMTEC and utilised the results of the earlier 
phases to enable further optimisation.  The primary focus of this phase was to utilise a 
composite sample representative of the desired resource head grade and then conduct 
flotation testwork to determine the optimal grind size that would produce the highest grade, 
recovery and iron to MgO ratio. 

In addition to this, there was also an extensive amount of optimisation testwork conducted 
to assess the effects of other factors such as pulp density, reagent addition and regrinding. 

The results of the Phase 5 flotation grind size optimisation testwork are shown in 
Table 16.5.2_1.

This testwork indicated that the optimum flotation grind size was approximately 125μm.  
The final iron to MgO ratio, which ranged between approximately 2.3 and 3.0, did not 
appear to be significantly affected by the primary grind size. 

The most recent testwork conducted at AMMTEC at P80 grind sizes of 125μm and 145μm 
achieved a nickel recovery in excess of 70% at a concentrate grade of 13.0%.  This was 
the first work conducted on a resource composite of 60% orthopyroxenite, 14% olivine 
orthopyroxenite and 26% harzburgite at a nickel head grade of 0.61%.  The results are 
shown in Table 16.5.2_2.

16.5.3 Locked Cycle Testing 

Subsequent to the batch flotation testing, 6-cycle locked cycle flotation tests were 
completed on composite samples from the Santa Rita deposit.  These tests were based on 
the grind size and reagent conditions established in the earlier phases of testing.

Nickel recovery was approximately 72% at 13% nickel in concentrate for the third test 
which was conducted on the latest resource composite.  The concentrate Fe: MgO ratio 
ranged from 2.5:1 to 3: 1. 

16.5.4 Bulk Flotation Testing 

Large scale bulk flotation testing was conducted to produce concentrate to provide product 
to smelters as possible end-users of the concentrates.  A total of 4.6kg of concentrate 
assaying 13.9% Ni, 4.5% Cu, 10.1% MgO and 25.4% Fe, with and Fe: MgO ratio of 2.5: 1 
was produced.

The latest results indicated 71% nickel recovery at 13% nickel grade in concentrate from a

Based on the testwork results, it was concluded that the flash flotation concentrate was not

16.6 Ancillary Testwork 

16.6.1 Bulk Solids Testwork 

The materials handling testwork was conducted at TUNRA Bulk Solids and included: 

� Particle size range determination, 

� Moisture content testwork, 

� Shear testwork, 

� Compressibility testwork, 

� Wall friction testwork, and 

� Angle of repose testwork. 

The results indicated an easy handling material with little bulk strength that increases 
slightly after 3 days undisturbed storage.  The testwork indicated a low tendency to form 
stable ratholes.  The angle of repose was 43° at a worst case moisture content, however, 
this would be expected to decrease as the moisture content was reduced. 

16.6.2 Tailings and Concentrate Thickener Design Testwork 

Outokumpu Technologies conducted thickening testwork on concentrate and tailings 
produced from large scale flotation testwork conducted in Perth.   The tailings sample was 
sourced from a 12kg bulk flotation test and the concentrate sample was sourced from a 
500kg bulk locked cycle test. 

The tests conducted were: 

� Flocculent screening and dilution tests, and 

� A dynamic thickening test. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 91 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Of the four flocculants tested, Magnafloc 342 was found to be the most suitable for both the 
Santa Rita tailings and concentrate.  A flocculent dosage of 10g/t was used in the dynamic 
testwork, based on the flocculent screening testwork results. 

The dynamic thickening testwork results attained at a solids loading of 0.97t/m2h at an 
underflow density of 67.0%w/w solids for the tailings and a solids loading of 0.25t/m2h at an 
underflow density of 75.5%w/w solids for the concentrate. 

The thickener requirements as recommended by Outokumpu are shown in Table 16.6.2_1. 
 

Table 16.6.2_1 
Thickening Testwork 

Flocculent Magnafloc 342 Magnafloc 342 
Flocculent dosage 10g/t 10g/t 
Underflow density < 200ppm < 50ppm 
Overflow clarity 66 to 67 %w/w solids >75%w/w solids 
Thickener diameter 23m 10m 
 
MNL chose to take an approach leaving the largest potential for upgrade with a 35m 
diameter tailings thickener and a 15m diameter concentrate thickener. 

16.6.3 Tailings Storage Facility Design Testwork 

Golder and Associates conducted tailings storage facility testwork on a sample sourced 
from a 15kg bulk flotation test. 

The following tests were conducted on the tailings sample provided: 

� Particle size distribution test; 

� Particle density test; 

� Settling tests, and 

� Permeability test. 

The testwork report described the tailings material as a Sandy SILT / Silty SAND, with 
100% passing 300μm and a P80 of about 110μm.  About 5% of the material was less than 
one micron in size and the calculated tailings solid density was 3.20g/cm3. 

The aim of the settling test was to determine the ease in which a tailings beach could be 
formed and the clarity of the supernatant pond water.  The test results indicated that the 
tailings solids would likely settle out of the tailings slurry relatively quickly, with the liquid 
flowing on to form a reasonably clear supernatant pond with minimal suspended solids, 
allowing recovery and recycling of water to occur. 

The aim of the permeability testwork is to estimate a coefficient of hydraulic conductivity for 
use in seepage modelling.  The results of these tests showed approximate rates of  
6.5 x 10-7m/s and 6.6 x 10-7m/s. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 92 
Technical Report – May 2008 

It is proposed that a consolidation test and a direct shear test would also be conducted.  
Sufficient sample is still available to conduct these tests. 

16.7 Heap Leach Testwork 

A bench scale analysis was conducted by MNL on the option of using heap leach to treat 
2.0 million tonnes of oxide overburden at a head grade of 0.79% nickel and potentially 
2.5 million tones of laterite overburden at 2.2% nickel. 

Testwork was conducted on a sample of the oxide overburden at SGS Lakefield Oretest.  
The testwork showed that approximately 70% of the nickel was likely to be recoverable at a 
relatively low acid addition rate. 

16.8 Additional Testwork 

Additional testwork is currently being undertaken to finalise and optimise various aspects 
so as to determine: 

� The metallurgy of the low grade ore types, 

� Bulk scale performance, 

� Magnesia rejection testwork, 

� Concentrate production testwork for smelters, 

16.9 Testwork Summary 

The comminution and metallurgical testwork programs are considered to be of high quality 
and accounted for the variability of the mineralised zones within the Santa Rita deposit.  
The testwork has enabled the key process design criteria to be established. 

The key results of the testwork program are as follows: 

� The deposit has been categorised throughout much of the testwork into a number of 
relatively complex mineralogical zones, however, this can be simplified back to four 
major mineralogical types; orthopyroxenite, which represents approximately 60% of 
the deposit and has approximately 15% of the nickel associated with silicates and 
hence has a maximum recovery of approximately 80%; olivine orthopyroxenite which 
represents approximately 14% of the deposit and contains approximately 20% of the 
nickel in silicate, harzburgite which has the highest non recoverable nickel 
component of approximately 25% and represents approximately 26% of the deposit. 

� The samples are in the medium range in terms of competency for crushing and 
grinding.  The comminution results also indicated that SAG milling would be 
appropriate for these samples. 

� Based on the samples, the grind characteristics are consistent throughout the 
deposit. 

� The optimum rougher P80 grind size is approximately 125μm. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 93 
Technical Report – May 2008 

� A nickel concentrate grade of approximately 13% can be achieved via conventional 
flotation at a recovery of approximately 70%. 

� There is still potential for improvements in both nickel grade and nickel recovery.  
This would most likely be achieved through further optimisation of the flotation 
parameters and concentrate regrind options.  It should be noted that the overall 
nickel recovery will remain limited to a large extent by the percentage of nickel 
associated with sulphides in the deposit. 

� Flash flotation is not considered to provide any benefits to the flowsheet. 

� The settling properties of the flotation tail are acceptable in terms of flocculent 
consumption, thickener capacity, underflow density and overflow liquor clarity. 

16.10 Key Process Design Parameters 

The key process design parameters derived from the testwork are summarised in 
Table 16.10_1. 

 
Table 16.10_1 

Key Process Design Parameters 

Physical Properties 

UCS MPa 86.6 
Crushing Work Index kWh/t 23.2 
Bond Work Index - Rod Mill kWh/t 18.4 
Bond Work Index - Ball Mill kWh/t 20.4 
JK Drop Weight A x b  41.3 
SAG Mill Comminution SMC DWI  7.48 
Abrasion Index  0.346 

Flotation 

Optimum Mill Product Size, P80 microns 125 
Nickel Feed Grade % 0.61 
Nickel Concentrate Grade % 13.0 
Nickel Recovery % ~70 

Thickening 
Settling Rate t/m2h 0.95 
Underflow Density %w/w solids 65.0 

 
16.11 Process Plant 

The proposed process plant to treat the Santa Rita deposit consists of primary crushing, 
conventional SAG and ball milling, followed by a flotation circuit. 

It is proposed that material would be delivered to a primary crusher via a front end loader 
and / or 100 tonne dump trucks.  The primary crusher would reduce the ROM feed to a P80 
size of 120mm.  This material would then be conveyed to a coarse 'ore' stockpile where it 
could be fed at a steady rate to the milling circuit. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 94 
Technical Report – May 2008 

A comprehensive study has been undertaken in respect of the milling circuit, which would 
have a 8MW SAG mill in open circuit with a 5.8MW ball mill to produce a rougher feed at a 
P80 grind size of 125μm.  Changes in the overall resource composition and the requirement 
for additional throughput made it a necessity to also include a second ball mill and pebble 
crusher.  The capacity and configuration of the comminution circuit is considered 
acceptable, particularly with provision to include a regrind mill if necessary later in the 
project. 

The comminution properties of potential mining dilution was not tested, however the 
geological assessment indicated that there is unlikely to be any material difference in the 
competency of the mineralised zones as opposed to the waste zones. 

The flotation circuit design is based on the metallurgical testwork that was completed and 
includes a conventional rougher/cleaner arrangement.  Based on the high quality of the 
flotation testwork, there would be a high degree of confidence in the established design 
parameters and hence it is considered that if normal engineering practices are followed, 
this section of the plant would be capable of achieving the results seen in the testwork. 

The flotation tailings testwork established the design parameters for both the tailings 
thickener and the tailings storage facility.  Testwork relating to concentrate thickening and 
filtration is incomplete, however, this would be considered as a low risk in terms of potential 
project implementation. 

The proposed flow sheet for the Santa Rita deposit is shown in Figure 16.11_1. 

16.12 Engineering Design Philosophy 

The engineering design has been completed by GRD Minproc and has formed a major part 
of the Bankable Feasibility Study document. 

The engineering design philosophy is conventional and supported by the testwork 
programs and includes primary crushing, SAG and ball milling, flotation, thickening and 
filtration and is considered robust. 

The plant design allows for the retro fitting of both flash flotation and a regrind circuit if 
necessary. 

The target plant availability is readily achievable at 91.3%. 

16.13 Services and Infrastructure 

The project is located adjacent to sealed highways with high-voltage power supply lines 
crossing the tenement areas.  Water is provided for industrial and pastoral activity by the 
Rio de Contas, other major watercourses and numerous artesian bores.
