MirabelaProject Page: 96 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The nearby towns of Ipiau and Itagiba are well endowed with commercial activity and 
industrial support services such as transport and earthmoving, construction, commercial 
and banking and are capable of providing a source of skilled and unskilled labour. 

The reliability of the power supply has been taken into account in respect to the targeted 
plant availability. 

A water balance has been completed by Golders Associates and confirms that there are 
adequate water resources available for the 4.0Mtpa and 4.6Mtpa operations. 

16.14 Tailings Storage Facility 

Golder Associates have completed the design of the proposed tailings storage facility to a 
pre-feasibility level.  The technical specifications for construction were supplied to GRD 
Minproc to enable capital costing estimates to +/-30% to be completed.  The design 
concept includes waste rock embankments, a fully HDPE lined facility, a fixed decant 
structure, a tailings underdrainage system and a liner underdrainage system. 

16.15 Capital Costs 

Mirabela has completed capital cost engineering estimates to an accuracy of +/- 10% for a 
4.6Mtpa nickel concentrator appropriate for the Santa Rita deposit. 

The capital cost estimate including processing plant, infrastructure, port facilities, EPCM, 
commissioning, first fills, spare parts and contingency is USD267 million.  This is based on 
detailed equipment lists with real pricing for major equipment. 

A breakdown of the capital cost estimate to an accuracy of ±10% is shown in 
Table 16.15_1.

16.16 Operating Costs 

GRD Minproc has completed operating cost estimates for the Mirabela processing plant.  
The operating cost estimate at a throughput of 4.0Mtpa is USD$6.89 per tonne of ore. 

A summary breakdown of the operating cost estimate is shown in Table 16.16_1. 
:  

Table 16.16_1 

Mirabela Project @ 4Mtpa 
Plant Operating Cost Estimate 

Area USD $ per tonne 
Labour $0.83 
Power $2.34 
Reagents & Consumables $2.15 
Maintenance $1.27 
Administration $0.06 
Miscellaneous $0.18 
Tax $0.06 
Total $6.89 
 
The overall operating cost estimate is considered to be reasonable and is supported by a 
detailed breakdown of consumption rates and unit costs. 

The overall estimate is considered to be achievable to an accuracy of ±15%. 

MNL has conducted an internal review of the 4.0Mtpa operating cost scenario and 
considers a 16% increase in this cost to be sufficient in order to allow for currency 
movement and inflation.  This equates to an operating cost of $7.99. 

Power

The power is accurately estimated based on a supply price of USD$0.0533/kWh and a 
theoretical consumption of approximately 42kWh/t.  It is probable that the overall 
consumption of power in the processing plant on a per tonne basis may be less than that 
calculated (due to the spare power capacity within the grinding circuit) and although this 
cost has been classified by GRD Minproc as a variable cost, the major component of the 
cost of power consumption will tend to be of a fixed nature, hence savings may be realised 
in this area. 

Reagents & Consumables

The reagent consumptions have been calculated based on optimised laboratory testwork 
data. 

The mill liner change-out frequencies are considered optimistic.  However, any increased 
consumption rate in mill liners would likely be offset by improved mill liner configurations 
and / or prices that might be achieved after the first year of operation. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 98 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Maintenance & Administration

The maintenance and administration costs are considered to be reasonable. 

Miscellaneous

The miscellaneous costs are considered reasonable for the first year of operation, after 
which there may be potential for minor cost reductions. 

Overall

The operating cost estimate, despite the potential for variance within the various areas is 
considered valid. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 99 
Technical Report – May 2008 

17 MINERAL RESOURCES AND MINERAL RESERVES 
17.1 Introduction

Two Mineral Resource estimates have been generated and reported for the Mirabela 
Project.  Estimates for the Santa Rita Nickel Sulphide deposit and the Serra Azul Laterite 
Nickel deposit have been completed.  Mineral Reserves have been reported for the Santa 
Rita deposit. 

The Santa Rita deposit has been estimated by MNL under the supervision of Brett 
Gossage of Coffey Mining, who is considered an Independent Qualified Person.  The Serra 
Azul deposit has been estimated by Independent Consultants Resource Evaluations Pty 
Ltd (ResEval) on behalf of MNL.  The Serra Azul estimate has been reviewed by Brett 
Gossage of Coffey Mining and is the Independent Qualified Person for this resource 
estimate. 

17.2 Santa Rita Sulphide Nickel Project 

17.2.1 Study Data 

The Santa Rita deposit resource estimate is based on the 378 diamond drillholes for 
93,757.88m drilled by MNL and by Brazilian companies CBPM and Caraíba Metais SA.  
The resource estimate is based on drilling and assay data collected in relevant drillholes up 
to and including MBS-439.  A summary of the drilling statistics by drill type, including data 
used for the resource estimate, is provided as Table 17.2.1_1.  The holes are also shown in 
Figure 17.2.1_1.  Significant intersections of additional drill completed post resource cutoff 
date are presented as Appendix 1. 

 
Table 17.2.1_1 

Summary of Santa Rita Drilling Grouped by Hole Type 
 

Holes In Database (as at 28/09/2007) Used in Santa Rita Resource 
Holes Metres Holes Metres 

DDH 426 102,627.90 378 93,757.88 
RC 71 6,699.00 - - 
 497 109,326.90 378 93,757.88 
 
In addition to the drilling data, 10,329 bulk density determinations have been collected and 
used as the basis for tonnage reporting.  Detailed topographic survey data has also been 
collected and used to generate a robust digital terrain model. 

17.2.2 Geological Model 

MNL generated a geological model for the Santa Rita deposit using the 3D software 
package Surpac.  Variables estimated include Ni, Cu, Co, Pt, Pd, Au, Fe, Mg and S. 

Wireframe surfaces were generated by connecting east-west cross-sectional interpretations 
to model lithological contacts, faults, mineralised zones and the bases of oxidation, 
supergene and transition. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 100 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The base of oxidation is defined by the depth of full oxidation of the rock.  Over the gabbro, 
the depth of full oxidation is consistently shallow and is generally only a few metres in 
depth.  This depth increases substantially over the more mafic lithologies to tens of metres, 
with a maximum oxidation depth of 55m over the dunite. 

 

Figure 17.2.1_1 
Drillhole Collar Locations 

 
 

The base of the supergene zone is defined by a combination of factors including the assay 
data (especially Ni and S), lithological logs and core photos.  This surface mimics the base 
of oxidation (i.e. shallower over the gabbro and deeper over the more mafic lithologies) and 
can be as deep as 70m over the central zone. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 101 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The base of the transition zone is defined simply by the presence of violarite.  This surface 
again mimics the base of oxidation (i.e. shallower over the gabbro and deeper over the 
more mafic lithologies) and can be as deep as 100m over the central zone. 

Table 17.2.2_1 lists the weathering wireframes constructed. 
 

Table 17.2.2_1 

Listing of Oxidation Wireframe Surfaces 

Wireframe/DTM Oxidation Code Coding Priority 
oxide_sections_v231.dtm Oxide 1 
supergene_sections_v232.dtm Supergene 2 
transition_base_v28.dtm Transition 3 
 Fresh 4 
 
Mineralisation at Santa Rita occurs as disseminated sulphides within a layered mafic-
ultramafic intrusion. 

The layered intrusion includes from the stratigraphic 'base' moving upwards: 

� Dunite (Serpentinite) (base) 

� Harzburgite 

� Olivine Orthopyroxenite 

� Orthopyroxenite 

� Gabbro (top) 

The main concentration of sulphides is spread across three main lithologies - the 
harzburgite, olivine orthopyroxenite and the orthopyroxenite.  Minor sulphides do also occur 
in the dunite and the gabbro. 

To assist the metallurgical classification, these rock units have been abbreviated.  The 
abbreviated codes are listed in Table 17.2.2_2. 

 
Table 17.2.2_2 

Listing of Abbreviated Rock Units 
 

Rock Unit Rock Unit Code 
Dunite (Serpentinite) S 
Harzburgite H 
Olivine Orthopyroxenite O 
Orthopyroxenite P 
Gabbro G 
 
The lithological contacts between the different rock types have been modelled as sub-
parallel layers that dip generally between 50º and 60º to the east.  In some places the 
contacts are offset by a series of faults interpreted to strike NNE and dip sub-vertically to 
the west. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 102 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Between sections 8,430,950mN and 8,431,250mN, a late barren dolerite dyke cross-cuts 
all lithologies and the mineralised zone.  The dyke strikes ESE-WNW and dips 75º to the 
SSW.  Two splays come off the main dyke, thickest at the western side and thinning to the 
east.  One splay strikes E-W and the other strike SE-NW. 

The mafic intrusive sequence is truncated to the north and south by basement rocks. 

The mineralised zone has been defined using the sulphur content.  Silicate Ni levels (based 
on analysis of drillhole assay data) vary in the host lithologies (averaging 0.225% Ni in the 
dunite, 0.175% in the harzburgite, 0.125% in the olivine orthopyroxenite, and 0.075% in the 
orthopyroxenite) and hence it is not possible to use a single Ni cutoff to define the 
mineralised zone.  The chart below (Figure 17.2.2_1) shows the relationship between Ni 
and sulphur in the drillhole samples.  A base value of 0.2% sulphur was chosen to create a 
mineralised envelope that was continuous and represented sulphide Ni grades not silicate 
Ni material. 

 
Figure 17.2.2_1 

Santa Rita - Ni versus S Scatter Plot – 1m Drillhole Assays

A 3D perspective of the interpreted lithology and mineralisation interpretation is provided as

The sulphide zone was modelled in Surpac file 'interp_sulph_v1280.dtm' and was broken 
up into a number of domains, as listed below, to deal with the fault offsets, and the spatial 
breaks in the interpreted mineralisation zone.

17.2.3 Statistical Analysis 

The drillhole database was composited to a 3m downhole composite interval, recording the 
geological model.  Residual (partial) composites less than 75% of the 3m interval were 
rejected from further study.  The 3m composites were used for all statistical, geostatistical 
and grade estimation studies. 

The decision to use 3m composites was based on the targeted mining approach which is to 
be conventional open pit methods and will be moderately selective.  The majority of the 
sampling (>99.9%) have been collected using a 1m sample interval and the 3m composite 
interval is appropriate as a direct multiple of the in situ sample length and requires no 
splitting of sample intervals. 

Statistical analysis of the composite datasets was completed grouped by the main domains 
described in Section 8 (Domains 1 to 10).  Elements included in the composite database 
are Ni, Cu, Co, Pd, Pt, Au, Fe, Mg and S. 

As discussed in previous sections, the majority of the mineralisation is hosted in the 
pyroxenite and peridotite (harzburgite plus olivine orthopyroxenite) lithologies, with the 
highest mean grade of the composites returned from the olivine orthopyroxenite, as 
displayed in Figure 17.2.3_1. 

 
Figure 17.2.3_1 

Box Plot – 3m Ni (%) Composites Grouped by Lithology 

0

0.5

1

1.5

2

2.5

3

Dunite Harzburgite Olivine
Orthopyroxenite

Orthopyroxenite Gabbro Basement

N
i p

ct

Q1
min

max
Q3

 
Q1 0.289 0.282 0.226 0.194 0.04775 0.01175
min 0.009 0 0.005 0.001 0.041 0.001

median 0.348 0.348 0.41 0.3205 0.0835 0.0785
max 1.397 1.643 1.847 1.627 0.432 4.803
Q3 0.54875 0.673 0.773 0.55275 0.242 0.20175

 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 110 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The northern region (Domains 6 and 7) represents the highest grade mineralisation 
although very similar statistics are noted for each of the domains.  As displayed in 
Figure 17.2.3_1, the Ni grade distributions display slight positive skew with low coefficient 
of variations (CV - calculated by dividing the standard deviation by the mean grade) which 
are generally below 1.  The statistics are consistent with well behaved and consistent with 
most disseminated Ni sulphide deposits.  Few outlier intervals were identified in the review.  
Descriptive statistics are presented in Table 17.2.3_1. 

Appendix 6 provides the statistics plots generated for the Santa Rita deposit. 

An assessment of the high-grade composites was completed to determine the requirement 
for high-grade cutting (capping).  As previously discussed, the distribution statistics 
identified very few outliers which required adjusting.  Only two (2) Ni, two (2) Cu and one 
(1) Co samples were cut (capped) for the entire composite dataset as highlighted below in 
Table 17.2.3_2. 

The correlation between variables has been assessed as displayed in the correlation matrix 
presented as Table 17.2.3_3.  Significant levels of correlation (r>0.80) are common with the 
strongest correlation, excluding the Ni and S correlation, 0.935 noted for Ni and Cu in 
Domain 8.  The strong correlation between elements potentially provides an opportunity to 
regress grades for primary Ni estimates.  However, a significant level of local error would 
be introduced and therefore both OK and regression estimates have been generated for 
the final resource model.  In addition, as all elements are well represented in the drilling 
little benefit exists in co-estimation such as co-kriging. 

17.2.4 Variography 

Variography is used to describe the spatial variability or correlation of an attribute (Ni, Cu 
etc).  The spatial variability is traditionally measured by means of a variogram, which is 
generated by determining the averaged squared difference of data points at a nominated 
distance (h), or lag.  The averaged squared difference (variogram or �(h)) for each lag 
distance is plotted on a bivariate plot, where the X-axis is the lag distance and the Y-axis 
represents the average squared differences (�(h)) for the nominated lag distance.  The 
term variogram will be used as a generic term to describe all spatial measures in this 
document. 

The variography was calculated and modelled in the geostatistical software, Isatis, and 
mining package, Surpac.  The rotations are reported in mathematical notation (Az, Ay, Ax) 
with the X, Y and Z axis also referred to as the major, semi-major and minor axes 
respectively. 

Variography was generated for the principal variables (Ni, Cu, Co, Pd, Pt, Au, Fe, Mg and S) 
based on the 3m downhole composites.  High grade cuts (caps) were applied to the 
composites prior to generating the variography, as described in Section 9.

Technical Report – May 2008

MirabelaProject Page: 114 
Technical Report – May 2008 

Based on previous studies and statistical analysis described in Section 9, a decision was 
taken to group the composite data for the purposes of variography.  The main 
mineralisation domains were grouped into the Southern Domain (Domain 1), the Central 
Domain (Domains 2, 3, 4, and 5) and the North Domain Domains 6 and7).  The 
hangingwall mineralisation (Domains 8 and 9) were grouped and investigated separately as 
was the footwall mineralisation (Domain 10).  The domain grouping as applied to 
variography is shown in Figure 17.2.4_1. 

The variogram models fitted and applied to resource estimation are provided in 
Table 17.2.4_1.  A summary of the key aspects of the variography is provided in bullet form 
below: 

� The Ni variography modelled for the main mineralisation zones (Domains 1 to 7) 
were very similar as were the Cu and Co variograms, although with an approximate 
5 to 105 higher nugget effect noted for the Cu variograms. 

� The relative nugget (% nugget variance of the total variogram variance) for the Ni 
variography has been modelled at approximately 10% for the majority of zones.  The 
footwall mineralisation (Domain 10) displayed the highest relative nugget effect being 
modelled at 21%.  Excluding the footwall mineralisation, similar relative nugget 
effects, ranging from 11% to 26%, were modelled for the remaining variables.  The 
Au variography consistently were modelled with the highest nugget effect. 

� The short-range structures generally contribute a significant portion of the non-
nugget variance, and have been fitted with a range approximating the drill spacing 
(25m to 50m). 

� Overall ranges are noted to be in excess of the current drill spacing.  For Ni, a 
maximum major and semi-major axis range of 90m or greater has been fitted.  The 
minor axis range has been fitted with ranges between 25m and 60m. 

The variography indicates that low to moderate levels of short range variability exists, which 
is consistent with a disseminated Ni sulphide mineralisation style.  Applying the variogram 
models to estimation with OK, it is expected the moderate levels of smoothing will result 
and that a non-linear estimation method, such as UC, will be required to enable reporting of 
an appropriate selective mining estimate. 

Modelled variograms for are included as Figures 17.2.4_2 to 17.2.4_6 for Domain 1, 
Domains 2 through 5, Domains 6 and 7, Domains 7 and 8, and Domain 10 respectively.  
Appendix 7 provides the modelled variograms for Ni, Cu, Co, Au, Pt, Pd, S, Fe and Mg. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 115 
Technical Report – May 2008

17.2.5 Block Model Development 

A three dimensional block model was generated to enable grade estimation.  The selected 
block size was based on the geometry of the domain interpretation and the data 
configuration.  A parent block size of 20mE x 25mN x 5mRL was selected with sub-blocking 
to a 5mE x 12.5mN x 2.5mRL cell size to improve volume representation of the interpreted 
wireframe models.  Sufficient variables were included in the block model construction to 
enable grade estimation and reporting. 

The 20mE x 25mN x 5mRL block size represents the approximate drill spacing of the 
northern region of the deposit which has been classified as high confidence resource.  The 
remainder of the deposit is defined by an approximate 40m or greater drill spacing.

Variogram Model - Global Window

Isatis
Composites/SRN Oct07 3m comps(Est Domain{Northern Domain (6 & 7)})
- Variable #1 : ni
Experimental Variogram : in 1 direction(s)
D6  : N110 D50
      Angular tolerance =  15.00
      Lag =  40.00m, Count = 10 lags, Tolerance = 50.00%
Model : 4 basic structure(s)
Global rotation = (Az=-110.00, Ay=  0.00, Ax=-50.00)
S1  - Nugget effect, Sill =       0.01
S2  - Spherical - Range = 20.00m, Sill =      0.057
      Directional Scales = (     40.00m,     35.00m,     20.00m)
S3  - Spherical - Range = 40.00m, Sill =       0.01
      Directional Scales = (     40.00m,    150.00m,     60.00m)
S4  - Spherical - Range = 60.00m, Sill =      0.019
      Directional Scales = (    130.00m,    150.00m,     60.00m)

The block model construction parameters are displayed in Table 17.2.5_1. 
 

Table 17.2.5_1 
Santa Rita Deposit 

Block Model Parameters 
 

 East North Elevation 
Origin 421,500 8,429,200 -400 
Extent (m) 2,500 3,000 800 
Parent Block size (m) 20 25 5 
Sub-Block Size (m) 5 12.5 2.5 
Number of Blocks (parent) 500 240 320 

 
The mineralisation domains, lithology and modelled oxidation were coded to the block 
model.  The mean bulk density, sub-divided by lithology and oxidation, was applied to the 
block model for tonnage reporting, as summarised below in Table 17.2.5_2. 

 
Table 17.2.5_2

17.2.6 Grade Estimation 

Resource estimation for the Santa Rita deposit was undertaken using OK as the principal 
estimation method for Ni, Cu, Co, Pd, Pt, Au, Fe, Mg and S.  The OK estimates were 
completed using Surpac mining software.  UC was subsequently used to produce a SMU 
resource estimate for Ni. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 123 
Technical Report – May 2008 

OK grade estimates were generated based on the 3m composite data and applying a 
restricted number of composite data.  All variables have been estimated with the same 
sample search approach and orientations.  A staged sample search was applied to the 
generation of the OK grade estimate with the generalised approach as summarised below: 

� Pass 1 minimum of 8 and maximum of 24 composites collected within an 80m 
(major axis) x 80m (semi-major axis) x 26.67m (minor axis search) sample 
search.  A maximum of five 3m composites could be used for any block 
estimate. 

� Pass 2 minimum of 8 and maximum of 24 composites collected within a 160m 
(major axis) x 160m (semi-major axis) x 53.33m (minor axis search) sample 
search.  A maximum of five 3m composites could be used for any block 
estimate. 

� Pass 3 minimum of 8 and maximum of 24 composites collected within a 240m 
(major axis) x 240m (semi-major axis) x 80m (minor axis search) sample 
search.  A maximum of five 3m composites could be used for any block 
estimate. 

Additional estimation passes with expanded sample searches were completed; however 
these estimates are not included in the final resource model and therefore are not reported. 

The sample searches have been adjusted to match the interpreted sub-domain geometry 
with the OK estimates based on variography presented in Section 17.2.4.  Sample search 
parameters are provided as Appendix 8.  The OK estimation has been completed with a 3 x 
3 x 3 block discretisation and parent cell estimation was completed. 

The sample search parameters were derived based on iterative test runs and were 
designed to restrict smoothing to appropriate levels without compromising the estimation 
quality.  The OK grade estimation results are globally reflective of the predicted grade 
tonnage distribution before change of support was applied to produce a selective mining 
model using UC.  Upper cuts, as presented in Table 17.2.3_2, were applied to estimation. 

The estimation domains, as described in Section 17.2.2 were used for data collection.  The 
mineralisation zones were considered as soft boundaries (i.e. sample collection across 
domain boundaries) for the major mineralisation zones (i.e. Domains 1 through 7, and 
Domains 8 and 9) but data was not shared between the main, hangingwall and footwall 
mineralisation zones. 

17.2.7 Validation 

Extensive visual and statistical validation of the grade estimates was completed.  This 
process included: 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 124 
Technical Report – May 2008 

� Review of the block estimate and the composite data in cross section, long section 
and plan views. 

� Comparison of composite grades and block model grades broken down into Northing 
and RL zones (see charts in Appendix 9). 

� Comparison of the mean grade of the estimate versus the mean grade, subdivided 
by estimation domain (see Appendix 9). 

� Comparison of the OK estimate (Ni only) versus the global change of support derived 
via the discrete gaussian change of support. 

The validation indicates that the resource model replicates the source input data well in 
regions of higher density drilling.  The regions where the data density is lower, smoothing is 
evident, however the estimates are considered appropriate. 

The restriction of the sample search for high-grade composites has ensured reasonable 
limits on the extrapolation of high-grade data.  When the mean grade of the input data, 
declustered where appropriate, is compared with the overall grade of the estimate a high 
degree of correlation is noted, except in regions of lower data density. 

17.2.8 Change of Support 

17.2.8.1 Introduction to Change of Support 

In most resource estimations in mining, the issue of 'change of support' is of great 
significance.  The variability encountered in a deposit when taking small samples is very 
different from the variability encountered when mining the same deposit using larger 
(selective) mining units.  The change of support calculation basically models these 
differences. 

If the whole deposit could be mined as one sample, and processed through the mill and the 
metallurgical plant as one sample, there would be no variability and the value returned by 
the plant would simply be the mean value of the entire deposit.  Typically, the sampling of 
the resource is based on volumes much smaller than those extracted during mining.  The 
observed differences between the value distribution of the samples and the grade 
distribution of mining panels has an impact on achieved mine grades, particularly when 
grade cutoffs are used to delineate areas of economic mineralisation. 

In addition to this difference, at the final grade control stage there will still be insufficient 
information to distinguish waste and ore without some error.  This final error is known as 
the 'Information Effect' and, although it may be small, it also needs to be modelled into the 
resource estimate. 

In order to appreciate the possible effects of applying a specific selectivity, and of applying 
grade cutoffs, it is necessary that the differences in distributions are quantified and 
accounted for in the resource estimation.  This in turn aids in assessing the risks of 
overestimating or underestimating the resource at a local level. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 125 
Technical Report – May 2008 

A number of methods exist for analysing the change of support: 

� At the global level, it is possible to model grade-tonnage curves for each domain, 
using a particular correction method (e.g. affine correction, indirect log-Normal 
correction, discrete Gaussian model). 

� At the local level, the aim is to estimate grade-tonnage curves for individual panels. 

This last process is critically dependent on drillhole density and good quality variography.  
The techniques used at the local level are generally referred to as non-linear geostatistical 
methods. 

17.2.8.2 Uniform Conditioning 

In the case of the Santa Rita estimates, the "recoverable" resources emulating selective 
mining of units smaller than the estimation block size were calculated by the UC method, 
using Isatis software.  The objective when estimating local "recoverable" resources is to 
obtain the proportion of mineralisation above a particular cutoff, within panels large enough 
for robust estimation.  Estimation of the panels was carried out by OK. 

In calculating the proportion of mineralisation above a cutoff, it is necessary to determine 
how selectively the mining will be completed.  The SMU reflects mining selectivity.  When 
UC was carried out, the proportion of mineralisation and metal tonnes above a cutoff were 
computed.  In this study, it was established that a 20m E-W x 25m N-S x 5m RL panel 
could be reliably estimated from the given drilling grid, and that a SMU of 5m x 10m x 5m 
would be used to represent mining selectivity. 

The main steps involved in UC are as follows: 

� Definition of the geometry of the block model, including the definition of the panels to 
be estimated. 

� Transformation, or "anamorphosis", of the Ni composite data. 

� Variography of the raw composite data.  The variography of the transformed data is 
only needed to help determine a fitting for the raw variogram. 

� Estimation of the mean grade of panels by OK. 

� Computation of change of support coefficients (see below) for both the SMU (5m x 
10m x 5m) and the estimation panel (20m x 25m x 5m).  Information effect was 
included in the SMU calculation. 

� Computation of the "recoverable" functions giving the proportion of mineralisation and 
metal within each estimation panel. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 126 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The modelled grade variability (the variogram) was used to calculate the expected 
variability of SMU size parcels of mineralisation (which will be less than that of samples or 
composites).  The modelled distribution of composites (weighted) was then adjusted to 
reflect the expected variability of mining units.  The adjustment factor is called the change 
of support coefficient.  This process assumes that the distribution of SMU's de-skews as 
the SMU size increases (which is expected) and adjusts the distribution appropriately.  
Other methods (not employed here) do not make this adjustment for de-skewing. 

17.2.8.3 Change of Support Results 

Change of support was applied by UC for cutoffs 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.35, 0.4, 0.45, 0.5, 0.6, 0.7, 
0.8, 0.9 and 1.0% Ni.  Parameter details are in Table 17.2.8_1. 

 
Table 17.2.8_1 

Santa Rita Deposit 

Uniform Conditioning Parameters 
 

Domains

Domain 

(Domain 1) 

Central 
Domain 

(Domain 2, 3, 4 and 5)

North 
Domain 

(Domain 6 and 7)

(Domain 8 and 9)

Discretization 4 x 6 x 3 4 x 6 x 3 4 x 6 x 3 4 x 6 x 3 4 x 6 x 3 
Punctual variance 0.072 0.087 0.098 0.059 0.050 
Gamma (v,v) 0.022 0.022 0.026 0.014 0.019 
Real block variance 0.050 0.065 0.072 0.045 0.030 
Real block correction (r) 0.853 0.887 0.870 0.896 0.083 
Kriged block correction (s) 0.823 0.862 0.829 0.883 0.810 
Kriged - Real block correction (rho) 0.983 0.971 0.966 0.986 0.979 

Information Effect 
Hole spacing (m) 6E-W x 8 N-S 
Hole direction (º) -90 � 000 
Sample length (m) 5 
Variance of Z* (Estimated Z) 0.049 0.061 0.064 0.044 0.028 
Covariance between Z and Z* 0.050 0.061 0.065 0.044 0.028 

Kriged Panel Correction 
Panel size (m) 20 E-W x 25 N-S x 5 RL 
Kriged panel correction used 0.652 0.582 0.604 0.788 0.640 

 
In all instances the Information Effect was applied to try and account for 'ore' selection 
errors during grade control.  It was assumed that grade control holes will be drilled 
vertically, on a 6m E-W by 8m N-S pattern, and will be sampled in 5m intervals.  Note the 
pit optimisation study assumes a higher density of grade control drilling. 

The so-called "kriged panel variance" is an important input for the UC.  It can be calculated 
from the composite grade distribution and variogram or it can be obtained from the 
interpolated block grade.  For the Santa Rita deposit the calculated panel variances are 
significantly higher than the variance of interpolated blocks.  This suggests that the block 
model grade distribution is smoother than calculated globally.  As the UC is applied to 
interpolated grades, a panel variance calculated from interpolated grades was used for the 
change of support. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 127 
Technical Report – May 2008 

As a check on the UC results we have carried out the Discrete Gaussian change of support 
for blocks equivalent to the SMU size (5m x 10m x 5m).  UC is a local "recoverable" 
resource estimator and the Discrete Gaussian method is a global resource estimator.  
Graphs of "volume" against cutoff, "metal" against cutoff and mean grade against cutoff are 
shown in Figures 17.2.8_1 to 17.2.8_3 for the Southern, Central and Northern Domains 
respectively.  Curves included in the graphs are as follows: 

� POINTS - point support, based on the declustered composites (Discrete Gaussian). 

� SMU IE - SMU support, using information effect (Discrete Gaussian). 

� PANEL COS - estimation block size support calculated from the variogram (Discrete 
Gaussian). 

� UC - SMU Estimate - UC estimate based on the OK and calculated UC recovered 
estimate. 

There is generally a good correspondence between the results obtained by UC 
(Section 17.2.8.2) and the global Discrete Gaussian SMU IE curves for the mean grade 
above cutoff, which confirms that the UC results are robust when it is considered that the 
methodologies are quite different. 

In addition to checks described above, a small scale conditional simulation is 
recommended.  The (co)-simulation can then be up scaled to match the UC SMU estimate 
and a 'chain of mining' method applied, with added error to replicate information effect, was 
used to select and report the model.  Previous conditional simulation studies reproduced 
the UC estimate to within 2% in terms of tonnage, grade and metal but have not been 
completed as part of this study. 

17.2.9 Estimation of Cu and Co by Regression 

A review of the composite correlation matrix (see Table 17.2.3_3) indicated a high 
correlation (above 80%) between Ni and Cu and Ni and Co.  Hence, these elements were 
reported using different regression equations for each domain as listed in Table 17.2.9_1. 

The application of regression to produce SMU estimates for Cu and Co resulted in a 
22% (Cu) and 6% (Co) increase in reported grade, as shown in Table 17.2.9_2.  The use of 
regression will reduce the local confidence of these estimates but enables the same level of 
mining selectivity to be reported as is reported for Ni.  It is likely that these models will need 
to be refined once additional close spaced data is collected.  Further small scale co-
simulation could be used to test the validity of this approach. 

 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 128 
Technical Report – May 2008

17.2.10 Resource Reporting 

The resource estimate for the Santa Rita deposit has been categorised in accordance with 
the criteria laid out in the Canadian National Instrument 43-101 ("NI 43-101") and the JORC 
code.  A combination of Measured, Indicated and Inferred Mineral Resources have been 
defined using definitive criteria determined during the validation of the grade estimates, with 
detailed consideration of the CIM categorisation guidelines. 

Applying the above confidence levels, resource classification codes were assigned to the 
resource block model using the following criteria: 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 132 
Technical Report – May 2008 

� Measured Resources 

� A portion of the shallower part of the northern zone has the drill density exists to 
report measured resources. 

� Indicated Resources 

� Blocks estimated with estimation pass 1 not categorised as measured. 

� Blocks located above base of drilling surface constructed approximately 40m 
(average drill spacing) below the deepest drilling intercept. 

� Blocks falling with a pit optimisation using a $10.00/lb Ni price. 

� Inferred Resources 

� Blocks estimated with estimation pass 1 or 2 not categorised as indicated or 
measured. 

� Blocks located above base of drilling surface constructed approximately 120m 
(average drill spacing) below the deepest drilling intercept. 

� Blocks falling with a pit optimisation using a $10.00/lb Ni price. 

� Not classified 

Blocks not qualifying as measured, indicated or inferred. 

17.2.10.1 Grade Tonnage Reporting 

Measured, Indicated and Inferred Resources are reported for the Santa Rita deposit, based 
on the "recoverable" model emulating selective mining for a 5mE x 10mN x 5mRL SMU 
(UC).  Grade tonnage reports are provided in Tables 17.2.10_2 and 17.2.10_3.  Additional 
grade tonnage reporting is provided in Appendix 10. 

A variety of cutoff grades are required for each ore type, because they vary in olivine 
content.  Olivine contains non-sulphide nickel that is not recoverable (silicate nickel), so 
lower olivine content increases nickel recovery and reduces the corresponding cutoff grade.  
Mineral resource grades reflect the combined sulphide and silicate nickel content, because 
assay technology is not accurate enough to measure sulphide nickel content alone for 
mineral resource estimation. 

There are four different types of mineralised rock.  Each has a different cutoff grade 
depending on its non-sulphide nickel content.  Pyroxenite has a low cutoff grade to reflect 
low olivine and low non-sulphide nickel content, whereas dunite has a high cutoff grade to 
reflect high olivine and high non-sulphide nickel content. 

The average cutoff grade for the new resource has been slightly reduced, compared to the 
June 2007 resource to reflect an increase in the percentage composition of pyroxenite from 
41% to 58% in the new resource. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 133 
Technical Report – May 2008 

 

Table 17.2.10_1 

Santa Rita Deposit 

Confidence Levels of Key Categorisation Criteria 
 

Items Discussion Confidence 
Drilling Techniques Diamond - industry standard approach. High 

Logging Geological logging is completed using standard nomenclature and apparent high 
quality.   

High 

Drill Sample Recovery Acceptable recoveries determined for the majority of the drilling. High 

Sub-sampling Techniques 
& Sample Preparation Industry standard for  diamond drilling 

High 

Quality of Assay Data Extensive quality control data available and has been assessed.  The majority of 
quality control data is acceptable. 

Moderate to 
High 

Verification of Sampling and 
Assaying Umpire assaying completed which indicates robust analytical data. 

Moderate 

Location of Sampling Points All drillhole collars and have been surveyed and most drillholes have been 
downhole surveyed. 

High 

Data Density and 
Distribution 

The current data spacing is considered appropriate for resource evaluation, but 
local infill drilling required to test SMU modelling assumptions. 

Moderate to 
High 

Audits or Reviews The current resource estimation has not been audited by independent parties. NA 

Database Integrity No Material errors identified. High 

Geological Interpretation The interpreted lithological and weathering boundaries are considered robust and 
of high confidence.  Mineralisation boundaries are more difficult to determine and 
part of the resource was constrained on geology and a nominal 0.2% Ni lower 
cutoff grade. 

Moderate 

Estimation and Modelling 
Techniques 

The Ni resource estimate has been generated via OK with change of support by 
UC.  Coffey Mining considers OK + UC estimation approach appropriate where 
selective mining is being considered based on cutoff grades.  Relative nuggets 
are low to moderate and therefore a moderate level of mining selectivity should 
be achieved.  Further small scale co-simulation could be completed to confirm 
the level of mining selectivity likely to be achieved for Ni, Cu and Co. 

Moderate to 
High 

Cutoff Grades Geology and a notional 0.2 % Ni cutoff grade criteria plus S grades have been 
used to complete the interpretation of mineralisation domain envelopes to 
exclude material that is definitely waste.  The estimation methods used in the 
resource estimation study are not cutoff grade dependent and allow reporting at 
a range of cutoffs   However, the Santa Rita is a low grade disseminated 
deposits and mining at elevated cutoff grades above 0.5% Ni is likely to be 
unsuccessful. 

Moderate to 
High 

Mining Factors or 
Assumptions 

The resource estimate has used geostatistical techniques which take into 
account information effect and tries to replicate a recovered resource 
(i.e. inclusive of mining dilution) given that the proposed minimum mining unit 
represents the size for which UC was applied.  The resource model thus takes 
into account proposed mining dilution and mining recovery. 

Moderate 

Tonnage Factors Detailed statistical evaluation of the dry bulk density data subdivided by 
weathering has been completed prior to assignment of average bulk densities.  
The bulk density is considered to be well established. 

High 

 
A lower resource cutoff grade has been used as set out below: 

 Host rock type Percentage composition Cutoff grade 
� Pyroxenite 58 0.22% 

� Olivine Orthopyroxenite 13 0.25% 

� Harzburgite 26 0.35% 

� Dunite 3 0.40% 

� Weighted average cutoff grade 100% 0.26%

17.3 Serra Azul Deposit 

The Serra Azul nickel laterite deposit has been estimated by Independent Consultants 
Resource Evaluations Pty Ltd (ResEval) on behalf of MNL.  The study was completed in 
March 2005 with 5 variables (Ni, Co, MgO, Fe203 and Si02) estimated as part of the study. 

17.3.1 Study Data 

The resource estimate was based on the available diamond drilling (Table 17.3.1_1) but 
excludes auger drilling completed on the deposit.  The drilling, as described in Section 11, 
has been completed by NML and a Brazilian company CBPM.  A complete data suite is 
available for Ni and Co with the exception of the CBPM drilling not including assay data for 
MgO, Fe2O3 and SiO2. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 135 
Technical Report – May 2008 

 

Table 17.3.1_1 
Summary of Serra Azul Drilling Grouped by Company and Hole Type 

 

Holes In Database Used in Serra Azul Resource 
Holes Metres Holes Metres 

CBPM Diamond 46 2,898 28 836 
MBN Diamond 72 2,621 68 2,562 
Total 118 5,519 96 3,398 

 
A plan displaying the drilling data applied to resource evaluation and the resource 
wireframes is presented as Figure 17.3.1_1. 

 
Figure 17.3.1_1 

Serra Azul Deposit - All Drilling and Resource Wireframes 

 
17.3.2 Geological Model 

ResEval generated a geological interpretation based on a combination of regolith and 
geochemistry (Table 17.3.2_1).  The regolith boundaries modelled includes a base of 
transported, base of limonite, top of saprolite (base of clay zone) and top of bedrock 
surface. 

 
Table 17.3.2_1 

Serra Azul Deposit 

Geochemical Criteria Used to Define Geological Zones 
(From Elias, 2004) 

 

Zone Ni MgO Fe2O3 SiO2
Limonite  Low >50 Low 
Clay  3-10 25-40 33-50 
Saprolite  20-30 15-22 35-40 
HG Saprolite >2 7-22 18-24 40-50 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 136 
Technical Report – May 2008 

A 0.5% Ni grade threshold was applied when generating the mineralisation constraints.  
The 0.5% Ni lower cutoff grade was arbitrarily selected, although ResEval considered this 
grade threshold corresponded with a step change in Ni grades.  In addition to the 0.5% Ni 
mineralisation zones, a separate high grade domain was generated for the saprolite in 
recognition of the high Ni grades which clustered in the saprolite. 

The criteria mineralisation constraints have been constructed applying the following general 
criteria: 

� A minimum downhole length of 4m, 

� No edge dilution, 

� Up to 3m of internal dilution was included in the intersections although generally little 
dilution was noted, and 

� The general strike and trend of the mineralised zone was used to limit the 
extrapolation of the resource boundary from drillholes. 

The interpretation was completed in cross section prior to building wireframing into 
wireframe solids.  An example cross section highlighting the mineralisation interpretation 
and drilling is presented as Figure 17.3.2_1 with Figures 17.3.2_2 and 17.3.2_3 presenting 
oblique views of the interpretation. 

17.3.3 Statistical Analysis 

The drilling data was composited to a regular 1m downhole interval, which is the dominant 
in situ sample length.  These composites were then coded with the geological model as 
described in Section 17.3.2 and used for the statistical and geostatistical analysis and 
subsequent grade estimation. 

Statistical analysis completed included the generation of descriptive and distribution 
statistics (probability plots).  Summary statistics grouped by estimation domain are 
presented in Table 17.3.3_1.  All domains and variables of interest are characterised by low 
variability and a slight positive skew, with the calculated CVs all significantly below 1.  The 
high grade saprolite domain reports the highest tenor nickel mineralisation while the 
limonite reports the lowest. 

While no outliers are evident in the distribution plots, ResEval has elected to apply a 
uniform high grade cuts (caps) to all estimated variables based on the 97.5% of the 
composite distribution.  While this is likely to be considered slightly conservative for the Ni 
and Co, applying cuts (caps) to the MgO, Fe203 and Si02 composites is not considered 
appropriate as the potential under-estimation of these variables, which maybe deleterious 
to processing, is considered sub-optimal.  Figure 17.3.3_1 presents the log probability plots 
for Ni grouped by estimation domain. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 137 
Technical Report – May 2008

MirabelaProject Page: 139 
Technical Report – May 2008 

17.3.4 Variography 

Variography was generated for the 5 principal variables based on the 1m downhole 
composites grouped by estimation domain and cut (capped) to remove the influence of high 
grade data.  The variography was generated using GeoAccess statistical software. 

Reasonably structured variograms are reported by ResEval with the major axis of continuity 
generally modelled towards 0° to 30°, although some variables have modelled with a major 
axis of continuity oriented towards 60° to 110°.  Consistent with the flat lying mineralisation, 
no dip or plunge has been modelled. 

The variography for all domains has been modelled with very low relative nugget effects 
(<10%), with the first or close range structure often dominating the non-nugget variance.  
This close range structure has generally been modelled with ranges in the order of (50 to 
100m for the major and semi-major axis, and 3 to 11m for the minor (vertical) axis).  Overall 
ranges in excess of 200m have been fitted.  All variogram models are presented in 
Table 17.3.4_1 with plots are included in Appendix 12. 

 
Table 17.3.4_1 

Serra Azul Deposit  -  Summary Variogram Models

C0 C1 A1 C2 A2 Bearing C1 A1 C2 A2 A1 A2

17.3.5 Block Model Development 

A three dimensional block model was generated for Serra Azul to enable grade estimation.  
A parent block size of 25mE x 20mN x 5mRL was selected with sub-blocking to a 5mE x 
12.5mN x 2.5mRL cell size to improve volume representation of the interpreted wireframe 
models.  Sufficient variables were included in the block model construction to enable grade 
estimation and reporting.  The block model construction parameters for each deposit are 
displayed in Table 17.3.5_1. 

 
Table 17.3.5_1 

Serra Azul Deposit  -  Block Model Parameters 
 

 East North Elevation 
Origin 8,430,100 421,400 170 
Extent (m) 1,600 1,000 190 
Parent Block size (m) 25 25 2 
Sub-Block Size (m) 6.25 6.25 1 
Number of Blocks (parent) 64 40 95 
 
The mineralisation domains, lithology and modelled oxidation were coded to the block 
model. 

Bulk density was assigned to the block model on the basis of determinations made on drill 
core and samples collected from an excavated shaft.  Principally the bulk density database 
is comprised of shaft samples which spatially are not considered spatially representative.  
Further bulk density work, in the form of additional data collected from either test pits, large 
diameter auger (Calweld) drilling or from a large number of drill core samples, has been 
recommended.  The average bulk density as assigned to the block model is presented in 
Table 17.3.5_2. 

 
Table 17.3.5_2 

Serra Azul Deposit 

Bulk Density 
 

Resource Type Number of Samples Assigned Bulk Density (t/m3)
Limonite 20 1.92 
Clay 20 1.54 
HG Saprolite 20 1.59 
Saprolite 20 1.87 
 

17.3.6 Grade Estimation 

Grade estimate for the Serra Azul deposit have been generated using ordinary kriging as 
implement in mining package Surpac.  OK is considered a robust estimation method for 
grade estimates for nickel laterite deposits such as Serra Azul. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 141 
Technical Report – May 2008 

A consistent two-pass sample search approach was applied with the search orientations 
and passes described in Tables 17.3.6_1.  No plunge or dip component has been applied 
to the estimation, however the bearing (major axis) has been varied in accordance to the 
applied the variogram models (Section 17.3.4).  The domain boundaries were used as hard 
boundaries for the major elements thus restricting estimation to composites located within 
the domain being estimated.  Parent cell estimation has been completed. 

 
Table 17.3.6_1 

Serra Azul Deposit  -  Sample Search Criteria 
 

Parameter

Co 10 0 0 125 (250) 62.5 (125) 12.5 (25) 4 32 NA 

MgO 10 0 0 125 (250) 62.5 (125) 12.5 (25) 4 32 NA 
Fe203 70 0 0 125 (250) 62.5 (125) 12.5 (25) 4 32 NA 
Si02 0 0 0 125 (250) 62.5 (125) 12.5 (25) 4 32 NA 

 
A 4 x 4 x 1 discretisation has been used in the estimate.  No maximum composite per 
drillhole per estimate or octant sample searching has been applied. 

For estimation pass 1, a 125m major axis sample search has been applied with the semi-
major axis search being 62.5m and the minor axis being 12.5m, consistent with the 
anisotropic nature of the mineralisation envelopes.  The sample search was expanded by a 
factor of 2 for the second pass estimate.  A minimum of 4 and a maximum of 32 data have 
been used in the estimation of pass 1 and 2. 

The model was validated visually, comparing the grade estimates to the composites, and 
statistically with the model mean grade versus the composites mean grade compared in 
50m slices.  As displayed in Figures 17.3.6_1 to 17.3.6_4, the grade estimate reproduces 
the input composites well for Ni with this trend repeated for the other variables estimated. 

Coffey Mining has reviewed the relevant documentation and digital data and considers the 
grade estimate to be robust and suitable for resource reporting.

Technical Report – May 2008

17.3.7 Mineral Resource Classification and Reporting 

ResEval has classified the grade estimate at Serra Azul on the basis of data density in 
accordance to the JORC code.  Areas of the deposit which have been defined by a drill 
density of 50m by 50m have been categorised as an indicated mineral resource whilst 
peripheral portions of the deposit and the northern extensions have been categorised as 
inferred mineral resource. 

Based on a review of the available data and documentation Coffey Mining concurs with the 
categorisation and considers the reported resource to be consistent with NI 43-101 and the 
classifications adopted by CIM Council in November 2004. 

Based on the above classification criteria the Serra Azul laterite nickel project resources 
above a 2% Ni lower cutoff grade and grouped by NI 43-101 categorises are provided as 
Table 17.3.7_1.  Detailed reporting of the resource is provided as Appendix 13. 

 
Table 17.3.7_1 

Serra Azul Deposit 

March 2005 Estimate 2% Ni Cutoff

Tonnes Ni % Co % Mg % Fe % Si % 

Indicated 
Limonite 0.004 2.15 0.19 1.08 57.64 18.05

Saprolite 0.048 2.24 0.05 26.29 17.06 36.02

MirabelaProject Page: 144 
Technical Report – May 2008 

17.4 Dilution and ore losses 

It is becoming common in the industry to develop resource models (particularly where 
nonlinear estimation techniques are applied), which essentially take into account potential 
dilution within the blocks, or adopt selective mining unit (SMU) as part of the resource 
modelling process.  The Santa Rita mineral resource model has been assessed to achieve 
this outcome and hence through the uniform conditioning process, the mining model 
adopted is considered to be a 'diluted' model. 

Mining recovery, based on the applied SMU, has been set to 95%.  This is to allow for ore 
loss as a result of blasting, edge effects of cutbacks and wedges of potential mill feed left 
as a function of bench face advancement with pit depth. 

17.5 Mineral Reserve Estimate 

The mineral reserve estimate was completed by NCL Brasil Ltda (NCL).  Additional 
information on mining can be found in Section 18. 

17.5.1 Operating Parameters and Criteria 

A mine plan was developed for the Santa Rita project to process 4.6 M tonnes of ore per 
year with a peak total material movement rate of 61 M tonnes per year.  The mine is 
scheduled to work seven days per week or 365 days per year.  Each day will consist of 
three 8-hour shifts.  Four mining crews will cover the operation.  Included in these 
operations will be normal drilling, blasting, loading, hauling activities, as well as the 
supporting functions of dewatering, grade control and equipment maintenance. 

The study is based on operating the Santa Rita mine with excavators of 12.0 cubic meter 
capacities and trucks with a capacity of 96 tonnes.  This type of equipment is able to 
develop the require productivity to achieve an annual total material movement of 67 M 
tonnes; and also to have good mining selectivity with the excavators as defined by the 
grade control activities. 

17.5.2 Pit Optimisation and Design Parameters 

The project's Mineral Resource model, which has been used for pit optimisation, is based 
on the non-linear resource estimation technique of uniform conditioning.  This method 
enables the estimation of local recoverable resources at different selective mining unit 
sizes, which can be substantially smaller than the drilling density, without creating bias or 
over-smoothing local values. 

Whittle Four-X pit optimisation software was applied in conjunction with Gemcom for the 
mining model preparation and actual optimisation runs. 

The economic parameters assume a nominal 4.6 M tonnes per year treatment plant 
throughput rate.  This rate has been determined as optimal, based on the project's potential 
mineral inventory, its capital requirements and operating cost profile. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 145 
Technical Report – May 2008 

17.5.2.1 Whittle Pit Optimisation Model Construction 

The Whittle Four-X model development was carried out using Gemcom software.  Whittle 
Four-X uses the amount of metal in a block for assessment, rather than the block's grade 
value.  The process calculates the grade from the supplied tonnage and metal content, 
which are provided for each model block.  The metal content for each block is calculated 
using the grade estimate derived from the uniform conditioning resource estimate. 

17.5.2.2 Base Parameters 

Table 17.5.2_1 summarises the base case economic parameters used for Whittle Four-X 
economic shells analysis and mine design. 

The mining cost estimate for the pit optimisation process is based on NCL estimates for the 
Bankable Feasibility Study Update (BFS Update) developed in January 2008.  The 
estimated average life of project mining cost was separated into various components such 
as fuel, explosives, tyres, parts, salaries etc. according to similar current operations in 
Brazil.  This resulted in the mining cost estimate of approximately US$1.30 per tonne 
shown in Table 17.5.2_1. 

Additionally to the estimated average mining cost, a variable cost with depth was modelled 
and used with the pit optimisation process, according on what is shown in Figure 17.5.2_1. 

 
Figure 17.5.2_1

17.5.2.3 Slope Angles 

Slope angles, varying from 37° to 50°, were used for the optimisation process.  This 
information was provided by VOGBR, based on the review of the BFS available data.  
Table 17.5.2_2 and Figure 17.5.2_2 summarises the values used.

The recommended angle for fresh rock was lowered down from 54º to 50º as an allowance 
for ramps during the following pit design stage. 

17.5.2.4 Whittle Four-X  Economic Shells Results 

Table 17.5.2_3 shows the results of the final optimisation run.  Pit shells were generated for 
several nickel prices, from US$2.24/lb to US$7.56/tonne.  Figures 17.5.2_3 through to 
Figures 17.5.2_6 show graphically those results.  Measured and indicated resources were 
used as only these can be converted into reserves.  Inferred mineral resources are not 
converted to reserves and are instead treated as waste for mine planning purposes. 

The optimisation was generated considering only nickel adding value to the resource model 
blocks and 5% ore loss. 

Physically analysing the obtained shells, three sectors can be identified, named as north 
pit, central pit and south pit.  The three of them join together in the final geometry.

Technical Report – May 2008

Shell�36

 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 150 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The NPV columns of Table 17.5.2_3 represent the best, worst and average operational net 
present value reported by the optimisation system, for an ore rate of 4600 ktonnes per year 
and 8% discount rate.  The "best" corresponds to the maximum value that could be 
obtained if one economic pit is mined after the other.  The "worst" is the case if each single 
pit is mined bench by bench in descending order, without considering previous shells.  The 
"average" NPV corresponds to the mean of "best" and "worst" values obtained for each pit.  
The incremental cost represents the cash cost of mining, processing and selling the 
contained material (ore and waste) between two consecutive pit shells. 

From the table and figures it can be seen that up to shell number 12, generated at a nickel 
price of US$3.64 per pound and contained resources of 18.7 M tonnes at 0.65% nickel, the 
NPV curves increase rapidly and together for the first 84 ktonnes of recovered nickel and at 
a strip ratio of 4.55 to 1. 

From shell number 12 up to shell number 18, generated at a nickel price of US$4.48 per 
pound, a big increase on the ore tonnes corresponds also with a big increase of the strip 
ratio to 7.38 to 1, decrease of the mean grade to 0.61% nickel and difference between the 
NPV curves of US$123 M. 

From shell number 18 up to shell number 36, this last one generated at the evaluating 
nickel price of US$7.00 per pound, there is a small increase in the cumulative NPV for a 
total contained resource of 87.8 M tonnes of ore and recovered nickel of 370 ktonnes. 

Analysing the last portion of the curves, it can be seen that from shell number 28 to 36, 
there is a change on the inclination of the incremental cost, making the lasts tonnes 
recovered nickel more risky, with costs over US$6.00 per pound.  Pit 28 was then the 
selected shell used for final pit design. 

It is important to note that the parameters shown in Table 17.5.2_3 are initial estimates, 
done at the beginning of the project, for the purpose of starting the design process.  They 
are not the final economic parameters developed for this study.

17.5.3 Pit and Mining Phases Designs 

17.5.3.1 Final Pit Designs 

The final pit design was based on the economic shell generated at US$5.88 per pound with 
variable slopes angle according to geotechnical domains, ranging from 37º to 50º.  
Table 17.5.3_1 shows the key open pit design parameters. 

 
Table 17.5.3_1 

Pit Design Parameters 
 

Haul Road Width 25m 
Haul Road Grade 10% 
Bench Height 10m 
Stacked Bench Height with 3 Benches Stacked (fresh rock) 30m 
Nominal Minimum Mining Phase Width 50m 
Batter Angle as per geotechnical domains 
Berm Width as per geotechnical domains 
Security Berm Width 20m every 150m wall height 
 

Geotechnical Domains Batter Height (m)
Batter Angle 

(º)
Berm Width 

(m)
Oxide 10 50 5 
Transition 10 55 5 
Fresh Rock 30 65 10 
 
The road width of 25 metres is to accommodate the selected 96 tonne trucks.  NCL used 
the 10% road gradient, which is common in the industry for these type of trucks. 

The current mine plan is designed with 10m benches stacked to 30 metres (i.e. triple 
benching) for the fresh rock material.  Mining costs for this report are based on blasting 
10m benches for the waste zones and 5m benches for the ore, to assure a good selectivity.  
As a high strip ratio is expected, this differential drilling and blasting operations don't seem 
to be difficult, as large areas are going to be 100% waste. 

Additional safety berms of 20m wide were designed on the final west wall, at 10m elevation 
on the South wall, at 130m elevation on the North wall and at 220m elevation on the West 
wall, to limit the pit wall to a maximum of 150m height, accordingly to the geotechnical 
recommendation. 

An independent pit was designed at the south that deeps down to 40m elevation.  This 
minor pit was designed with a ramp of 15m wide. 

Figure 17.5.3_1 shows the final pit design.  There are two exits on the east side of the pit 
and two exits on the west side of the pit that allow independent access to the ROM-pad 
area, primary crusher and to the main waste storage area.  The final pit is 2300m long in 
the north-south direction and 1000m wide in the east-west direction.  The pit bottom is at 
the -280 metre elevation.  The highest wall is about 630 metres on the west side.  The total 
area disturbed by the pit is about 159 hectares. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 153 
Technical Report – May 2008 

 

Figure 17.5.3_1 
Final Pit Design 

 
 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 154 
Technical Report – May 2008 

17.5.3.2 Mining Phases Designs 

NCL designed a set of eight mining phases for the Santa Rita Project Figure 17.5.3_2 
shows the phase outlines on the 90 mining bench. 

 
Figure 17.5.3_2 

Phases Design on 90 Bench 

Ph01

Ph02

Ph03

Ph04

Ph05

Ph06

Ph07

Ph08

Phases Design�on Bench 90
 

 
Phases 1 and 2 target the ore in the highest grade and lowest strip ratio in the northern 
area of the mine, down to 40m elevation. 

Phase 3 corresponds to an initial pit at the central-south area down to 80m elevation. 

Phase 4 joins together the north pit with the south pit and deeps down to -20m elevation at 
the centre. 

Phase 5 expands the centre and goes down to -120m. 

Phase 6 corresponds to the final expansion at the east, going down to -160m elevation. 

Phase 7 corresponds to the independent pit at the south. 

Phase 8 corresponds to the final expansion at the west and deeps down to the final 
configuration at -280m elevation. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 155 
Technical Report – May 2008 

17.5.3.3 Tabulation of Pit Contained Resources 

Table 17.5.3_3 summarises the pit contained resources for the final design pit at several 
different nickel recovered cutoff grades, and Table 17.5.3_3 is for the individual mining 
phases.  The tables include only measured and indicated resources using the updated 
November 2007 block model, inferred is considered as waste material. 

For mine production schedule purposes a "recovered nickel" grade was calculated to take 
into account the effect of variable recoveries for nickel, as a function of the head grade and 
lithology types, as previously detailed in Table 17.5.2_1.  Secondary elements were taken 
into account only for reporting purposes and do not interfere in the definition of ore.  
Table 17.5.3_2 shows the details for the "recovered nickel" calculation and the break even 
cutoff grade.  According to this, every block from the resource model contained in the final 
pit is considered as ore if its "recovered nickel" grade is greater or equal to 0.12%. 

 
Table 17.5.3_2 

Cutoff Calculation for Recovered Grade 
 

Processing cost per tonne 13.05 
Overall met. Recovery (for Ni recovered) 100% 
Metal price – Net per tonne 107.80 
Cutoff Grade Ni % recovered 0.12 
 
At an 0.12% "recovered nickel" cutoff grade, the final pit contains 88.4 M tonnes of ore at 
0.605% nickel and 752.2 M tonnes of total material. 

NCL does not consider Table 17.5.3_3 and Table 17.5.3_4 a statement of potential 
mineable reserves.  It is included to provide a distribution of ore grades in the pit and 
various phases.  The mineral reserve is based on the mine production schedule and is 
shown in Section 17.5.3.5. 

An appendix to this report includes a bench by bench statement of pit and phase contained 
resources at several cutoff grades. 

 
Table 17.5.3_3

17.5.4 Mine Production Schedule 

A mine production schedule was developed to show the ore tonnes, metal grades, total 
material and waste material by year throughout of the life of the mine.  The distribution of 
ore and waste contained in each of the mining phases was used to develop the schedule, 
assuring that criteria such as continuous ore exposure, mining accessibility, and consistent 
material movements were met. 

NCL used an in-house developed system to evaluate several potential production mine 
schedules.  Required annual ore tonnes and user specified annual total material 
movements are provided to the algorithm, which then calculates the mine schedule.  
Several runs at various proposed total material movement schedules were done to 
determine a good production schedule strategy.  It is important to note that this program is 
not a simulation package, but a tool for calculation of the mine schedule and haulage 
profiles for a given set of phases and constraints that must be set by the user. 

The mine plan developed by NCL does not include any special provisions for dilution 
because the resource block model is considered as already diluted. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 157 
Technical Report – May 2008 

NCL considered a 95% ore mining recovery due to the disseminated characteristics of the 
ore and the proximity of the economical cutoff to the background nickel content of the rock.  
Nevertheless, careful grade control must be carried out during mining to minimise 
misplaced ore due to the important effect of head grade on nickel recovery.  These efforts 
should include the following standard procedures: 

� Implement an intense and systematic program of sampling, mapping, laboratory 
analyses, and reporting. 

� Utilise specialized in-pit, bench sampling drills for sampling well ahead of production 
drilling and blasting. 

� Use of excavators and benches no higher than 5m (as presently planned) to 
selectively mine ore zones. 

� Maintain top laboratory staff, equipment, and procedures to provide accurate and 
timely assay reporting. 

� Utilise trained geologists and technicians to work with excavator operators in 
identifying, marking, and selectively mining and dispatching ore and waste. 

Table 17.5.4_1 shows the mine production of ore for each mining year.  The schedule is 
based on 4.6 M tonnes per year to the processing plant.  The table also shows the total 
material movement from the mine by year, which peaks at 61 M tonnes per year during 
commercial production, aiming to maintain recovered nickel at or near 19 ktonnes for 
years 1 through 5.  The limit on the ore production is the number of benches that it is 
possible to mine in a year in a single phase, or vertical development per phase. 

 
Table 17.5.4_1 

Mine Production Schedule

Y19 2,026 0.712 14.4 1,136 - - 3,162 0.56 1,013 1,013 

Total 83,999 0.605 508.2 655,605 11,929 682 752,215 7.96 41,568 42,431 
1 TSF: Tailings Storage Facility 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 158 
Technical Report – May 2008 

 

The total mined waste considers three destinations for the material, the main waste storage 
area, the tailings storage facility for the dam construction and topsoil stripping and disposal 
to specific stockpile location: 

� The estimate of the topsoil stripping and disposal comes from the calculated new 
opened areas, according to the mine production schedule on a yearly basis, 
assuming a topsoil depth of 0.3m and a density of 1.8 tonnes/m3. 

� It is been considered that 100% of the waste material mined during the pre-striping 
period will go to the Tailings Storage Facility (TSF) construction, as informed to NCL 
by Mirabela. 

� Finally, the material to the waste storage area corresponds to the difference between 
the total mined waste from the mine production schedule and the requirement for the 
TSF and the topsoil stripping. 

The total of the mined ore will be hauled to a ROM-pad area close by the primary crusher 
for later rehandle and blending to feed the processing plant.  It is been considered that 50% 
of the total plant feed will be rehandled and 50% for direct tipping. 

The preproduction period requires the mining of 13 M tonnes of total material to expose 
sufficient ore to make it a reliable ore source for the start of commercial production in 
Year 1.  The preproduction period will require approximately 15 months.  The ore mined 
during preproduction will be stockpiled in the ROM-pad area near the primary crusher to 
make up part of Year 1 ore production. 

The plant feed is shown in Table 17.5.4_2.  It shows that Year 1 ore to the plant is made up 
of material mined during preproduction and Year 1. 

 
Table 17.5.4_2

MirabelaProject Page: 159 
Technical Report – May 2008 

The mine production schedule considers an extra ore movement during the first year of 
commercial production, 1.2M tonnes more than the estimated ramp-up of the processing 
plant.  This extra movement is to assure the ore availability and to generate the require 
blending. 

The plant feed rates for Year 1 and Year 2 in corresponds to the estimated ramp-up of the 
processing plant, provided to NCL by Mirabela personnel. 

17.5.5 Mineral Reserve 

It is the opinion of NCL that the mine production schedule defines the mineral reserve for a 
mining project.  Table 17.5.5_1 reports the mineral reserve of the Santa Rita Project based 
on the production schedule used for this study. 

 
Table 17.5.5_1 

Proven & Probable Mineral Reserves (1)(2)(3)
 

Ore Source ktonnes Ni (%) 
Recovered Ni 

(%) 
Recovered Ni 

(ktonnes) 
Proven Reserve 8,826 0.678 0.449 39.6 
Probable Reserve 75,173 0.596 0.416 312.8 
Total Reserve 83,999 0.605 0.420 352.5 
 

Total Material 752,215 Strip Ratio 7.96 
1) Based on a nickel price of $7.00 per pound. 
2) The Mineral Reserves as set out in the table above have been estimated by Carlos Guzmán of NCL Brasil Ltda, who is a Qualified 

Person under NI 43-101 and Member of the AusIMM. 
3) Numbers may not add up due to rounding. 

 
The difference between the reported reserves of Table 17.5.5_1 and the resources 
contained in final pit of Table 17.5.3_3 corresponds to the assumed 5% losses during 
mining operations. 

All mining modifiers, including aspects relating to metallurgy, processing, infrastructure 
and/or mining have been included in the Mineral Reserve determination.   Environmental, 
permitting, legal, title, taxation, socio-economic, marketing, and or political factors have 
also been considered, where relevant, and are discussed in various sections of this report 
(refer to Sections 4, 16, 18 and 19).  



 

MirabelaProject Page: 160 
Technical Report – May 2008 

18 MINING OPERATIONS 
18.1 Mining Operations 

The current mining plan is based on exploiting the Santa Rita sulphide nickel deposit by 
conventional open pit mining techniques using excavators of 12 cubic meter capacity and 
trucks with a capacity of 96 tonnes.  This type of equipment is able to develop the required 
productivity to achieve the required material movement; and also to have good mining 
selectivity with the excavators as defined by the grade control activities. 

The fleet is complemented with drilling rigs for ore and waste, as 100% of material is 
defined as hard rock. 

Auxiliary equipment includes track dozers, wheel dozers, motor graders and water truck.  
Additionally a reverse circulation drill rig is included for grade control purposes. 

The operations are planned to be performed and managed by the owner. 

18.2 Open Pit Design 

Using the resource block model, the pit slope recommendations, and the expected 
operating costs based on the mining and milling methods selected and the results of the 
Bankable Feasibility Study, an open-pit was designed, a mine production schedule was 
developed and the mineral reserve was estimated, as previously detailed in Section 17 of 
this report. 

18.3 Waste and Stockpiles Storage Areas 

One waste rock storage area was designed for the Santa Rita Project.  The area available 
for waste storage is located at the east of the pit, in between the tailings dam to the north 
and the "Peixe" river to the south.  The total extent of the pile is 2000m in the east-west 
direction by 1650m in the north-south direction, covering a total area of approximately 
294 hectares.  The total height is 230m, from 125m RL to 355m RL.  The final configuration 
is shown on Figure 18.3_1. 

The pile was designed in 10m lifts.  Each lift is constructed at the approximate angle of 
repose of 36°.  A 10m set-back between two10m lifts maintains the overall angle at 28° to 
facilitate reclamation and long term stability.  Every 60m height a wider 20m berm was 
designed to avoid rock falling from such high elevations.  A constant 2.2 tonnes/m3 loose 
density was used, based on a 20% swell factor.

MirabelaProject 
Technical Report – May 2008  Page: 162 

The total mined waste considers three destinations for the material, the main waste storage 
area, the tailings storage facility for the dam construction and topsoil stripping and disposal 
to a specific stockpile location: 

� The estimate of the topsoil stripping and disposal comes from the calculated new 
opened areas, according to the mine production schedule on a yearly basis, 
assuming a topsoil depth of 0.3m and a density of 1.8 tonnes/m3. 

� It is considered that 100% of the waste material mined during the pre-stripping period 
will go to the Tailings Storage Facility (TSF) construction, as informed to NCL by 
Mirabela. 

� Finally, the material to the waste storage area corresponds to the difference between 
the total mined waste from the mine production schedule and the requirement for the 
TSF and the topsoil stripping. 

The construction sequence of the main waste storage area was always considered from 
bottom to top.  The pile was divided into four sections, because of the big horizontal 
extension of the full area and the capacity of each section was calculated every 10m lift.  
Using NCL's in-house developed system, a construction schedule was performed for these 
four sections to smooth the truck fleet.  The general applied strategy was to reduce long 
horizontal and uphill hauling distances within the waste storage area when mining occurs at 
high depths in the pit. 

The designed pile covers the total storage requirement of 656 M tonnes of waste material 
scheduled in the mine production plan. 

Table 18.3_1 through to Table 18.3_4 show the amount of material placed in each area by 
mining year. 

18.4 Production Schedules 

A mine production schedule was developed to show the ore tonnes, metal grades, total 
material and waste material by year throughout of the life of the mine.  The distribution of 
ore and waste contained in each of the mining phases was used to develop the schedule, 
assuring that criteria such as continuous ore exposure, mining accessibility, and consistent 
material movements were met. 

Table 18.4_1 shows the mine production of ore for each mining year.  The schedule is 
based on 4.6M tonnes per year to the processing plant.  The table also shows the total 
material movement from the mine by year, which peaks at 61 M tonnes per year during 
commercial production, aiming to maintain recovered nickel at or near 18.5 ktonnes for 
years 1 through 5.  The limit on the ore production is the number of benches that it is 
possible to mine in a year in a single phase, or vertical development per phase.

Y15 4,600 0.656 30.2 17,268 - - 21,868 3.75 2,300 2,300 
Y16 4,600 0.680 31.3 10,886 - - 15,486 2.37 2,300 2,300 
Y17 4,600 0.697 32.1 8,243 - - 12,843 1.79 2,300 2,300 
Y18 4,600 0.677 31.1 6,989 - - 11,589 1.52 2,300 2,300 
Y19 2,026 0.712 14.4 1,136 - - 3,162 0.56 1,013 1,013 

Total 83,999 0.605 508.2 655,605 11,929 682 752,215 7.96 41,568 42,431 
1 TSF: Tailings Storage Facility 

 
The total of the mined ore will be hauled to a ROM-pad area close by the primary crusher 
for later rehandle and blending to feed the processing plant.  It is been considered that 50% 
of the total plant feed will be rehandled and 50% for direct tipping. 

The preproduction period requires the mining of 13 M tonnes of total material to expose 
sufficient ore to make it a reliable ore source for the start of commercial production in 
Year 1.  The preproduction period will require approximately 15 months.  The ore mined 
during preproduction will be stockpiled in the ROM-pad area near the primary crusher to 
make up part of Year 1 ore production. 

The plant feed is shown on Table 18.4_2.  It shows that Year 1 ore to the plant is made up 
of material mined during preproduction and Year 1.  The plant feed rate for Year 1 
considers a ramp-up period, which corresponds to 82% of the designed capacity in a yearly 
basis. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 168 
Technical Report – May 2008

18.5 Mine Equipment 

18.5.1 General 

Mine equipment requirements were calculated based on the annual mine production 
schedule, the mine work schedule, and equipment annual production capacity estimates. 

Table 18.5_1 provides a summary of the peak number of units required for preproduction 
and commercial production.  Table 18.5_2 provides the fleet requirements by year during 
the mine life.  This represents the equipment necessary to perform the following duties: 

1. Construct roads to the initial mining areas as well as to the crusher, waste storage 
areas, and leach pads.  Construct additional roads as needed to support mining 
activity. 

2. The preproduction development required to expose ore for initial production. 

3. Mine and transport ore to the ROM-pad area.  Mine and transport waste material from 
the pit to the appropriate storage areas. 

4. Maintain all the mine work areas, in-pit haul roads, and external haul roads.  Also 
maintain the waste storage areas. 

5. Rehandle the ore (load, transport and auxiliary equipment) from the ROM-pad to feed 
the primary crusher. 

Topsoil striping and disposal is considered to be developed by a contractor, with minor 
equipment, according to the mine necessities. 



 

MirabelaProject Page: 169 
Technical Report – May 2008 

 

Table 18.5_1 
Peak Fleet Requirements for Preproduction and Commercial Production 

 

Element Type Preproduction Commercial Production 
Tamrock Pantera 1500 2 6 
Komatsu PC2000-8 Excavator (12 cu m) 2 5 
Komatsu WA800-3 Wheel Loader 0 1 
Komatsu HD785-5 truck (96mt) 8 48 
Komatsu D275AX-5 Track Dozer 2 4 
Komatsu WD600-3 Wheel Dozer 2 3 
Komatsu GD825A-2 Grader 2 3 
Scania Water Truck (20000 litre) 2 3 
Atlas Copco Explorac 50 1 1
