Printed: 7/30/2007 Page 3 of 55 

1 DISCUSSION 

1.1 Blanks 
 

Blank material submitted returned satisfactory results, although a limited number of Ni 
and Cu blanks returned elevated grades potentially indicating some low level 
contamination (generally <0.01% Ni, <0.005% Cu and <5ppm Co) at the sample 
preparation process.  The generally infrequent values above detection is not material for 
resource estimation study as the elevated blank assays are generally below the detection 
of the resource estimate. 

 

Out of the 1988 blank samples assayed, one sample returned anomalous values for Ni 
(1920ppm), Cu (503ppm) and Co (115ppm).  Two more samples also return Cu and Co 
values that are considered anomalous – sample 202069 (3050ppm Cu and 34ppm Co) 
and sample 202100 (396ppm Cu and 55ppm Co).  No obvious explanation could be 
found for theses results but their positions in the sampling sequence, they are not 
considered to have a material impact on the resource estimation. 

 

None of the listed 'bad values' for Pd, Pt and Au are considered to be at levels that would 
have a material impact on the resource estimation. 

 

Ongoing monitoring of QA/QC protocols and data is recommended to ensure 
minimization of further errors. 

 

 

1.2 Standards submitted by MBN 
 

Standard 1 – Reference GBM396-8C (as defined by Geostats Pty Ltd) 
 

Certified value  Ni - 4010ppm (expected range - 3,244 to 4,776ppm) 
Cu - 246ppm (expected range - 196 to 296ppm) 
Co - 140ppm (expected range - 102 to 296ppm) 

 

The standards are certified for Ni, Cu and Co only, with the acceptable assay ranges 3 
times the standard deviation of the certified grade. 

 

In general, the CRM assaying falls within acceptable ranges, with the majority of samples 
falling within the tolerance limit (2 times the recommended standard deviation value). 

 



Printed: 7/30/2007 Page 4 of 55 

No material bias was identified for Ni (<2.5%) and Co (4%) although Cu assays 
consistently over reports relative to the certified value by approximately 7%.  The bias for 
Co has increased since the report compiled in late 2006 (<3%), so this will be monitored 
carefully in the future.  Further umpire assaying is planned to investigate this bias. 

 

Pd, Pt and Au results are acceptable.  One sample (383170) returned unexplained 
anomalous results for Pd (1ppm) and Pt (1ppb) but the sample lies outside the 
mineralised zone and is not considered to have a material impact on the resource 
estimation.  Three samples returned unexplained low results for Au, including 368420 
(205ppb), 370220 (559ppb) and 374420 (571ppb) but these are not considered to have a 
material impact on the resource estimation. 

 

 

Standard 2 – Reference GBM301-3 (as defined by Geostats Pty Ltd) 
 

Certified value  Ni – 7,843ppm (expected range – 7,057 to 8,629ppm) 
Cu - 770ppm (expected range - 672 to 868ppm) 
Co - 155ppm (expected range - 155 to 219ppm) 

 

In general, the CRM assaying falls within acceptable ranges, with the majority of samples 
falling within the tolerance limit (2 times the recommended standard deviation value). 

 

No material bias was identified for Ni (<1%) and Co (<1.5%) although Cu assays 
consistently over reports relative to the certified value by approximately 4%.  Further 
umpire assaying is planned to investigate this bias. 

 

Pd and Pt grades for this standard are not appropriate for the analytical method as they 
are above the maximum recommended detection limits. 

 

Three samples returned unexplained low results for Au, including 372220 (13ppb), 
372520 (407ppb) and 389020 (0.5ppb) but these are not considered to have a material 
impact on the resource estimation. 

 

 
Standard 3 – Reference GBM999-1 (as defined by Geostats Pty Ltd) 
 

Certified value  Ni – 11,728ppm (expected range – 10,326 to 13,130ppm) 
Cu - 435ppm (expected range - 367 to 503ppm) 
Co - 239ppm (expected range - 239 to 355ppm) 

 

In general, the CRM assaying falls within acceptable ranges, with the majority of samples 
falling within the tolerance limit (2 times the recommended standard deviation value). 

 



Printed: 7/30/2007 Page 5 of 55 

No material bias was identified for Ni (<0.5%) and Co (<0.5%) although Cu assays 
consistently over reports relative to the certified value by approximately 8%.  Further 
umpire assaying is planned to investigate this bias. 

 

Pd, Pt and Au results are acceptable.  Three samples returned unexplained slightly low 
or high results for Pd and Pt, including 201320 (0.05ppm Pd and 0.03ppm Pt), 371220 
(0.05ppm Pd and 0.02ppm Pt) and 378120 (0.03ppm Pd and 0.05ppm Pt) but these are 
not considered to have a material impact on the resource estimation. 

 

Four samples returned unexplained high results for Au, including 370320 (~120ppb), 
374520 (~160ppb), 387120 (~135ppb) and 391320 (~260ppb).  Based on a review of 
their position in the sampling sequence, these samples are not considered to have a 
material impact on the resource estimation. 

 

 

1.3 Duplicates 
 

Field Duplicates 
 

Results for field duplicates are considered acceptable.  A minor number of samples had 
duplicate values greater than the accepted 20% range but this is not considered to have 
a material impact on the resource estimation.  MBN no longer submits field duplicated 
(i.e. quarter core comparisons).  It has been recommended by RSG Global to use coarse 
crush duplicates, as discussed below. 

 

 

Coarse Crush Duplicates 
 

Results for coarse crush duplicates are considered acceptable. 

 

A minor number of samples had duplicate values for Ni, Cu and Co greater than the 
accepted 20% range but this is not considered to have a material impact on the resource 
estimation. 

 

It is noted that the duplicate results for Pd, Pt and especially Au show more variability 
than the Ni, Cu and Co results.  This is a reflection of the Fire Assay method used on 
these samples.  This higher variability is considered acceptable and does not have a 
material impact on the resource estimation. 



Printed: 7/30/2007 Page 6 of 55

3.5 Pd FA_ICPMS 
Method used is not appropriate for the standard value.

3.6 Pt FA_ICPMS 
Method used is not appropriate for the standard value.  
Values returned are above the detection limit.

Appendix 3C:  QAQC Analysis - Santa Rita Deposit April to September 2007 Page 3 of 71 

8.1 Ni 4A_ICPAES .........................................................................................................45 
8.2 Cu 4A_ICPAES ........................................................................................................48 
8.3 Co 4A_ICPAES ........................................................................................................50 
8.4 Pd FA_ICPMS ..........................................................................................................52 
8.5 Pt FA_ICPMS ...........................................................................................................57 
8.6 Au FA_ICPMS ..........................................................................................................64 



Appendix 3C:  QAQC Analysis - Santa Rita Deposit April to September 2007 Page 4 of 71 

1 DISCUSSION 

1.1 Blanks 
 

Blank material submitted returned satisfactory results, although a limited number of Ni 
and Cu blanks returned elevated grades potentially indicating some low level 
contamination (generally <0.01% Ni, <0.005% Cu and <5ppm Co) at the sample 
preparation process.  The generally infrequent values above detection is not material for 
resource estimation study as the elevated blank assays are generally below the detection 
of the resource estimate. 

 

Out of the 1279 blank samples assayed, one sample returned anomalous values for Ni 
(2580ppm), Cu (814ppm) and Co (375ppm).  Investigation of this indicates a sample out 
of sequence, which has subsequently been corrected in the database.  The position of 
this sample in the sampling sequence indicates it is not considered to have a material 
impact on the resource estimation. 

 

None of the listed 'bad values' for Pd and Pt are considered to be at levels that would 
have a material impact on the resource estimation. 

 

Ongoing monitoring of QA/QC protocols and data is recommended to ensure 
minimization of further errors. 

 

 

1.2 Standards submitted by MBN 
 

Standard 1 – Reference GBM396-8C (as defined by Geostats Pty Ltd) 

 

Certified value  Ni - 4010ppm (expected range - 3,244 to 4,776ppm) 
Cu - 246ppm (expected range - 196 to 296ppm) 
Co - 140ppm (expected range - 102 to 178ppm) 

 

The standards are certified for Ni, Cu and Co only, with the acceptable assay ranges 3 
times the standard deviation of the certified grade. 

 

In general, the CRM assaying falls within acceptable ranges, with the majority of samples 
falling within the tolerance limit (2 times the recommended standard deviation value). 

 



Appendix 3C:  QAQC Analysis - Santa Rita Deposit April to September 2007 Page 5 of 71 

No material bias was identified for Ni (<4%) and Co (4%) although Cu and Co assays 
consistently over reports relative to the certified value by approximately 7.7% and 6.2% 
respectively.  Further umpire assaying is planned to investigate this bias. 

 

Pd, Pt and Au results are acceptable. 

 

 

Standard 2 – Reference GBM301-3 (as defined by Geostats Pty Ltd) 

 

Certified value  Ni – 7,843ppm (expected range – 7,057 to 8,629ppm) 
Cu - 770ppm (expected range - 672 to 868ppm) 
Co - 155ppm (expected range - 155 to 219ppm) 

 

In general, the CRM assaying falls within acceptable ranges, with the majority of samples 
falling within the tolerance limit (2 times the recommended standard deviation value). 

 

No material bias was identified for Ni (<4%) and Co (<1.3%) although Cu assays 
consistently over reports relative to the certified value.  Further umpire assaying is 
planned to investigate this bias. 

 

Pd and Pt grades for this standard are not appropriate for the analytical method as they 
are above the maximum recommended detection limits. 

 

Three samples returned unexpected results for Ni, including 390820 (1800ppm), 398020 
(1380ppm) and 399220 (4250ppm) but these are not considered to have a material impact 
on the resource estimation.  Sample 399220 has been subsequently corrected to be 
Standard 1. 

 

 

Standard 3 – Reference GBM999-1 (as defined by Geostats Pty Ltd) 

 

Certified value  Ni – 11,728ppm (expected range – 10,326 to 13,130ppm) 
Cu - 435ppm (expected range - 367 to 503ppm) 
Co - 239ppm (expected range - 239 to 355ppm) 

 

In general, the CRM assaying falls within acceptable ranges, with the majority of samples 
falling within the tolerance limit (2 times the recommended standard deviation value).  
Only one sample returned a higher than expected value (397470 at 14500ppm Ni) 
although its Cu and Co values are representative. 

 

No material bias was identified for Ni (<0.5%) and Co (<0.8%) although Cu assays 
consistently over reports relative to the certified value by approximately 8.6%.  Further 
umpire assaying is planned to investigate this bias. 

 



Appendix 3C:  QAQC Analysis - Santa Rita Deposit April to September 2007 Page 6 of 71 

Pd, Pt and Au results are acceptable. 

 

Standard 4 – Reference GBM396-8 (as defined by Geostats Pty Ltd) 

 

Certified value  Ni - 4064ppm (expected range - 3,312 to 4,816ppm) 
Cu - 246ppm (expected range - 196 to 296ppm) 
Co - 140ppm (expected range - 102 to 178ppm) 

 

This new standard is certified for Ni, Cu and Co only, with the acceptable assay ranges 3 
times the standard deviation of the certified grade.  It was added to the standard list to 
replace Standard 1 in late September 2007. 

 

In general, the CRM assaying falls within acceptable ranges, with the majority of samples 
falling within the tolerance limit (2 times the recommended standard deviation value). 

 

No material bias was identified for Ni (<1.7%) although Cu and Co assays consistently 
over report relative to the certified value by approximately 6.7% and 5.5% respectively.   

 

Pd, Pt and Au results are acceptable.   

 

 

1.3 Duplicates 
 

Field Duplicates 

 

Results for field duplicates are considered acceptable.  A minor number of samples had 
duplicate values greater than the accepted 20% range but this is not considered to have 
a material impact on the resource estimation.  MBN no longer submits field duplicated 
(i.e. quarter core comparisons).  It has been recommended by RSG Global to use coarse 
crush duplicates, as discussed below. 

 

 

Coarse Crush Duplicates 

 

Results for coarse crush duplicates are considered acceptable. 

 

A minor number of samples had duplicate values for Cu and Co greater than the 
accepted 20% range but this is not considered to have a material impact on the resource 
estimation. 

 

It is noted that the duplicate results for Pd, Pt and especially Au show more variability 
than the Ni, Cu and Co results.  This is a reflection of the Fire Assay method used on 



Appendix 3C:  QAQC Analysis - Santa Rita Deposit April to September 2007 Page 7 of 71 

these samples.  This higher variability is considered acceptable and does not have a 
material impact on the resource estimation. 



Appendix 3C:  QAQC Analysis - Santa Rita Deposit April to September 2007 Page 8 of 71
